THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        Khalid A. Muhammad, Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Emerald M. Muhammad, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Orangeburg County
Â William J. Wylie, Jr., Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-001
Submitted November 1, 2006 â€“ Filed January 9, 2007Â Â Â  

REMANDED


  
    
      
        Clarissa Warren Joyner, of Orangeburg, for Appellant.
        Janne Berry Osborne, of Orangeburg, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: Â Emerald Muhammad (Mother) appeals the family courtâ€™s order awarding custody of her daughter, Fahrah (Child), to Khalid Muhammad (Father).Â  We remand.
FACTS
Father and Mother married on December 28, 2000. Â Prior to their marriage, on July 29, 2000, Father and Mother had a child. Â The Muhammads resided together in Orangeburg, South Carolina until sometime between September and December 31, 2002, when Mother moved with Child to New York. Â The parties dispute when the move occurred, and Father claims he did not know his wife and child were leaving prior to December 31, 2002. 
Mother and Child lived in New York with Motherâ€™s parents.Â  Child suffers from developmental issues resulting in underdeveloped communication skills. Â Mother enrolled Child in a school with programs designed to assist children with special needs.Â  Child flourished in New York. Â 
Both Father and Mother filed custody actions. Â Father filed in South Carolina on April 17, 2003 and served Mother on December 17, 2003. Mother filed in New York on October 14, 2003.Â  Father was never personally served, but was apparently served by mail in January of 2004.Â  On March 4, 2004, the New York family court issued an order awarding custody to Mother. Â The New York order indicates there was proper service on Father.Â  
On November 19, 2004, the South Carolina family court issued a final order awarding custody to Father and directing law enforcement to assist in obtaining physical custody of Child.Â  Mother timely filed a motion for reconsideration in the South Carolina family court.Â  In that motion and its attachments, Mother argued the family court lacked jurisdiction to decide the case because New York was Childâ€™s home state, the New York family court issued the initial decree of custody in this matter, and substantial evidence of Childâ€™s present and future care exists in New York.Â  Mother averred the Uniform Child Custody Jurisdiction Act (UCCJA) mandates the South Carolina court make an inquiry to the New York family court concerning the simultaneous proceedings in order to avoid relitigation. 
Evidence in the record indicates that the parties knew cases had been filed in both New York and South Carolina.Â  Neither the New York family court nor the South Carolina family court was afforded full candor during its proceedings.Â  In fact, it appears the New York family court did not have notice of the South Carolina case prior to issuing its order. Â The South Carolina family court heard of the New York order during the motion to reconsider filed by Mother.
In an order dated August 18, 2005, the South Carolina family court denied Motherâ€™s motion for reconsideration concluding â€œthat South Carolina was the childâ€™s home state when this action was commenced . . . .â€ Â Child now resides with Father in South Carolina. Â This appeal follows.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In appeals from the family court, the appellate court has authority to find facts in accordance with its own view of the preponderance of the evidence.Â  This does not require the appellate court, however, to disregard the findings of the family court, which saw and heard the witnesses.Â  Badeaux v. Davis, 337 S.C 195, 202, 522 S.E.2d 835, 838 (Ct. App. 1999).
In all child custody controversies, the controlling considerations are the childrenâ€™s welfare and best interests.Â  Cook v. Cobb, 271 S.C. 136, 140, 245 S.E.2d 612, 614 (1978).Â  In reaching a determination as to custody, the family court should consider how the custody decision will impact all areas of the childâ€™s life, including physical, psychological, spiritual, educational, familial, emotional, and recreational aspects.Â  Pountain v. Pountain, 332 S.C. 130, 136, 503 S.E.2d 757, 760 (Ct. App. 1998).Â  Additionally, the court must assess each partyâ€™s character, fitness, and attitude as they affect the child.Â  Id. at 136, 503 S.E.2d at 760.Â Â  Indeed, â€œthe totality of circumstances peculiar to each case constitutes the only scale upon which the ultimate decision can be weighed.â€Â  Davenport v. Davenport, 265 S.C. 524, 527, 220 S.E.2d 228, 230 (1975).Â Â  
Custody decisions are matters left largely to the discretion of the trial court.Â  Stroman v. Williams, 291 S.C. 376, 378, 353 S.E.2d 704, 705 (Ct. App. 1987).Â  An abuse of discretion occurs either when the court is controlled by some error of law or where the order, based upon findings of fact, lacks evidentiary support.Â  McKnight v. McKnight, 283 S.C. 540, 543, 324 S.E.2d 91, 93 (Ct. App. 1984).Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
Mother claims the South Carolina family court did not comply with the UCCJA because it failed to contact the New York family court concerning a simultaneous custody action.Â  We agree.
The UCCJA provides, in pertinent part that:

  (a) A court of this State which is competent to decide child custody matters has jurisdiction to make a child custody determination by initial or modification decree if:
      (1) this State (i) is the home state of the child at the time of commencement of the proceeding, or (ii) had been the childâ€™s home state within six months before commencement of the proceeding and the child is absent from this State because of his removal or retention by a person claiming his custody or for other reasons, and a parent or person acting as parent continues to live in this State; or Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 
  (2) it is in the best interest of the child that a court of this State assume jurisdiction because (i) the child and his parents, or the child and at least one contestant, have a significant connection with this State and (ii) there is available in this State substantial evidence concerning the childâ€™s present or future care, protection, training and personal relationships; orÂ  
  . . . .
   (4) (i) it appears that no other state would have jurisdiction under prerequisites substantially in accordance with paragraphs (1), (2) or (3) of subsection (a), or another state has declined to exercise jurisdiction on the ground that this State is the more appropriate forum to determine the custody of the child and (ii) it is in the best interest of the child that this court assume jurisdiction.
  (b) Except under paragraphs (3) and (4) of subsection (a), physical presence in this State of the child, or of the child and one of the contestants, is not alone sufficient to confer jurisdiction on a court of this State to make a child custody determination.
    (c) Physical presence of the child, while desirable, is not a prerequisite for jurisdiction to determine his custody.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-788 (1976).
Further, the South Carolina Code instructs family court judges on the proper actions when there is a simultaneous proceeding in another state, namely:

  (a) A court of this State shall not exercise its jurisdiction under this subarticle if at the time of filing the petition a proceeding concerning the custody of the child was pending in a court of another state exercising jurisdiction substantially in conformity with this subarticle, unless the proceeding is stayed by the court of the other state because this State is a more appropriate forum or for other reasons.
   (b) Before hearing the petition in a custody proceeding the court shall examine the pleadings and other information supplied by the parties under Â§ 20-7-800 and shall consult the child custody registry established under Â§ 20-7-814 concerning the pendency of proceedings with respect to the child in other states. Â If the court has reason to believe that proceedings may be pending in another state it shall direct an inquiry to the state court administrator or other appropriate official of the other state.
   (c) If the court is informed during the course of the proceeding that a proceeding concerning the custody of the child was pending in another state before the court assumed jurisdiction it shall stay the proceeding and communicate with the court in which the other proceeding is pending to the end that the issue may be litigated in the more appropriate forum and that information be exchanged in accordance with Â§Â§ 20-7-820 through 20-7-826. Â If a court of this State has made a custody decree before being informed of a pending proceeding in a court of another state it shall immediately inform that court of the fact. Â If the court is informed that a proceeding was commenced in another state after it assumed jurisdiction it shall likewise inform the other court to the end that the issues may be litigated in the more appropriate forum.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-794 (1976).
We find the South Carolina family court erred in that it did not contact the New York family court when confronted with evidence that there may be a simultaneous proceeding in that state.Â  
CONCLUSION
Keeping in mind the mandates of the UCCJA, we hereby remand to the family court.Â  Upon remand, the family court shall, within forty-five days, make an inquiry to the New York family court to determine the most appropriate forum in accordance with Section 20-7-794 of the South Carolina Code of Laws (1976), and issue an order setting forth with specificity all findings of fact and factors considered in determining the appropriate forum. Â Â This Court does not address Motherâ€™s remaining issues without prejudice so that they may be raised in any subsequent appeal, if necessary.Â  Accordingly, the family courtâ€™s order is
REMANDED. [1]
HEARN, C.J., KITTREDGE, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        James Randy Todd, Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        James Oâ€™Hara Brereton both Individually and as agent for VT, Inc., Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Horry County
Â Paula H. Thomas, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-002
Submitted December 1, 2006 â€“ Filed January 9, 2007

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Ian D. Maguire, Vivien K. Sookram, of Myrtle Beach; for Appellant.
        G. Michael Smith, of Conway; for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  In this civil action, James Randy Todd appeals the circuit courtâ€™s order granting summary judgment in favor of James Oâ€™Hara Brereton and VT, Inc. (collectively Brereton). Â Â We affirm.
FACTS
On November 30, 1999, Todd and Brereton were involved in an auto accident.Â  At the time of the accident, Brereton was driving a vehicle owned by VT, Inc.Â  In July 2001, Todd executed a release which provides, in its entirety:

  For the sole consideration of Five Hundred ($500.00) dollars, the receipt and sufficiency whereof is hereby acknowledged, the undersigned hereby releases and forever discharges James O. Brereton, his heirs, executors, administrators, agents and assigns, and all other persons, firms or corporations liable or, who might be claimed to be liable none of whom admit any liability to the undersigned but all expressly deny any liability from any and all claims, demands, damages, actions, causes of action or suits of any kind or nature whatsoever, and particularly on account of all injuries, known and unknown, both to person and property, which have resulted or may in the future develop from an accident which occurred on or about the 30th day of November, 1999, at or near Conway, S.C.
  This release expressly reserves all rights of the parties released to pursue their legal remedies, if any, against the undersigned, their heirs, executors, agents and assigns.
  Undersigned hereby declares that the terms of this settlement have been completely read and are fully understood and voluntarily accepted for the purpose of making a full and final compromise adjustment and settlement of any and all claims, disputed or otherwise, on account of the injuries and damages above mentioned, and for the express purpose of precluding forever any further or additional claims arising out of the aforesaid accident.

Todd signed the release and acknowledged receipt of the $500. 
Thereafter, in 2002, Todd brought a negligence action against Brereton seeking to recover damages as a result of the 1999 auto accident. Â Brereton answered, raising as an affirmative defense the release signed by Todd in 2001.Â  Brereton also moved for summary judgment, arguing the release was a complete bar to Toddâ€™s action.[1]Â  At the summary judgment hearing, Brereton argued the terms of the release were clear and unambiguous and no extrinsic evidence was needed to explain its terms.Â  Todd argued the release should not bar the action because (1) the release was an unconscionable contract of adhesion; (2) it was not properly signed by VT; (3) he was not represented by an attorney when he signed the release; (4) he did not understand the terms of the release; and (5) he was taking large doses of Oxycontin at the time he signed the release.Â  The circuit court found that Todd signed the release and that the terms of the release were clear and unambiguous.Â  Accordingly, the circuit court granted summary judgment in favor of Brereton, finding Toddâ€™s action was barred by the release.Â  The circuit court denied Toddâ€™s motion for reconsideration, and this appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œIn reviewing the grant of summary judgment, [the appellate court] applies the same standard that governs the trial court under Rule 56, SCRCP: summary judgment is proper when there is no genuine issue as to any material fact and the moving party is entitled to judgment as a matter of law.â€Â  Pittman v. Grand Strand Entmâ€™t, Inc., 363 S.C. 531, 536, 611 S.E.2d 922, 925 (2005).Â  The appellate court therefore reviews all ambiguities, conclusions, and inferences arising in and from the evidence in a light most favorable to the non-moving party.Â  Id.Â  Once the moving party meets the initial burden of showing an absence of evidentiary support for the opponentâ€™s case, the nonmoving party must come forward with specific facts showing there is a genuine issue for trial and cannot simply rest on mere allegations or denials contained in the pleadings.Â  Miller v. Blumenthal Mills, Inc., 365 S.C. 204, 220, 616 S.E.2d 722, 730 (Ct. App. 2005).
LAW/ANALYSIS
On appeal, Todd argues the circuit court erred in granting summary judgment because the release was an unconscionable contract of adhesion. Â We disagree.
A release is a contract.Â  Bowers v. South Carolina Dept. of Transp., 360 S.C. 149, 153, 600 S.E.2d 543, 545 (Ct. App. 2004); 18 S.C. Jur. Release Â§ 2 (2003) (â€œBecause a release is a contract, principles of law applicable to contracts generally are also applicable to releases.â€).Â  â€œA contract of adhesion is generally thought of as a standard form contract offered on a take-it-or-leave-it basis.Â  The terms of the contract of adhesion are not negotiable.Â  An offeree faced with such a contract has two choices: complete adherence or outright rejection.â€Â  Lackey v. Green Tree Financial Corp., 330 S.C. 388, 394, 498 S.E.2d 898, 901 (Ct. App. 1998)(internal quotations omitted). 
The fact that a contract is one of adhesion does not make it unconscionable.Â  Id.Â  Determining whether a contract is one of adhesion is merely the beginning point in the analysis. Â Unconscionability, on the other hand, requires a greater showing.Â  Id. at 395, 498 S.E.2d at 901.Â  Unconscionability is characterized by the â€œabsence of meaningful choice on the part of one party due to one-sided contract provisions, together with terms which are so oppressive that no reasonable person would make them and no fair and honest person would accept them.â€Â  Fanning v. Fritzâ€™s Pontiac-Cadillac-Buick Inc., 322 S.C. 399, 403, 472 S.E.2d 242, 245 (1996).
There is no evidence in the record that this was a contract of adhesion.Â  There is no evidence the terms of the release were not negotiable; in fact, the release itself indicated the key term of the release, the consideration to be paid to Todd, was negotiated and he had the right to reject the amount offered.
Moreover, even if this release could be construed as a contract of adhesion, there is no evidence to conclude the release was unconscionable.Â  Toddâ€™s Â unsubstantiated allegations that the release was unconscionable because he was unrepresented when he signed the release, because he was using prescription drugs at the time he signed the release, and Â because he failed to understand the terms of the release are insufficient to create a genuine issue of material fact.Â  See Shupe v. Settle, 315 S.C. 510, 516, 445 S.E.2d 529, 534 (Ct. App. 1994) (â€œA conclusory statement as to the ultimate issue in a case is not sufficient to create a genuine issue of fact for purposes of resisting summary judgment.â€).Â  Todd did not present any evidence to the circuit court that he was impaired or incapacitated as a result of his prescription drug use at the time he signed the release, or that Brereton knew of his use of Oxycontin and that he took advantage of Toddâ€™s alleged impairment.Â  Additionally, Todd failed to present any evidence to support his allegation that he did not understand the terms of the release when he signed it.Â  Lastly, Todd presented no authority, either to the circuit court or in his brief, that the release should be set aside because he was unrepresented when he signed the document.Â Â Â  
CONCLUSION
Accordingly, the order of the circuit court granting summary judgment in favor of Brereton is hereby
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., and BEATTY and SHORT, JJ., concur

[1] The procedural posture of this case is a bit unusual.Â  First, rather than bringing an action to set aside the release, Todd filed an action as if the release did not exist.Â  Second, after Brereton answered and pled the release as an affirmative defense, Todd did not file a reply with the court alleging the release was unenforceable.Â  While this arguably could have prevented Todd from asserting the invalidity of the release, Brereton never raised this issue to the circuit court at the summary judgment hearing.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        Delores Holmes, Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Samuel Holmes, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Berkeley County
Â Berry L. Mobley, Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-003
Submitted December 1, 2006 â€“ Filed January 10, 2007

AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART, AND REMANDED 


  
    
      
        Donald Bruce Clark and Marvin I. Oberman, both of Charleston, for Appellant.
        William J. Clifford, of Charleston, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  In this divorce action, Samuel Holmes (Husband) appealsÂ  from a family court order denying him a divorce to Delores Holmes (Wife), and requiring him to pay Wife permanent periodic alimony and attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  We affirm in part, reverse in part, and remand.[1]
FACTS
Husband and Wife married on September 20, 1990, in Charleston, South Carolina.Â  No children were born of their marriage.Â  Both Husband and Wife have a high school education.Â  Husband is employed as an Intelligence Specialist, with a rank of E-6 in the United States Navy.Â  Wife has a work history in retail and customer services.Â  At the time of the commencement of this action, Husband had a gross monthly income of $6707.39, while Wife was unemployed.Â  The highest wage Wife has earned was eight dollars ($8.00) per hour.Â  In 1991, Husband and Wife relocated from South Carolina to Mayport, Florida, due to Husbandâ€™s military duties.Â  Between 1993 and 1996, they moved to London, England, and then returned to the United States to settle in Virginia.Â  In 1998, Husband and Wife moved to Jacksonville, Florida, where they purchased their first marital home.Â  At the time of this action, Husband owned three automobiles including a 1998 Chevy Malibu, a 1976 Lincoln, and a BMW. 
In 2000, Husband had a child from an extra-marital affair.Â  In January of 2001, Wife separated from Husband due to his adulterous misconduct.Â  On November 26, 2001, Wife instituted this action against Husband in family court, seeking: (1) a divorce on the basis of Husbandâ€™s adultery and one-year separation; (2) alimony and/or spousal support; (3) a restraining order against Husband; (4) equitable distribution of marital property and debts; and (5) Husbandâ€™s payment of her attorneyâ€™s fees and costs.Â  Husband filed a counterclaim, also seeking divorce on the basis of Wifeâ€™s adultery or one-year separation.Â  Wife denied Husbandâ€™s allegations of adultery.
Wife moved for temporary relief on January 9, 2002; and on April 17, 2002, the family court issued a temporary decree, ordering Husband to pay Wife one-third of his basic allowance for housing, which amounted to $213.70.Â  The family court further ordered that Husband â€œtake all steps necessaryâ€ to ensure that Wife receives all benefits to which she is entitled as the spouse of a member of the military, including medical coverage.Â  Husband did not obey the family courtâ€™s order; therefore, on June 28, 2002, the family court issued an order and rule to show cause why Husband should not be held in contempt of court for his disobedience.Â  
On October 25, 2002, the family court ordered a continuance of the hearing on the rule to show cause because Wifeâ€™s counsel was unable to serve Husband due to his military obligations out of the area.Â  The family court ordered that the hearing be reset for December 17, 2002.Â  Meanwhile, in 2003, while Husband and Wife remained married, Husband had a second child from an extra-marital affair.Â  
On June 23, 2004, Wife filed a motion to compel Husband to fully answer her request to admit, interrogatories, and request to produce.Â  Two months later, Wife filed a notice of motion for discovery sanctions against Husband for failing to respond to the interrogatories and for attorneyâ€™s fees and costs.Â  On July 30, 2004, the family court ordered Husband to fully respond to Wifeâ€™s discovery requests within thirty days of July 15, 2004.Â  Husband again failed to obey the family courtâ€™s order, and on August 31, 2004, the family court issued Husband a second order and rule to show cause why Husband should not be held in contempt for his disobedience.
The family court issued an order to continue the hearing for October 12, 2004, due to a conflict in the Husbandâ€™s counselâ€™s schedule.Â  The family court again issued an order for continuance for November 15, 2004.Â  Because Husbandâ€™s counsel sought to be relieved as counsel, and Husband was out of the country, the family court, for a fourth time, issued an order for continuance until the next term of court.Â  The family court next issued an order relieving Husbandâ€™s counsel based on Husbandâ€™s failure to cooperate with his attorney.Â  
The final hearing was held on March 23, 2005.Â  On May 3, 2005, the family court entered its final order and denied both Husband and Wife the divorce in order that Wife may retain her military medical benefits.Â  The family court awarded Wife: (1) $900 per month in permanent periodic alimony; (2) the 1998 Chevrolet Malibu automobile or its NADA value; (3) one half of the equity in the marital home, determined as $11,250; and (4) attorneyâ€™s fees in the amount of $4420.17.Â  This appeal followed.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In appeals from the family court, the appellate court has the authority to find the facts in accordance with its view of the preponderance of the evidence.Â  Ex parte Morris, 367 S.C. 56, 61, 624 S.E.2d 649, 652 (2006).Â  However, because the family court is in a superior position to judge the witnessesâ€™ demeanor and veracity, its findings should be given broad discretion.Â  Scott v. Scott, 354 S.C. 118, 124, 579 S.E.2d 620, 623 (2003).
In the area of the award of alimony, the appellate courtâ€™s inquiry on appeal is not whether the family court gave the same weight to particular factors as the appellate court would have in making the alimony award, but, rather, whether the family court abused its discretion in assigning weight to applicable statutory factors.Â  Allen v. Allen, 347 S.C. 177, 186, 554 S.E.2d 421, 425 (Ct. App. 2001).
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.  Divorce
Husband contends the family court erred in failing to grant him a divorce because both he and Wife requested a divorce in their pleadings and the evidence established grounds for granting Husband a divorce.Â  We remand this issue to the family court for a consideration of the appropriate factors in determining whether a divorce should have been granted to Husband.Â  Section 20-3-10 of the South Carolina Code (1976) provides that divorce shall be granted upon one or more of the following grounds: (1) adultery; (2) desertion for a period of one year; (3) physical cruelty; (4) habitual drunkenness; or (5) on the application of either party if and when Husband and Wife have lived separate and apart without cohabitation for a period of one year.Â  
In his pleadings, Husband requested a divorce from Wife on the ground of one yearâ€™s continuous separation and adultery.Â  Although Wife withdrew her request for a divorce at trial, Husband made it clear that he desired a divorce.Â  Moreover, the evidence is clear that the parties had lived separate and apart without habitation for more than a year.Â  We therefore remand to the family court to consider whether Husband should have been granted a divorce on the ground of one yearâ€™s separation.Â  
II.Â Â Alimony
Husband contends the family court erred in awarding Wife permanent periodic alimony because Wife, as a healthy able-bodied woman in the prime of her life with a work history and no legal dependents, is fully capable of supporting herself.Â  We disagree.Â  Based on the length of the marriage, Wifeâ€™s sporadic work history, Wifeâ€™s several relocations with Husband to further his career, and Husbandâ€™s adulterous relationships, the family courtâ€™s award of separate support and maintenance[2] in the amount of nine hundred dollars ($900.00) per month is fully supported by the record before this court.
III.  Attorneyâ€™s Fees
Husband contends the family court erred in awarding Wife attorneyâ€™s fees because Wife is able to pay her own fees, and the award of fees to Wife under the circumstances of this case is not warranted.Â  We disagree.
Attorneyâ€™s fees may be assessed against a party in an action brought in the family court.Â  Section 20-7-420(38) of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2005); Patel v. Patel, 359 S.C. 515, 533, 599 S.E.2d 114, 123 (2004).Â  The decision to award attorneyâ€™s fees in a divorce case is a matter within the sound discretion of the trial court.Â  Hailey v. Hailey, 357 S.C. 18, 31, 590 S.E.2d 495, 502 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  The trial courtâ€™s decision to award attorneyâ€™s fees will not be reversed on appeal absent an abuse of discretion.Â  Green v. Green, 320 S.C. 347, 353, 465 S.E.2d 130, 134 (Ct. App. 1995).Â  
In deciding whether to award attorneyâ€™s fees in a divorce action, the family court should consider: (1) the partiesâ€™ ability to pay their own fee; (2) the beneficial results obtained by counsel; (3) the respective financial conditions of the parties; and (4) the effect of the fee on each partyâ€™s standard of living. Â Browning v. Browning, 366 S.C. 255, 269, 621 S.E.2d 389, 396 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  To determine the amount of an award of attorneysâ€™ fees, the family court should consider: (1) the nature, extent, and difficulty of the services rendered; (2) the time necessarily devoted to the case; (3) counselsâ€™ professional standing; (4) the contingency of compensation; (5) the beneficial results obtained; and (6) and the customary legal fees for similar services.Â  Deidum v. Deidum, 362 S.C. 47, 65, 606 S.E.2d 489, 499 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  
Contrary to Husbandâ€™s contention, the family court considered the factors set forth in Glasscock v. Glasscock, 304 S.C. 158, 161, 403 S.E.2d 313, 315 (1991), to include: (1) the beneficial results obtained by Wife; (2) the partiesâ€™ financial conditions; (3) the time Wifeâ€™s attorney necessarily devoted to the case; (4) the difficulties in bringing this case to closure; (5) customary legal fees for similar services; and (6) the professional standing of Wifeâ€™s attorney.Â  Under these circumstances, we find the family court did not abuse its discretion in awarding Wife attorneyâ€™s fees.
CONCLUSION
We affirm the awards of spousal support and attorneyâ€™s fees to Wife.Â  We remand the issue of whether the family court should have awarded Husband a divorce based on the parties having lived separate and apart for a period of one year. 
AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART, AND REMANDED.
HUFF and WILLIAMS, JJ. and CURETON, A.J., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2] We construe the family courtâ€™s award of support to Wife as an award of spousal support pursuant to S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-3-140 (1976).Â  While Husband complains that Wife did not request separate support and maintenance in her pleadings, she did request spousal support in her complaint.Â

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        Stephen Anvar, M.D., Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Greenville Hospital System, John R. Sanders, M.D., John Rowell, M.D., Tim Sullivan, M.D., Robin Kelley, M.D., Fleming Mattox, M.D.,
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
Â D. Garrison Hill, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-004
Heard December 4, 2006 â€“ Filed January 10, 2007

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        L. Henry McKellar, Christian Stegmaier, and Suzanne C. Boulware, all of Columbia, for Appellant.
        Sally M. Purnell and Matthew P. Utecht, both of Greenville, for Respondents.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  In this civil conspiracy case, Dr. Stephen Anvar appeals the circuit courtâ€™s grant of summary judgment to Greenville Hospital System (individually, â€œHospitalâ€) and its agents and employees, Dr. John R. Sanders, Dr. John Rowell, Dr. Tim Sullivan, Dr. Robin Kelley, and Dr. Fleming Mattox (these physicians and Hospital, collectively, are â€œRespondentsâ€).Â  We affirm. 
FACTS
Because this appeal is from a grant of summary judgment to Respondents, we view the facts, as we must, in the light most favorable to Dr. Anvar.Â  See, e.g., Summer v. Carpenter, 328 S.C. 36, 42, 492 S.E.2d 55, 58 (1997) (â€œIn determining whether any triable issue of fact exists, the evidence and all inferences which can be reasonably drawn therefrom must be viewed in the light most favorable to the non-moving party.â€).
Dr. Anvar practices medicine as a radiologist and a neurointerventionalist.Â  During the time this case arose, he was employed by Greenville Radiology, a private group of radiologists.Â  Although Dr. Anvar was not employed by Hospital, he had privileges to perform radiological procedures at Hospital.Â  He is specially trained to perform a carotid angioplasty/stenting (â€œCASâ€) procedure.Â  
On May 25, 2001, Dr. Sella Littlepage contacted Dr. Anvar and asked him to perform an emergency diagnostic angiogram on a patient at Hospital.[1]Â  Dr. Littlepage had already performed a carotid endarterectomy (â€œCEAâ€) on the patient, and Dr. Anvarâ€™s angiogram thereafter revealed a ninety percent stenosis, or narrowing, of the patientâ€™s carotid artery. Â After reviewing several alternatives, Dr. Littlepage and Dr. Anvar concluded Dr. Anvar should perform a CAS procedure to attempt to remove the blockage and prevent a stroke.Â  
During the stenting procedure, Dr. Anvar remembered a conversation he previously had with his colleague, Dr. Lee Madeline, about the Angioguard, a device made by Cordis, a Johnson & Johnson Company, used to catch clots that break off during a CEA or CAS procedure and prevent them from traveling into the cerebral circulation.Â  Dr. Madeline was a partner of Dr. Anvarâ€™s employed at Greenville Radiology as a neurointerventionalist.Â  Dr. Anvar sent a technician, Ralph Scott, to retrieve the device from an operating room, and Dr. Anvar used it on the patient.Â  The patient was thereafter returned to the surgical recovery area.Â 
Dr. Madeline, Dr. Sullivan, and other physicians were studying the Angioguard as part of a clinical trial program, called the SAPPHIRE[2] Trial, at Hospital.Â  Dr. Sullivan, a vascular surgeon employed by Hospital, was the principal investigator for the SAPPHIRE Trial at Hospital.Â  The Angioguard was labeled at the time of this incident as being suitable for â€œinvestigational use onlyâ€ and was classified as a device of â€œsignificant riskâ€ by the Federal Drug Administration (â€œFDAâ€).Â  As an investigational device, the Angioguard could be used only in a clinical setting as part of a trial, and regulations required a physician to obtain a patientâ€™s informed consent before using it.Â  At the time he used the Angioguard on the patient, Dr. Anvar had not received the patientâ€™s consent, had not seen the device used, and had never been trained to use it.Â  
Dr. Sullivan, upset over the unauthorized use of the Angioguard device, contacted Hospital administration.Â  Dr. Sanders, the vice president of Medical Staff Affairs at Hospital, investigated the incident.Â  Dr. Sanders was concerned because the Angioguard device was to be used only in the investigational study and because there were concerns raised about whether Dr. Anvar knew how to use the device.Â Â Â  
Dr. Sanders notified Dr. Kelley, chairperson of Hospitalâ€™s Institutional Research Committee (â€œIRCâ€), the body charged with administering Hospitalâ€™s clinical trials.Â  Dr. Kelley appointed an IRC subcommittee, chaired by Dr. Mattox, to conduct an inquiry.Â  At the same time, Dr. Sanders asked Dr. Rowell, president of Hospitalâ€™s Medical Staff, to investigate Dr. Anvarâ€™s conduct.Â  Dr. Rowell appointed an Ad Hoc Committee in conjunction with Hospitalâ€™s Medical Executive Committee (â€œMECâ€), of which Dr. Rowell was also president.Â  Hospitalâ€™s IRC Policies and Procedures allow the IRC to report research misconduct to the medical staff, but the IRC has no jurisdiction to suspend a physicianâ€™s ability to practice medicine at Hospital.Â  Hospitalâ€™s Bylaws allow the MEC to conduct â€œpatient care quality and appropriateness reviews.â€Â  
The IRC ultimately decided Dr. Anvarâ€™s participation in research at Hospital should be suspended for five years.Â  In a report dated July 19, 2001, the MEC recommended to Hospitalâ€™s Board of Trustees that Dr. Anvar be placed on probation for twelve months and be given a letter of reprimand.Â  After considering the MECâ€™s recommendation, the Board of Trustees, by letter dated July 24, 2001, placed Dr. Anvar on probation for five years, required him to complete a bioethics course within one year, and issued a letter of reprimand.Â Â Â Â Â  
In May 2003, Dr. Anvar filed a complaint against Respondents, alleging a civil conspiracy and violation of due process.Â  Dr. Anvar asserted his suspension and probation were solely the result of Respondentsâ€™ combined intent to injure him because of a â€œturf battleâ€ at Hospital between radiologists who were not Hospital employees, such as Dr. Anvar, and vascular surgeons who were employed by Hospital, such as Dr. Sullivan, over which medical procedure was going to be performed by which medical specialty.Â  
Respondents answered and later moved for summary judgment.Â  The circuit court initially denied the motion.Â  After Respondents filed a motion to alter or amend the order, the circuit court granted partial summary judgment in favor of Respondents on Dr. Anvarâ€™s civil conspiracy claim.[3]Â  Specifically, the circuit court granted summary judgment because Dr. Anvar (1) alleged a conspiracy between Hospital and its agents and employees acting within the scope of their authority, but Hospital can act only through its agents and employees and a legal entity such as Hospital cannot conspire with itself under South Carolina law; (2) produced no evidence of a combination or agreement among Respondents with the intent to injure him; and (3) produced no evidence of special damages.Â  Dr. Anvar made a motion to alter or amend this order, and the circuit court modified its order to grant summary judgment to Respondents on the claim of civil conspiracy based on the lack of evidence of an agreement among Respondents to injure Dr. Anvar.Â  The circuit court deleted the other two grounds for granting summary judgment.Â  This appeal followed.Â  Â Â Â Â Â 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In reviewing the grant of a motion for summary judgment, an appellate court applies the same standard that governs the trial court under Rule 56(c), SCRCP.Â  Ferguson v. Charleston Lincoln Mercury, Inc., 349 S.C. 558, 564 S.E.2d 94 (2002).Â  Summary judgment is appropriate when â€œthe pleadings, depositions, answers to interrogatories, and admissions on file, together with the affidavits, if any, show that there is no genuine issue as to any material fact and that the moving party is entitled to a judgment as a matter of law.â€Â  Rule 56(c), SCRCP; see also Standard Fire Ins. Co. v. Marine Contracting & Towing Co., 301 S.C. 418, 421, 392 S.E.2d 460, 462 (1990).Â  In determining whether any triable issues of fact exist, the evidence and all reasonable inferences therefrom must be viewed in the light most favorable to the party opposing summary judgment.Â  Summer v. Carpenter, 328 S.C. 36, 492 S.E.2d 55 (1997).
LAW/ANALYSIS
Dr. Anvar argues the circuit court erred in granting summary judgment to Respondents on his claim for civil conspiracy.Â  We disagree.
A civil conspiracy is a combination of two or more parties joined for the purpose of injuring the plaintiff, thereby causing the plaintiff special damages.Â  Angus v. Burroughs & Chapin Co., 368 S.C. 167, 170, 628 S.E.2d 261, 262 (2006).Â  In order to establish a civil conspiracy, the record must contain evidence, either direct or circumstantial, of the joint assent of two or more persons for the purpose of injuring the plaintiff.Â  Cowburn v. Leventis, 366 S.C. 20, 49, 619 S.E.2d 437, 453 (Ct. App. 2005); First Union Natâ€™l Bank v. Soden, 333 S.C. 554, 575, 511 S.E.2d 372, 383 (Ct. App. 1998).
Dr. Anvarâ€™s civil conspiracy claim is based on his allegation that a competition existed between vascular surgeons who were employed by Hospital and radiologists who were not employed by Hospital over which specialty would perform certain procedures.Â  On appeal, Respondents contend the trial court did not err in granting summary judgment on the ground that Dr. Anvar had presented no evidence of an agreement among Respondents to injure him.Â  All the evidence shows, Respondents contend, is that Dr. Anvar was properly disciplined for using a medical device that was clearly marked for investigational use only and that this discipline applied only to his participation in clinical trials, not to his work as a radiologist at Hospital.Â  Respondents further argue, as an additional sustaining ground, that the circuit courtâ€™s decision granting summary judgment should be affirmed because Dr. Anvar alleges a civil conspiracy between a corporation and its agents and employees all acting in the scope of their authority, and as a matter of law an entity cannot conspire with itself.
We address only the latter contention.
An appellate court may review a respondentâ€™s additional reasons to affirm the judgment and, if convinced it is proper and fair to do so, rely on them or any other reason appearing in the record to affirm the lower courtâ€™s judgment.Â  Iâ€™On, L.L.C. v. Town of Mt. Pleasant, 338 S.C. 406, 420, 526 S.E.2d 716, 723 (2000); see also Rule 220(c), SCACR (â€œThe appellate court may affirm any ruling, order, or judgment upon any ground(s) appearing in the Record on Appeal.â€).
In a case involving a physicianâ€™s (an anesthesiologistâ€™s) allegation of civil conspiracy against Oconee Memorial Hospital and a competing anesthesiology group, our supreme court recently stated that â€œa civil conspiracy cannot exist when the alleged acts arise in the context of a principal-agent relationship because by virtue of the relationship such acts do not involve separate entities.â€Â  McMillan v. Oconee Memâ€™l Hosp., 367 S.C. 559, 564, 626 S.E.2d 884, 886-87 (2006).Â  The court in McMillan noted that it had previously â€œheld that agents for a corporation acting in the scope of their duties cannot conspire with the corporation absent the guilty knowledge of a third party.â€Â  Id. at 564, 626 S.E.2d at 887 (citing Goble v. Am. Ry. Express Co., 124 S.C. 19, 26-27, 115 S.E. 900, 903 (1923)).Â  The court stated:Â  â€œ[W]e believe that it is well settled that a corporation cannot conspire with itself.â€Â  Id.Â  
As is explained in American Jurisprudence, where agents and employees are acting in the course and scope of their authority for the benefit of the corporation and not for their own personal gain, it is not legally possible for there to be a civil conspiracy with the corporation:

  Since a corporate entity cannot conspire with itself a civil conspiracy is not legally possible where a corporation and its alleged coconspirators are not separate entities, but, rather, stand in either a principal-agent or employer-employee relationship with the corporation.Â  Thus, a corporation cannot conspire with its agent when the agent is acting within the scope of his or her authority and a corporation cannot be a party to a conspiracy consisting of the corporation and the persons engaged in the management, direction, and control of the corporate affairs, where the individuals are acting only for the corporation and not for any personal purpose of their own.

16 Am. Jur. 2d Conspiracy Â§ 56 (1998) (footnotes omitted), cited with approval in McMillan v. Oconee Memâ€™l Hosp., 367 S.C. 559, 626 S.E.2d 884Â  (2006).
In the case now before us, Dr. Anvar challenges Hospitalâ€™s decision to suspend him and place him on probation.Â  To support his position, Dr. Anvar challenges the actions of Respondents performed while acting within the scope of their authority at Hospital.Â  Hospital is a public corporation.Â  At the time this action arose, Respondents were all agents or employees of Hospital.Â  Dr. Sanders was vice president of Medical Staff Affairs; Dr. Rowell was an orthopedic surgeon and president of MEC at Hospital; Dr. Sullivan was a vascular surgeon and the principal investigator for the SAPPHIRE Trial; Dr. Kelley was a pediatric infectious disease specialist and president of the IRC at Hospital; and Dr. Mattox was a urogynecologist and a member of a subcommittee of the IRC at Hospital.Â Â Â  
There is no evidence in the record that the physicians in this case acted in any manner other than in their capacities as agents and employees for Hospital or that they acted other than on behalf of the corporation.Â  Although Dr. Anvar summarily alleges that Respondents generally received a benefit by means of more business, there is no evidence to support this assertion or to demonstrate that either Hospital or the physician Respondents received any personal benefit from Dr. Anvarâ€™s disciplinary matter.Â  
A corporation can act only through its directors, officers, agents, and employees.Â  Thus, because the actions of Hospitalâ€™s agents and employees were all performed while acting within the course and scope of their authority, Dr. Anvarâ€™s claim is barred by the intracorporate conspiracy doctrine.Â  See McMillan, 367 S.C. at 564-65, 626 S.E.2d at 886-87 (holding a civil conspiracy cannot exist in the context of a principal-agent relationship where the individuals are all acting only for the corporation and not for any personal purpose of their own); see also Cameron v. Church, 253 F. Supp. 2d 611, 623 (S.D.N.Y. 2003) (stating â€œ[t]he intracorporate conspiracy doctrine provides that the officers, agents and employees of a single corporate or municipal entity, each acting within the scope of his or her employment, legally are incapable of conspiring togetherâ€ and holding the plaintiffâ€™s claim of a civil conspiracy was barred by the intracorporate conspiracy doctrine where the individual defendants were all acting within the scope of their employment for the County of Westchester and thus no actionable conspiracy existed as a matter of law); Perk v. Vector Res. Group, Ltd., 485 S.E.2d 140, 144 (Va. 1997) (holding where Perk alleged a principal-agent or an employer-employee relationship existed between the several defendants, the trial court properly sustained a demurrer on Perkâ€™s claim of civil conspiracy because the defendants were not separate entities and â€œan entity cannot conspire with itselfâ€ (cited with approval in McMillan v. Oconee Memâ€™l Hosp., Inc., 367 S.C. 559, 626 S.E.2d 884 (2006)).Â  
Accordingly, the trial courtâ€™s grant of summary judgment to Respondents on Dr. Anvarâ€™s claim of civil conspiracy is, hereby,
AFFIRMED.
GOOLSBY, STILWELL, and SHORT, JJ., concur.

[1]Â  The record variously refers to the patient having an angiogram or an arteriogram.Â  
[2]Â  SAPPHIRE is an acronym for Stenting and Angioplasty with Protection in Patients at High Risk for Endarterectomy.Â  
[3]Â Â  The circuit court denied the motion for summary judgment as to the due process claim.Â

v.

  
    
      
        Ryan Brooks, Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County
Â Reginald I. Lloyd, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No.Â  2007-UP-006
Submitted January 1, 2007 â€“ Filed January 11, 2007

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Harold M. Coombs; and Solicitor Warren Blair Giese, all of Columbia, for Appellant.
        JoshuaÂ  Kendrick, of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  The State appeals the circuit courtâ€™s order allowing Ryan Brooks to withdraw his guilty plea.Â  We affirm.[1] 
FACTS
On February 11, 2005, Brooks pled guilty to voluntary manslaughter.Â  The circuit court imposed the maximum sentence of thirty years imprisonment.Â  Brooks timely moved the circuit court to reconsider the sentence.Â  More than ten days after the imposition of the sentence, the motion to reconsider the sentence was heard.Â  Brooks requested a reduction in sentence or alternatively to withdraw his guilty plea.Â  On October 17, 2005, the circuit court denied Brooksâ€™ motion to reduce his sentence, but granted his motion to withdraw his guilty plea.Â  The State did not object to the courtâ€™s consideration of Brooksâ€™ motion to withdraw his guilty plea. Â The State appeals. 
LAW/ANALYSIS
On appeal, because the motion to reconsider Brooksâ€™ sentence did not expressly include a request to withdraw the guilty plea, the State argues the circuit court lacked subject matter jurisdiction to hear Brooksâ€™ motion to withdraw his guilty plea.Â  We disagree. 
Rule 29 of the South Carolina Rules of Criminal Procedure provides: â€œExcept for motions for new trials based on after-discovered evidence, post trial motions shall be made within ten (10) days after the imposition of the sentence.â€Â  While it is true that the circuit court loses jurisdiction over the case if no post trial motion is made within ten days after the imposition of the sentence, Town of Hilton Head Island v. Godwin, 370 S.C. 221, 225, 634 S.E.2d 59, 61 (Ct. App. 2006), the circuit court retains jurisdiction over the case if a post trial motion is made within ten days after the imposition of the sentence.Â  When a post trial motion is timely made, the circuit court maintains subject matter jurisdiction over the case.Â  Pierce v. State, 338 S.C. 139, 150, 526 S.E.2d 222, 227 (2000) (â€œSubject matter jurisdiction is the power of a court to hear and determine cases of the general class to which the proceedings in question belong.â€); State v. Crocker, 366 S.C. 394, 401-02, 621 S.E.2d 890, 894 (Ct. App. 2005) (â€œThe circuit court has original jurisdiction in all criminal matters except those where an inferior court is given exclusive jurisdiction.â€) (citing State v. Dudley, 364 S.C. 578, 582, 614 S.E.2d 623, 625 (2005)).
Here, Brooks timely filed his motion to reconsider the sentence and, as result, the circuit court retained jurisdiction over the case.Â  Assuming the withdrawal of the guilty plea was not encompassed in the general motion to reconsider the sentence, the State did not object in the circuit court to consideration of the request to withdraw the guilty plea.Â  We do not view the circuit courtâ€™s consideration of the motion to withdraw the guilty plea as a matter of subject matter jurisdiction.Â  Because a motion to reconsider the sentence was timely filed, the circuit court had jurisdiction to consider the request to withdraw the guilty plea.
A motion to withdraw a guilty plea is committed to the sound discretion of the trial judge.Â  State v. Lambert, 266 S.C. 574, 580, 225 S.E.2d 340, 342-43 (1976).Â  There is no assignment of error in this regard. 
AFFIRMED. 
HEARN, C.J., KITTREDGE and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1]Â  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        The State, Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Jonah Israel Lowder, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Spartanburg County
Â J. Derham Cole, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-007
Submitted January 1, 2007 â€“ Filed January 11, 2007

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Chief Attorney Joseph L. Savitz III, Office of Appellate Defense, of Columbia, for Appellant.
        Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Donald J. Zelenka, Senior Assistant Attorney General William Edgar Salter, III, all of Columbia; and Solicitor Harold W. Gowdy, III, of Spartanburg, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: Â Jonah Israel Lowder was convicted of murder and sentenced to life in prison.Â  Lowder appeals, arguing the trial court erred by allowing the State to (1) introduce evidence that he had invoked his right to counsel during custodial interrogation, (2) cross-examine him about his invocation of the right to counsel, and (3) argue in closing that his invocation of the right to counsel was proof of his guilt.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS/ANALYSIS
Lowder was convicted of murder for the death of Robert Allen Arthur, who died in Spartanburg County when his skull was crushed by a cement block on or about August 6, 2002.Â  Lowder, then 23, and Arthur, who was in his 50s, were both homeless and transient, and had just met that day.Â  The two had spent the afternoon drinking together near a truck stop; thereafter, Â Arthur had invited Lowder to his campsite nearby to rest for the night.Â  
At trial, Lowder admitted that he had killed Arthur with a cement block.Â  He claimed, however, that he did it because Arthur first attacked him with the same cement block during an attempted homosexual advance while he was sleeping.Â  Lowder testified that he had awakened in the night to find Arthur, with his pants pulled down, leaning over him with the cement block.Â  Lowder stated he had grabbed the cement block and beaten Arthur with it only to defend himself.Â  Lowder acknowledged at trial that he never alleged during his police interrogations that Arthur had attempted to sexually assault him, but maintained it was because he did not want that information to be published in the newspapers.Â  During the investigation of this case, police investigators had spoken to Lowder on at least three occasions.Â Â Â  Â 
During direct examination, the solicitor questioned one of the investigators involved in Lowderâ€™s case, Officer Jeremy Mathis of the Bay County Sheriffâ€™s Office in Panama City, Florida.Â  Lowder was tracked by South Carolina authorities to a jail in Bay County during the course of the investigation into Arthurâ€™s death.Â  The solicitor inquired whether Lowder had said anything when they were taking his palm prints.Â  The investigator replied:

  He was very inquisitive as to why we needed his palm prints.Â  He wanted to know what they were being used for.Â  And I think it is important to note that the only involvement I had ever had with Mr. Lowder at the time was for, to assist Spartanburg in their investigation.Â  I had never been a part of any other case that involved him.Â  Since I knew that he had asked for a lawyer, of course --Â  Â Â 

Defense counsel moved for a mistrial on the basis the officer â€œmade a[n] impermissible reference to Mr. Lowderâ€™s right to counsel.â€Â  The trial court denied the motion.Â  The court noted that the State was at a disadvantage because Lowder had previously moved to suppress his statements as involuntary at the start of the trial and it was the Stateâ€™s burden to prove to the jury that the statements were freely and voluntarily made.Â  Defense counsel then stated he was not going to challenge before the jury the voluntariness of the statements.Â Â Â  
After further discussion, the trial court stated:Â  

  All heâ€™s testified to at the present time is the fact that he knew that Mr. Lowder had requested a lawyer and so he wasnâ€™t going to talk to him.Â  And I certainly donâ€™t think thatâ€™s a comment upon his invocation of his right to remain silent.Â  Thatâ€™s just an explanation as to why he refused to carry on a conversation with him . . . that he knew he had requested a lawyer and so he wasnâ€™t going to talk to him.Â  
  The issue now is going to simply be how to handle that since youâ€™re not challenging the voluntariness.
  I guess the witness can simply testify that Mr. Lowder initiated a conversation with the witness wherein he stated he wanted to talk to the police about the case . . . .Â  

The general rule in South Carolina is that a mistrial should be granted â€œin cases of manifest necessity and with the greatest caution for very plain and obvious reasons.â€Â  State v. Patterson, 337 S.C. 215, 227, 522 S.E.2d 845, 851 (Ct. App. 1999); see also State v. Kirby, 269 S.C. 25, 28-29, 236 S.E.2d 33, 34 (1977) (â€œThe power of a court to declare a mistrial ought to be used with the greatest caution under urgent circumstances, and for very plain and obvious causes.â€).Â  
â€œAmong the factors to be considered in ordering a mistrial are the character of the testimony, the circumstances under which it was offered, the nature of the case, and the other testimony in the case.â€Â  State v. Howard, 296 S.C. 481, 483, 374 S.E.2d 284, 285 (1988).Â  â€œA trial judgeâ€™s decision to grant or deny a mistrial will not be reversed on appeal absent an abuse of discretion amounting to an error of law.â€Â  State v. Rowlands, 343 S.C. 454, 458, 539 S.E.2d 717, 719 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  
In this case, we agree with the trial courtâ€™s reasoning that a mistrial was not warranted as the witness did not make an impermissible comment on Lowderâ€™s right to remain silent.Â  Rather, as the trial court noted, it was simply an explanation regarding why the detective did not pursue further questioning with Lowder at that time.Â  
Moreover, Lowder subsequently waived his right to counsel and spoke with the officers during their investigation.Â  The background given by the witness was to explain how Lowderâ€™s later statements came about.Â  As the court pointed out, Lowder had initially moved at the start of the trial to suppress his statements as involuntary, but later chose not to challenge their voluntariness at trial.Â  We discern, then, no prejudice from the witnessâ€™s brief comment about Lowderâ€™s request for a lawyer.Â  Accordingly, we find no abuse of discretion in the trial courtâ€™s denial of Lowderâ€™s motion for a mistrial.Â  
As to Lowderâ€™s two remaining issues regarding the extent of cross-examination[2] and closing argument,[3] no objections were made to these matters at trial.Â  Since the alleged errors were not raised to and ruled upon by the trial court, they are not properly before us for review.Â  See State v. Dunbar, 356 S.C. 138, 142, 587 S.E.2d 691, 693-94 (2003) (â€œIn order for an issue to be preserved for appellate review, it must have been raised to and ruled upon by the trial judge.Â  Issues not raised and ruled upon in the trial court will not be considered on appeal.â€); State v. Torrence, 305 S.C. 45, 406 S.E.2d 315 (1991) (observing a contemporaneous objection is required to properly preserve alleged errors for review on direct appeal); State v. Rice, 348 S.C. 417, 559 S.E.2d 360 (Ct. App. 2001) (stating as a general rule that all errors not involving subject matter jurisdiction must be raised and ruled on at trial to be preserved for further review and may not be raised for the first time on appeal).
Based on the foregoing, the judgment below is
AFFIRMED.
GOOLSBY, STILWELL, and SHORT, JJ., concur.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 

[1]Â  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2]Â  This cross-examination concerned Lowderâ€™s failure to allege, during his several statements to the police, that the victim had attempted to sexually assault him.Â  No objections were made to this questioning at trial, so no issue is preserved in this regard.
[3]Â  Lowder argues the solicitor â€œexploitedâ€ during closing argument the evidence of his exercising his right to counsel, but no contemporaneous objection was made in this regard so as to preserve the issue for appeal.Â

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        Estate of Laura J. Mims and Shelia Hood, Respondents,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Alta Ruth Robinson, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
Â Thomas L. Hughston, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No.Â  2007-UP-008
Submitted January 1, 2007 â€“ Filed January 11, 2007

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Eduardo Kelvin Curry, of Charleston, for Appellant.
        Sherry Bingley Crummey, Â for Respondents.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  This appeal arises from a formal testacy proceeding to invalidate a will.Â  The circuit court affirmed an order of the probate court declaring the will at issue to be null and void.Â  Alta Ruth Robinson, the proponent of the will, appeals to this court.Â  We affirm.[1] 
FACTS AND PROCEDURAL HISTORY
The decedent, Laura J. Mims, died on January 23, 2003.Â  On or about January 27, 2003, respondent Shelia Hood presented to the Charleston County Probate Court a will dated March 2, 1999, naming Hood as the personal representative of Mimsâ€™s estate as well as a devisee.Â  Shortly thereafter, on or about February 4, 2003, Robinson presented to the probate court a will dated January 22, 2000.Â  The second will named Robinson as the personal representative of Mimsâ€™s estate and as the principal beneficiary.
Hood filed this action on July 30, 2003, after the probate court decided to probate the will Robinson had presented instead of the 1999 will.Â  Hoodâ€™s complaint alleged (1) execution of the 2000 will was procured by fraud; (2) Mims never signed the instrument; (3) the will was not properly witnessed; and (4) the notarization was forged.Â  Hood requested revocation of the probate of the 2000 will, admission of the 1999 will to probate in solemn form, and an order that Robinson refrain from exercising any power of administration except as necessary to preserve the estate or as otherwise directed by the court.Â Â Â  
A hearing in the matter took place on February 19, 2004.Â  On July 9, 2004, the probate judge signed an order invalidating the 2000 will for several reasons including (1) concern that Mims did not know the content of the 2000 will; (2) â€œquestionable circumstancesâ€ regarding the notaryâ€™s signature; (3) disagreement between Robinsonâ€™s witnesses regarding the individuals present at the signing of the will; (4) an apparent misspelling of Mimsâ€™s name in the first signature line of the will; (5) a discrepancy between the name of a witness who signed the will and the corresponding name typed on the document; and (6) the fact that the will was allegedly signed at Mimsâ€™s home on a Saturday.Â  In conclusion, the probate court held the authenticity of the entire January 22, 2000 will was suspect based on â€œ[t]he combination of . . . errors in this one document without any credible explanations offered by the proponents of the will.â€
Robinson appealed to the circuit court, which heard arguments of counsel on December 13, 2004.Â  By written order dated April 26, 2005, the circuit court affirmed the probate courtâ€™s decision.Â  On May 9, 2005, Robinson moved under Rule 59(e), SCRCP, to alter or amend the circuit courtâ€™s order.Â  Following the denial of this motion, Robinson filed this appeal.
DISCUSSION
1.Â  We disagree with Robinsonâ€™s assertions of error in the findings by the probate court and the circuit court that Mims did not know the contents of the 2000 will.
Generally, will contests are actions at law.[2]Â  In such cases, both this court and the circuit court, when sitting as an appellate court in the matter, will uphold the findings by the probate court if they are supported by any evidence.[3]Â  
We agree with the circuit courtâ€™s determination that the record contains evidence that supports the probate courtâ€™s determination that Mims did not know the contents of the 2000 will when she signed it.Â  Charles Drayton, a non-lawyer and funeral home employee who claimed to have drafted the instrument, testified Mims instructed him she wished to have her estate â€œdivided among her niece [i.e. Robinson] and nephewsâ€; however, the will on its face designates Robinson as the sole beneficiary, with the nephews taking in succession only if the others failed to survive.Â  Moreover, it appears from Draytonâ€™s testimony that he did not read the will to Mims and, although Mims allegedly took ten minutes to sign it, Drayton was unable to verify that he saw her reading the document.Â  Drayton then acknowledged that he took the original will with him, and there is no evidence suggesting he gave a copy to Mims or anyone else.
2.Â  As to Robinsonâ€™s assertions of error regarding the determinations that the notaryâ€™s testimony was unclear as to whether she in fact had notarized the 2000 will, we find no reversible error.Â  Although, as Robinson points out in her brief, defects in notarization are not necessarily fatal to the proper execution of a will, the will in this case was invalidated because of indications that the decedent did not know its contents.
3.Â  Finally, we disagree with Robinsonâ€™s argument that the probate court improperly shifted the burden of proof to her.Â  In support of her position, Robinson suggests that, because Mims allegedly executed the will in question more than three years before she died, she had the opportunity to revoke or change it.Â  There is no evidence, however, that Mims was provided a copy of the 2000 will or was otherwise alerted to the discrepancy between her instructions to Drayton regarding the disposition of her estate and the actual provisions in the will.Â  Moreover, Drayton, even though he never testified that he was an attorney or had expertise in drafting wills, had assumed the role of a legal professional.[4]Â  Absent evidence to the contrary, it was reasonable for Mims to assume he had drafted the will according to her specifications.[5]
AFFIRMED.
GOOLSBY, STILWELL, and SHORT, JJ., concur.

[1]Â  Because oral argument would not aid the court in resolving the issues on appeal, we decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.Â  We further note that, although under Rule 208(4), SCACR, this court â€œmay take such action as it deems properâ€ because Respondents have not filed a brief in this appeal, we have not found any error that would warrant reversing the decision of the circuit court. 
[2]Â  Estate of Cumbee v. Cumbee, 333 S.C. 664, 670, 511 S.E.2d 390, 393 (Ct. App. 1999).
[3]Â  See Estate of Weeks v. Drawdy, 329 S.C. 251, 261, 495 S.E.2d 454, 460 (Ct. App. 1997) (stating the circuit court, when sitting as an appellate court, and the court of appeals use the same standard of review and both should uphold a finding by the probate court in a law case if it is supported by any evidence in the record).
[4]Â  See State v. Buyers Serv. Co., 292 S.C. 426, 431, 357 S.E.2d 15, 18 (1987) (â€œThe reason preparation of instruments by lay persons must be held to constitute the unauthorized practice of law is . . . for the protection of the public from the potentially severe economic and emotional consequences which may flow from erroneous advice given by persons untrained in the law.â€); In re Duncan, 83 S.C. 186, 189, 69 S.E. 210, 211 (1909) (holding the practice of law includes â€œthe preparation of legal instructions of all kindsâ€).
[5]Â  Cf. True v. Monteith, 327 S.C. 116, 120, 489 S.E.2d 615, 617 (1997) (â€œ[A]bsent other facts, the client should be able to rely on the attorneyâ€™s advice and should be able to follow this advice without fear the attorney is not acting in the clientâ€™s best interest.â€).

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        The State, Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Charles LeRoy Dean, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Georgetown County
Â Paula H. Thomas, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-009
Submitted December 1, 2006 â€“ Filed January 11, 2007

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Assistant Appellate Defender Aileen P. Clare, Office of Appellate Defense, of Columbia, for Appellant,
        Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Special Assistant Attorney General Amie L. Clifford, all of Columbia; and Solicitor John Gregory Hembree, of Conway, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Charles Leroy Dean appeals his convictions for two counts of criminal sexual conduct with a minor in the second degree and a single count of disseminating obscene materials to a minor.Â  He argues the trial court erred in admitting evidence of uncharged acts and in denying his motion to sequester witnesses.Â  We affirm.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
FACTS
Charles Leroy Dean was employed at the Tara Hall Home for Boys[1] (the Home) as a child care worker from July of 1997 until his suspension in January of 2000.Â  During his time at the Home, Dean shared living quarters with the boys he supervised.Â  Dean had direct supervision over seven boys who ranged from nine to fifteen years of age. 
On January 28, 2000, a thirteen-year-old boy (Doe) informed the Home that Dean had forced him into receiving oral sex.Â  Doe stated the incident had occurred two days prior to his telling the Home.Â  The Home alerted the Georgetown County Sheriffâ€™s Department (the Police) and the South Carolina Department of Social Services (DSS) and immediately suspended Dean.Â Â  
Subsequent to the above accusations, the Police spoke with a fifteen-year-old boy (Roe) who had previously been under the supervision of Dean.Â  Roe informed the Police that he and Dean had an ongoing sexual relationship during his time at the Home.Â  Roe testified that he and Dean had engaged in oral and anal sex on many different occasions.Â Â  
Lastly, a fifteen-year-old third boy informed Police that Dean had utilizedÂ his computerÂ toÂ show the boy images of Â nudeÂ men and women having sex.[2]Â  In a statement given to Police and DSS, Dean admitted to showing this boy nude pictures of men and women.Â Â  
A Georgetown County grand jury indicted Dean for two counts of criminal sexual conduct with a minor in the second degree and three counts of disseminating obscene materials to a minor.Â  The State elected to try Dean on only one count of disseminating obscene material to a minor.Â  At trial, the jury convicted Dean on all charges, and the trial court sentenced him to fifteen years imprisonment.[3]Â  This appeal followed.Â Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œIn criminal cases, the appellate court sits to review errors of law only.â€ Â State v. Wilson, 345 S.C. 1, 5, 545 S.E.2d 827, 829 (2001).Â  On appeal, we are limited to determining whether the trial judge abused his discretion.Â  State v. Bowie, 360 S.C. 210, 216, 600 S.E.2d 112, 115 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  â€œAn abuse of discretion occurs when the trial courtâ€™s ruling is based on an error of law.â€Â  State v. Foster, 354 S.C. 614, 621, 582 S.E.2d 426, 429 (2003).Â  This Court does not reassess the facts based on its own view of the preponderance of the evidence but simply determines whether the trial judgeâ€™s ruling is supported by any evidence.Â  Wilson, 345 S.C. at 6, 545 S.E.2d at 829.
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  Admission of Evidence
Dean contends the trial court erred in admitting evidence of â€œuncharged conductâ€ in violation of State v. Lyle[4] and Rules 403 and 404(b), SCRE.Â  We find this argument is not preserved for our review.
Â â€œA ruling in limine is not final; unless an objection is made at the time the evidence is offered and a final ruling procured, the issue is not preserved for review.â€Â  State v. Smith, 337 S.C. 27, 32, 522 S.E.2d 598, 600 (1999).Â  Although Dean moved in limine to exclude any testimony of uncharged conduct, his motion was denied, and he failed to object to the admission of this testimony at the time it was offered.[5]Â  We find this issue is not preserved for our review.
II.Â  Sequestration of the Witnesses
Dean contends the trial court erred in refusing to sequester the witnesses against him.Â  He argues the witnesses should have been sequestered to prevent their collusion in falsely accusing him.Â  We disagree.
The South Carolina Constitution contains a â€œVictimsâ€™ Bill of Rightsâ€ which states in pertinent part:Â  

  To preserve and protect victimsâ€™ rights to justice and due process regardless of race, sex, age, religion, or economic status, victims of crime have the right to:Â  (3) be informed of and present at any criminal proceedings which are dispositive of the charges where the defendant has the right to be present.

S.C. Const. art. I, Â§ 24.Â  Section 16-3-1510 of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2005) includes in its definition of a â€œvictimâ€ the parents of a minor victim.Â  Further, â€œa party is not entitled to have witnesses sequestered as a matter of right,â€ and â€œthe decision to sequester witnesses is left to the sound discretion of the trial judge.â€Â  State v. Tisdale, 338 S.C. 607, 616, 527 S.E.2d 389, 394 (Ct. App. 2000).Â Â  
Although Dean was tried in absentia, he certainly had the right to be present.Â  The trial court found the Victimsâ€™ Bill of Rights granted the victims a right to be present.Â  Based on the above cited law, we find the trial court did not abuse its discretion in denying Deanâ€™s motion to sequester the witnesses.
CONCLUSION
We find Deanâ€™s appeal of the trial courtâ€™s admission of evidence of uncharged conduct is not preserved for our review, and we find no error in the trial courtâ€™s denial of Deanâ€™s motion to sequester the witnesses.Â  Based on the foregoing, Deanâ€™s conviction is
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., BEATTY, and SHORT, JJ., concur.

[1] Tara Hall was described by its director as a home and school for boys who have been abused or neglected or who have emotional and behavioral problems.Â  
[2] Notably, both Doe and Roe had also alleged that Dean had shown them images of nude men and women having sex. 
[3]Â  Dean was tried in absentia.Â  After the verdict was announced, his sentence was sealed by the trial court.Â  Dean was a fugitive for over three years and was not apprehended until March of 2005.Â  At this time, his sentence was unsealed.
[4] State v. Lyle, 125 S.C. 406, 118 S.E. 803 (1923).
[5] Notably, Deanâ€™s counsel not only failed to object to this testimony, but also called further attention to the uncharged conduct by questioning the witnesses on this evidence during cross-examination.Â  In fact, once the trial court denied his motion in limine, Deanâ€™s attorney specifically requested that he be allowed to question Roe about his allegations of anal intercourse with Dean.Â Â Â Â
