THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        Thomas D. Jordan, Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Kelly Co, Inc., Employer/Appellant
      
    
  

&

  
    
      
        Zenith Insurance Company, Carrier/Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Horry County
Â B. Hicks Harwell, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-010
Heard November 6, 2006 â€“ Filed January 11, 2007

REVERSED


  
    
      
        Edwin P. Martin, Jr., of Columbia, for Appellants.
        David James Canty and James L. Hills, both of Myrtle Beach, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: Kelly Co, Inc. and their workersâ€™ compensation carrier Zenith Insurance Company (Appellants) claim the circuit court erred in holding the South Carolina Workersâ€™ Compensation Commissionâ€™s (the Commission)Â  findings were not supported by substantial evidence and therefore reversing the Commissionâ€™s order.Â  We agree.Â  
FACTS
Thomas Jordan (Jordan) was employed as a long haul truck driver by Kelly Co, Inc. (Kelly Co).Â  Kelly Co. is a trucking company which specializes in transporting oversized equipment.Â  Jordan suffered a heart attack on January 11, 2003, during one of his trips for Kelly Co.Â  Jordan claims the heart attack was proximately caused by unexpected strain or over-exertion in the performance of the duties of his employment or by the unusual and extraordinary conditions of this particular trip.Â  
Jordan testified that he was sent to Virginia to pick up a large piece of equipment and haul it to Texas.Â  Jordan claims he was told by the Kelly Co dispatcher that the load had to be in Houston before five oâ€™clock on Friday afternoon and that later this â€œdeadlineâ€ was pushed back to noon on Saturday.Â  It is undisputed that when he arrived in Virginia at the pickup location, the load was not ready to be picked up, and this delayed his departure by seven hours.Â  Due to the size of the equipment, Jordan could only travel with special permits issued by each state he was passing through.Â  These permits controlled the routes and times drivers could haul oversized loads through each state, and hauling an oversized load in a state without a permit would be illegal.Â  Jordan claims that when he started hauling the load in Virginia, he had not yet received the Virginia permit.Â  It is undisputed that when Jordan arrived in Houston, part of the specified route was closed due to construction, and he continued through downtown without an escort.Â  During his travels from Virginia to Texas, Jordan started to experience symptoms later associated with a heart attack, and he suffered a heart attack after he delivered the load on Saturday.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
Jordan sought workersâ€™ compensation benefits claiming the heart attack was proximately caused by stress from the deadline imposed for delivery, having to drive without a permit, and having to deviate from a specified route in a heavily congested area.Â  Jordanâ€™s claims were heard by the Single Commissioner on June 21, 2004.Â  On October 29, 2004, the Commissioner issued an order finding Jordan had suffered a compensable heart attack, awarding him temporary total compensation beginning on February 3, 2003, and holding the appellants responsible for payment of his past medical expenses and future medical care until he reaches maximum medical improvement.Â  On November 12, 2004, Appellants filed an application for appellate review.
The full commission heard the appeal on February 24, 2005.Â  By order issued on March 23, 2005, the Commission found that despite the difficulties Jordan encountered on the day of heart attack, the heart attack was not compensable because he was performing his regular job duties in the ordinary and normal manner without being subjected to unusual or extraordinary conditions.Â  Therefore, the Commission reversed the single commissionerâ€™s order.Â  Jordan filed an appeal on April 22, 2005.Â  
The circuit court held an appellate hearing on September, 23, 2005.Â  By order issued October 19, 2005, the circuit court reversed the full commission and reinstated the single commissionerâ€™s order.Â  This appeal follows.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
The Administrative Procedures Act establishes the standard of review for decisions by the Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission.Â  S.C.Code Ann.Â Â  Â§1-23-380 (2005); Lark v. Bi-Lo, Inc., 276 S.C. 130, 132, 276 S.E.2d 304, 305 (1981).Â  â€œThe appellate courtâ€™s review is limited to deciding whether the commissionâ€™s decision is unsupported by substantial evidence or is controlled by some error of law.â€Â  Hendricks v. Pickens County, 335 S.C. 405, 411, 517 S.E.2d 698, 701 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  Substantial evidence is â€œnot a mere scintilla of evidence nor the evidence viewed blindly from one side of the case, but is evidence which, considering the record as a whole, would allow reasonable minds to reach the conclusion that the administrative agency reached or must have reached in order to justify its action.â€  Miller by Miller v. State Roofing Co., 312 S.C. 452, 454, 441 S.E.2d 323, 324-25 (1994) (quoting Lark v. Bi-Lo, Inc., 276 S.C. 130, 135, 276 S.E.2d 304, 306 (1981)). 
â€œA judgment upon which reasonable men might differ will not be set aside.â€Â  Toddâ€™s Ice Cream, Inc. v. South Carolina Employment Sec. Commâ€™n, 281 S.C. 254, 258, 315 S.E.2d 373, 375 (Ct. App. 1984).Â  The final determination of witness credibility and the weight to be accorded evidence is reserved to the Commission.Â  Ross v. American Red Cross, 298 S.C. 490, 492, 381 S.E.2d 728, 730 (1989).Â  The reviewing court may not â€œsubstitute its judgment for that of the [Commission] as to the weight of the evidence on questions of fact.â€ S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-380(6) (2005).Â  â€œWhere there is a conflict in the evidence, either of different witnesses or of the same witnesses, the findings of fact of the Commission as triers of fact are conclusive.â€Â Â  Hoxit v. Michelin Tire Corp., 304 S.C. 461, 465, 405 S.E.2d 407, 409 (1991).Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
Appellants claim the circuit court erred in holding the Commissionâ€™s findings were not supported by substantial evidence and therefore reversing the Commissionâ€™s order.Â  We agree.
Heart attacks are compensable as an accident if induced by unexpected strain or over-exertion in the performance of the duties of employment or by unusual and extraordinary conditions in the employment. Â Green v. City of Bennettsville, 197 S.C. 313, 15 S.E.2d 334 (1941). Â This is true even though preexisting conditions may have been a contributing factor. Â Sweatt v. Marlboro Cotton Mills, 206 S.C. 476, 34 S.E.2d 762 (1945). Â However, heart attacks resulting from the ordinary exertion that is required in the performance of the duties of the employment in the ordinary and usual manner, and without any outward untoward event, are not compensable as an accident. Â Rivers v. V. P. Loftis Co., 214 S.C. 162, 51 S.E.2d 510 (1949); Sims v. South Carolina State Commission of Forestry, 235 S.C. 1, 109 S.E.2d 701 (1959).
Given the limited review allowed in cases arising from administrative agencies, the circuit court should have only reversed the full commission if the record lacked substantial evidence to support the commissionâ€™s findings.Â  Therefore, if after considering the record as a whole we find a reasonable mind could have reached the same conclusion as the full commission, we must reverse the circuit court and reinstate the commissionâ€™s order.
Daniel Kelly, Kelly Coâ€™s owner and a truck driver, and Rick Young, a Kelly Co driver, both testified that as there were no â€œdeadlinesâ€ for delivery of oversized loads due to the restrictions imposed in the permitting processes and the unpredictability of circumstances.Â  Kelly also stated that even though he had made a â€œloose commitmentâ€ to deliver the equipment in Texas on Friday, the commitment was void when the shipper failed to have the goods ready for pickup at the specified time.Â  Kelly gave a description of the process Kelly Co used to obtain permits and testified that Jordan had the Virginia permits when he left the pickup location.Â  Furthermore, Jordan testified that occasionally he would start his trips without the required permits and later stop at a truck stop and have the permits faxed to him.Â  Finally, Young testified that deviating from a specified route due to road construction was not unusual.
Given the testimony in the record, a reasonable mind could find the conditions and stress that Jordan experienced on this particular trip were the normal, ordinary conditions of his employment.Â  Therefore, there is substantial evidence in the record to support the Commissionâ€™s finding that Jordanâ€™s heart attack was caused by ordinary exertion that is required in the performance of his employment duties in the ordinary and usual manner, without any outward untoward event, and is not compensable as an accident. See Rivers v. V. P. Loftis Co., 214 S.C. 162, 51 S.E.2d 510 (1949).Â  Accordingly, the order of the circuit court is 
REVERSED. 
GOOLSBY, STILWELL, and SHORT, JJ., concur.

PER CURIAM:Â  Henri A. Glasby was convicted of trafficking cocaine and trafficking crack cocaine.Â  Glasby appeals his convictions arguing the court erred in refusing to suppress evidence. Â 
We affirm[1] pursuant to Rule 220(b)(2), SCACR, and the following authorities:Â  State v. Burton, 356 S.C. 259, 265, 589 S.E.2d 6, 9 (2003) (finding a motion for a directed verdict is limited to the sufficiency of properly admitted evidence, not is admissibility); State v. Owens, 346 S.C. 637, 651, 552 S.E.2d 745, 752-53 (2001), overruled on other grounds, State v. Gentry, 363 S.C. 93, 610 S.E.2d 494 (2005) (finding a ruling in a pre-trial suppression hearing is not final and an objection must be made at the time the evidence is introduced). Â 
AFFIRMED. 
GOOLSBY, STILWELL, and SHORT, JJ., concur.Â 

[1] Â We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        James Alfred Goff, Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Drenetha Dale Goff, Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Horry County
Â H. E. Bonnoitt, Jr., Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-012
Heard December 7, 2006 â€“ Filed January 11, 2007

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Irby E. Walker, Jr., of Conway, for Appellant.
        Joseph F. Singleton, of Conway, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: James Alfred Goff (Husband) appeals from a family court order requiring him to pay $800 per month in permanent periodic alimony and $14,000 in attorneyâ€™s fees to Drenetha Dale Goff (Wife).Â Â  Specifically, Husband contends the trial judge erred in denying his request that the order for alimony be declared null and void because the family court failed to comply with the South Carolina Uniform Veteranâ€™s Act.Â Â  Husband further contends the trial judge erred in awarding Wife attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
Husband, a veteran of the United States Army, married Wife, a high school teacherâ€™s assistant, on December 31, 1975.Â  Before the marriage, on September 24, 1969, Husband was involved in a truck accident, leaving him brain damaged.Â  In January of 1970, the medical board of the Veteranâ€™s Administration (Administration) determined Husband suffered from â€œsevere organic brain syndrome, manifested by a generalized slowing of cerebral function.â€Â  Despite Husbandâ€™s brain damage, the Administration determined Husband had been rated â€œcompetent for VA purposesâ€[1] since October 12, 1970.Â  Husband received monthly disability benefits from the Administration for his inability to work, and his only other source of income was from social security, the combination of which totaled a gross monthly income of $2,600.32.Â  Wife had a gross monthly income of $1,039.60.Â  
On July 16, 1999, Wife brought a divorce action against Husband based upon adultery, seeking inter alia, alimony and payment of her attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  Husband requested a guardian ad litem, and upon the consent of the parties, the trial judge appointed Husbandâ€™s brother, Eddie Goff, as his guardian.Â  
On September 29, 2000, the trial judge issued a final order and divorce decree in favor of Wife on the grounds of Husbandâ€™s adultery.Â  Â Pursuant to an agreement between Husband and Wife,[2] the trial judge ordered Husband to pay Wife $800 per month in permanent periodic alimony, beginning October 1, 2000.Â  
On January 13, 2004, Husband brought an action in family court before the same trial judge, seeking to reduce his alimony payments to Wife.Â  Husband further alleged: (1) his guardian ad litem did not have authority to enter into the alimony agreement on his behalf; and (2) the trial judge did not have subject matter jurisdiction to order his Veteranâ€™s Administration funds to be utilized for the payment of alimony because the family court failed to comply with the Uniform Veteranâ€™s Guardianship Act (the Act).Â  Upon these grounds, Husband requested the alimony provisions of the order be declared void ab initio.Â  
In February of 2004, Husband requested of the Administration that he be rated incompetent and appointed a fiduciary, but the Administration denied his request, again finding him â€œcompetent to handle his VA financial affairsâ€ based on his ability to pass a series of stringent medical tests.Â  The Administration did, however, find him one-hundred percent mentally disabled as a result of his injuries.Â  Yet, due to his level of competency, the Administration never determined it necessary to appoint a guardian for Husband to receive his veteranâ€™s benefits.Â  Â Â 
After a hearing on Husbandâ€™s complaint on September 15, 2004, the trial judge issued a final order, finding the family court had jurisdiction over the subject matter of the action and Husbandâ€™s guardian ad litem was authorized by law to reach decisions in the Husbandâ€™s best interest.Â  The trial judge also denied Husbandâ€™s request for modification of Wifeâ€™s alimony and ordered that Husband pay Wife $14,000 in attorneyâ€™s fees and costs.Â  This appeal followed.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
Subject matter jurisdiction is the power of a court to hear and determine cases of the general class to which the proceedings in question belong.Â  State v. Laney, 367 S.C. 639, 649, 627 S.E.2d 726, 732 (2006); Coon v. Coon, 364 S.C. 563, 566, 614 S.E.2d 616, 617 (2005).Â  Issues related to subject matter jurisdiction may be raised at any time.Â  Laney, 367 S.C. at 649, 627 S.E.2d at 732; see also Tatnall v. Gardner, 350 S.C. 135, 137, 564 S.E.2d 377, 378 (Ct. App. 2002) (â€œThe issue of subject matter jurisdiction may be raised at any time including when raised for the first time on appeal to this Court.â€).
â€œSubject matter jurisdiction is a question of law for the court.â€Â  Murphy v. Owens-Corning Fiberglas Corp., 346 S.C. 37, 43, 550 S.E.2d 589, 592 (Ct. App. 2001), overruled on other grounds by Farmer v. Monsanto Corp., 353 S.C. 553, 579 S.E.2d 325 (2003).Â  Questions of law may be decided with no particular deference to the trial court.Â  Moriarty v. Garden Sanctuary Church of God, 341 S.C. 320, 327, 534 S.E.2d 672, 675 (2000).
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  Alimony
Husband contends the trial judge erred in denying his request that the portion of the final order requiring him to pay alimony to Wife be declared null and void.Â  Husband specifically contends the trial judge erred in failing to find the family court did not have subject matter jurisdiction because it never notified the Administration of the divorce hearing as required by the Act.Â  We disagree and find subject matter jurisdiction is not implicated.
Â  â€œSubject matter jurisdiction is the power of a court to hear and determine cases of the general class to which the proceedings in question belong.â€Â  State v. Gentry, 363 S.C. 93, 100, 610 S.E.2d 494, 498 (2005).Â  The lack of subject matter jurisdiction may not be waived, even if the parties consent to the waiver.Â  Id.Â  By statute, the family court has subject matter jurisdiction to award alimony; therefore, even if the family court failed to comply with the notice requirements of the Act, the failure would not divest the family court of subject matter jurisdiction.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-420 (14).Â  Â Because subject matter jurisdiction is not implicated, any complaint Husband had with regard to the notice requirements of the Act being followed needed to be timely raised to the trial judge in order to be preserved for review.Â  See Lucas v. Rawl Family Ltd. Partnership, 359 S.C. 505, 510-11, 598 S.E.2d 712, 715 (2004) (â€œIt is well settled that, but for a very few exceptional circumstances, an appellate court cannot address an issue unless it was raised to and ruled upon by the trial court.â€). Â Husbandâ€™s argument regarding the Act comes four years after alimony was ordered in this case.Â  Accordingly, it is not preserved for our review.
II.  Attorneyâ€™s Fees
Husband next contends that if we reverse the trial judgeâ€™s order as to the validity of the alimony award, we should also reverse the award of attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  Because we have affirmed the trial judge decision with regard to alimony, we affirm the award of attorneyâ€™s fees as well.Â  
CONCLUSION
Accordingly, the trial judgeâ€™s order is
AFFIRMED. 
HEARN, C.J., and BEATTY and SHORT, JJ., concur.

[1] â€œCompetent for VA purposesâ€ indicates Husbandâ€™s competency to handle his own finances provided him by the Administration.Â  
[2] Husband and Wife agreed that if Wife was successful on her claim against Husband for adultery, she would receive permanent periodic alimony of $800 per month, commencing October 1, 2000.Â  Husband and Wife, along with Husbandâ€™s guardian, considered the agreement to be fair.Â

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        Department of Social Services, Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Rhonda M., Christopher George M., Chris H., Thomas Bill S., John Doe, Richard Roe, and the minor children under the age of eighteen (18) years:Â  C.M.Â  (born 10/31/2000), S.J.M. (born 07/19/2002),Â  K.M.(born 08/09/1997), Defendants; of whom Christopher George M. is
           Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal from Spartanburg County
Â James F. Fraley, Jr., Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-013
Submitted January 1, 2007 â€“ Filed January 11, 2007

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Stephen M. Bingman, of Spartanburg, for Appellant.
        DeborahÂ  Murdock, of Greenville, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: Christopher George M. (Father) appeals the family courtâ€™s termination of his parental rights to C.M., S.J.M., and K.M. (collectively â€œthe Childrenâ€). We affirm.[1]
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
On December 9, 2003, the Childrenâ€™s mother, Rhonda M. (Mother), was arrested.Â  Two days later, on December 11, 2003, the Children were taken into custody by the Department of Social Services (the Department).Â  Father was incarcerated at this time.Â  
Mother and Father were married on December 5, 1997.Â  As a result, Father is the presumptive legal father of S.J.M. and C.M.[2]Â  However, Mother named him as the potential biological father of only one of the children, S.J.M.Â  She claimed Chris H.[3] and Thomas Bill S. fathered K.M. and C.M., respectively.Â  A paternity test indicated Thomas Bill S. is C.M.â€™s biological father.Â  
On February 2, 2004, the family court held a removal hearing.Â  Because of Fatherâ€™s incarceration, a guardian ad litem represented Father at this hearing.Â  Father did not contest the Departmentâ€™s removal of the Children.Â  The family court entered an order with the consent of all parties for removal of the Children.Â  The family court further noted Father agreed to a submitted treatment plan which required Father to â€œcontact [the Department] upon his release from prison.Â  If he wants custody of his minor child or children, he must first request and complete a DSS treatment plan.â€Â  
Father was released from prison around June 25, 2004.Â  After his release, Fonda Chandler, the Childrenâ€™s foster care caseworker, set up an appointment to discuss a treatment plan for Father, but Father did not show up for the meeting. Â On July 30, Father underwent a hair test for drugs and tested positive for cocaine and benzos.Â  A related urine test was found altered.Â  Pursuant to court order, he was required to take another urine and hair test in November.Â  The urine test came back negative, however, Father did not take the court-ordered hair test. 
In February 2005, police arrested Father for two counts of larceny of a firearm, breaking and entering, two counts of possession of a firearm by a felon, two counts of probation violation, two counts of obtaining property by false pretenses, and larceny after breaking and entering.Â  Father was incarcerated again as of February 23, 2005.Â  
On March 23, 2006, the family court held a hearing for the termination of parental rights (TPR) of Father, Thomas Bill S., Chris H., John Doe, Richard Roe, and Mother.Â  Mother voluntarily relinquished her parental rights in the Children.Â  Thomas Bill S. appeared at the hearing, but did not oppose the relief requested by the Department.Â  Father, who was still incarcerated, challenged TPR through a guardian ad litem.Â Â Â  
At the TPR hearing, Chandler testified Father did not take steps to reunify himself with the Children during the eight month period in which he was not incarcerated.Â  She further explained Father made no attempt to financially support the Children, did not visit them on a consistent basis, and was not able to maintain a stable environment for the Children.Â  
The family court terminated Fatherâ€™s parental rights to the Children, holding (1) Father failed to remedy the conditions which caused the Childrenâ€™s removal from his home within six months of the adoption of a placement plan; (2) the Children lived outside Fatherâ€™s home for more than six months and, during this time, Father willfully failed to visit the Children; (3) the Children lived outside of Fatherâ€™s home for more than six months and, during this time, Father willfully failed to support the Children; (4) Father is not the biological father of C.M. and C.M.â€™s welfare would best be served by TPR; (5) Father has a diagnosable condition of drug addiction unlikely to change within a reasonable time; (6) the Children had been in foster care for fifteen of the twenty-two months before the hearing; and (7) TPR is in the Childrenâ€™s best interest.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§20-7-1572 (2)-(6), (8) (Supp. 2005) (providing the bases for TPR).Â  This appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In a TPR action, the best interests of the children are the paramount consideration.Â  Doe v. Baby Boy Roe, 353 S.C. 576, 579, 578 S.E.2d 733, 735 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  Before parental rights can be forever terminated, the grounds for the termination must be proven by clear and convincing evidence.Â  S.C. Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Headden, 354 S.C. 602, 608, 582 S.E.2d 419, 423 (2003).Â  In an appeal from a TPR, an appellate court may review the record and make its own determination whether the grounds for termination are supported by clear and convincing evidence.Â  Id. at 609, 582 S.E.2d at 423.Â  Despite this broad scope of review, the appellate court is not required to disregard the findings of the family court, as the family court is in a better position to evaluate the credibility of the witnesses and assign weight to their testimony.Â  Id. Â This degree of deference is especially true in cases involving the welfare and best interests of minor children.Â  Ex parte Morris, 367 S.C. 56, 62, 624 S.E.2d 649, 652 (2006).
LAW/ANALYSIS
I. Termination of Parental Rights
Father first contends the family court erred in terminating his parental rights because the court erroneously determined (1) the Children were removed from his home, (2) that he did not visit the Children, (3) that he did not support the Children, (4) that he has a diagnosable condition unlikely to change in a reasonable time, and (5) that his rights should be terminated as to C.M. based on the finding he is not the childâ€™s biological father. Â We decline to address these issues because Father does not dispute the termination of his parental rights on the alternate basis that the minor children had been in foster care for fifteen of the most recent twenty-two months at the time of the hearing.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1572(8) (Supp. 2005) (permitting TPR where a child has been in foster care under the responsibility of the State for fifteen of the most recent twenty-two months). Â Because Father does not refute this finding, the courtâ€™s determination that Fatherâ€™s parental rights should be terminated under section 20-7-1572(8) is the law of the case.Â  See Charleston Lumber Co. v. Miller Housing Corp., 338 S.C. 171, 175, 525 S.E.2d 869, 871 (2000) (holding an unappealed ruling is the law of the case);Â  S.C. Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Seegars, 367 S.C. 623, 628, n. 3, 627 S.E.2d 718, 721, n.3 (2006) (ruling unappealed grounds for TPR are law of the case). Further, our courts have held that a finding pursuant to section 20-7-1572(8) alone is sufficient to support a termination of parental rights. Â S.C. Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Sims, 359 S.C. 601, 608, 598 S.E.2d 303, 307 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  See also Charleston County Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. King, 369 S.C. 96, ____, 631 S.E.2d 239, 241 (2006) (holding, where parent failed to appeal ruling that child had been in foster care for fifteen of most recent twenty-two months, one statutory ground for TPR had been met and the appellate court need only consider whether termination of parental rights was in the best interest of the child).
II.Â  Best Interests of the Children
Father next maintains the family court erred in failing to make specific findings of fact supporting its decision that TPR was in the best interest of the Children.Â  We disagree.
Rule 26(a), SCRFC provides that â€œ[a]n order or judgment pursuant to an adjudication in a domestic relations case shall set forth the specific findings of fact and conclusions of law to support the courtâ€™s decision.â€Â  However, an appellate court may make an independent review of the record to make findings of fact when the family courtâ€™s order fails to make such findings in compliance with Rule 26(a).Â  Bull v. Smith, 299 S.C. 123, 126, 382 S.E.2d 905, 906-07 (1989).
We first note the family court orally included specific grounds supporting its finding TPR is in the best interest of the Children.Â  The family court stated:

  As to [Mother], I find that she voluntarily relinquished her rights and, based on the childrenâ€™s excitement about the possibility of adoption, and the plan to put them back together, with the prospective adoptive parents possibly being available, I find itâ€™s in their best interests and I will terminate [Motherâ€™s] parental rights.

With respect to Father, the family court found TPR is â€œin the best interests for the same reason as [for Mother] . . . .â€Â  
Additionally, we find clear and convincing evidence compels a finding TPR is in the Childrenâ€™s best interest.Â  First, Motherâ€™s counsel indicated Mother believed TPR and adoption would be in the Childrenâ€™s best interest, resulting in Motherâ€™s relinquishment of her own parental rights.Â  Second, the Childrenâ€™s caseworker, Chandler, testified she believed TPR and adoption would be in the Childrenâ€™s best interest.Â  Third, Chandler testified the Children were well-adjusted in their foster home, adoption recruitments had been successful, the Department found a pre-adoptive home for the Children, and the Children would be placed together during pre-adoption.Â  The Department was working for the Children to be adopted together, and the Children were excited about this possibility because of the continuing bond they shared.Â Â  
Additionally, Chandler testified Father did not work toward reunification with the Children, make financial or material contributions to support them, visit on a consistent basis, or show himself capable of providing a stable environment for the Children.Â  Finally, the Childrenâ€™s guardian ad litem confirmed the Children were well adjusted at that time, they were excited at the prospect of being adopted together, and agreed TPR would be in their best interest.Â  Based on this evidence, we hold clear and convincing evidence compels a conclusion TPR and adoption is in the Childrenâ€™s best interest.
For the foregoing reasons, the family courtâ€™s decision is
AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON, HUFF and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2] See Chandler v. Merrell, 291 S.C. 224, 226, 353 S.E.2d 133, 134 (1987) (â€œEvery child born in wedlock is presumed to be legitimate.â€).Â  Although the current marital status of Mother and Father is unknown, Mother had filed for divorce at the time of the TPR hearing.Â  
[3] The record shows the Department had legal documentation showing that in June 2001, a Chris H.H. changed his name to Christopher George M. The Department has no proof whether Chris H. does or does not exist, but Chris H.H. shows the same date of birth as Father.Â Â Â

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        Wesley Evans, Employee, Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        COMTRAK, Inc., Employer, and Great West Casualty Co., Inc., Appellants.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
Â Thomas L. Hughston, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-014
Submitted January 1, 2007 â€“ Filed January 11, 2007

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Darryl D. Smalls, of Columbia, for Appellants.
        Daniel A. Beck, of Charleston, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  COMTRAK, Inc. (COMTRAK), and Great West Casualty Company, Inc. (Carrier)[1] appeal the circuit courtâ€™s order entering judgment in favor of Wesley Evans (Evans) for payment of workerâ€™s compensation benefits.Â  We affirm.[2]
FACTS
On January 27, 2004, Evans was injured in a motor vehicle accident while driving a truck for COMTRAK.Â  Evans sought temporary total and permanent partial disability benefits for injuries sustained to his head, shoulder, left arm, neck, and back.Â  COMTRAK denied the claim asserting Evans was an independent contractor and not an employee.Â  
The single commissioner entered an order on December 21, 2004, in which he found Evans was an employee and entitled to benefits.Â  The commissioner awarded temporary total disability benefits from the date of the injury until October 24, 2004, the date on which Evans reached maximum medical improvement, and ordered payment of all causally-related medical expenses.Â  The commissioner assigned Evans a forty percent permanent partial disability rating to his left upper extremity and awarded him the requisite benefits. 
COMTRAK appealed to the Appellate Panel.Â  By order dated July 7, 2005, the Appellate Panel unanimously affirmed the decision of the single commissioner and adopted his order in its entirety. 
During the pendency of COMTRAKâ€™s appeal to the circuit court, Evans moved for an entry of judgment for payment of his awarded benefits.Â  Without a hearing, the circuit court entered judgment on September 16, 2005. Â This appeal followed.
DISCUSSION
COMTRAK argues the circuit court erred in issuing the order of judgment.Â  Specifically, COMTRAK asserts an entry of judgment is inappropriate and unnecessary because it has been making weekly benefit payments and has the financial ability to continue these payments.
In support of its argument, COMTRAK relies on section 42-17-70 of the South Carolina Code.Â  This section provides:

  Any party in interest may file in the court of common pleas of the county in which the injury occurred a certified copy of a memorandum of agreement approved by the Commission, an order or decision of the Commission, an award of the Commission unappealed from or an award of the Commission affirmed upon appeal, whereupon such court shall render judgment in accordance therewith and notify the parties. Such judgment shall have the same effect and all proceedings in relation thereto shall thereafter be the same as though such judgment had been rendered in a suit duly heard and determined by such court. But if the judgment debtor shall file a certificate duly issued by the Commission, showing compliance with Â§ 42-5-20,[3] with the clerk of the court in the county in which such judgment is docketed, such clerk shall make upon the judgment roll an entry showing the filing of such certificate which shall operate as a discharge of the lien of such judgment and no execution shall be issued thereon. But if at any time there is default in the payment of any installment due under the award set forth in such judgment the court may, upon application for cause and after ten daysâ€™ notice to the judgment debtor, order the lien of such judgment restored and execution or other proper process may be immediately issued thereon for past-due installments and for future installments as they may become due.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-17-70 (1985) (emphasis added).Â  
From what we can glean from the scant record and the partiesâ€™ briefs, the only point of contention is whether a judgment should have been entered to ensure COMTRAKâ€™s obligation to make weekly payments through Carrier for Evansâ€™ awarded benefits.Â  Both parties agree that COMTRAK was required by statute and case law interpreting the applicable statutes to pay Evans weekly benefits after the Appellate Panelâ€™s award.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-17-60 (Supp. 2005) (â€œIn case of an appeal from the decision of the commission on questions of law, the appeal does not operate as a supersedeas and thereafter the employer is required to make payment of the award involved in the appeal or certification until the questions at issue have been fully determined in accordance with the provisions of this title.â€); Case v. Hermitage Cotton Mills, 236 S.C. 515, 533, 115 S.E.2d 57, 66 (1960) (â€œWe construe Section 72-356 (precursor to section 42-17-60) as requiring payment, after the expiration of the thirty-day supersedeas period and during the pendency of the employerâ€™s appeal to the circuit court . . . not of such additional amounts, but only of the weekly compensation accruing after the date of the Commissionâ€™s award.â€); McLeod v. Piggly Wiggly Carolina Co., 280 S.C. 466, 472, 313 S.E.2d 38, 41 (Ct. App. 1984) (â€œSections 42-17-60 and 42-17-70 allow the payment of weekly compensation accruing after the date of the Commissionâ€™s award.â€).Â Â  Â 
Because Evans claimed that COMTRAK was not fulfilling its payment obligation, he was within his right, pursuant to section 42-17-70, to move for the circuit court to enter judgment after the Appellate Panel issued its order.Â  Pursuant to the statutory mandate, the court properly entered judgment based on Evansâ€™ motion.Â  
Although COMTRAK places great significance on the entry of this judgment, our appellate courts have characterized the statutorily-mandated entry of judgment as â€œministerial rather than judicial.â€ Â Thus, it is important to note the entry of the judgment has no affect on the merits of the underlying award of benefits claim.Â  See Wall v. C. Y. Thomason Co., 232 S.C. 153, 156, 101 S.E.2d 286, 288 (1957) (discussing section 72-357 (precursor to section 42-17-70) and stating â€œ[t]he language of the section is mandatory; and the rendition of judgment in such case is ministerial rather than judicial, for the award is subject to review only by the appeal procedure . . . .â€); McCants v. West Virginia Pulp & Paper Co., 223 S.C. 467, 470, 76 S.E.2d 614, 616 (1953) (discussing section 72-357 and stating â€œ[t]he entry of a judgment is merely a ministerial act and for the purposes of notice, lien, and enforcementâ€). 
Given that Evans was within his statutorily-created right to move for a judgment, we fail to see what remedy this court can provide for COMTRAK.Â  If COMTRAK is correct in its claim that it has been paying Evansâ€™ weekly benefits, it may discharge the judgment at issue by presenting to the clerk of court a certificate of compliance issued by the Commission.Â  If the judgment is discharged and COMTRAK becomes in default in the payment of Evansâ€™ weekly benefits, Evans may move to have the lien of the judgment restored to secure past-due and future payments.
CONCLUSION
Because the circuit court properly entered judgment in compliance with section 42-17-70, we affirm the courtâ€™s order.Â  Our decision, however, should not be construed as expressing any opinion as to the merits of the underlying claim for workerâ€™s compensation benefits.Â  We reiterate the entry of judgment is ministerial in nature and is not determinative of any future appeal arising from Evansâ€™ claim for benefits.Â  Finally, we emphasize that COMTRAK is not without remedy given it may move to discharge the judgment by filing with the clerk of court a certificate of compliance issued by the Commission.
Accordingly, the order of the circuit court is
AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON, HUFF, and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

[1] Although both parties appeal the circuit courtâ€™s order, we refer to the Appellants solely as â€œCOMTRAKâ€ in the interest of clarity and brevity.
[2] Because oral argument would not aid the court in resolving the issues on appeal, we decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[3]Â Â  Section 42-5-20 of the South Carolina Code outlines the requirements for an Employerâ€™s need for liability insurance or proof of its ability to pay awarded benefits.Â  This code section provides in pertinent part:Â  

  Every employer who accepts the provisions of this title relative to the payment of compensation shall insure and keep insured his liability thereunder in any authorized corporation, association, organization, or mutual insurance association formed by a group of employers so authorized or shall furnish to the commission satisfactory proof of his financial ability to pay directly the compensation in the amount and manner and when due as provided for in this title.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-5-20 (Supp. 2005).

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        Village West Horizontal Property Regime, Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Kenneth C. Arata and Madeleine R. Aratan,Â Appellants.
      
    
  


Appeal From Beaufort County
Â Jackson V. Gregory, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-015
Submitted January 1, 2007 â€“ Filed January 11, 2007

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Jack D. Simrill, of Hilton Head Island, for Appellants.
        Edward E. Bullard and Sonja N. Friedman, of Hilton Head Island, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  In this lien foreclosure action, Kenneth C. and Madeleine R. Arata (the Aratas) appeal the circuit courtâ€™s order granting Village West Horizontal Property Regime (Regime) summary judgment.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
The Aratas own Unit 6 in Phase 3 of the Village West Horizontal Property Regime.Â  Unit 6 is located in the Spinnaker building, one of five buildings within the Regime.Â  In March 2005, the Regime filed a complaint against the Aratas for failure to pay an assessment.Â  In addition, the Regime filed a lis pendens against Unit 6. 
On March 21, 2005, the Regime filed an amended complaint, asserting a lien against Unit 6 and asking the circuit court to foreclose on the lien.Â  The Aratas answered, admitting they did not pay the assessment.Â  However, they averred the Regimeâ€™s By-Laws prevented the Regime from collecting the assessment.Â  Furthermore, the Aratas counterclaimed for slander of title.Â  Subsequently, the Aratas moved to amend their answer to assert a counterclaim for an accounting of settlement proceeds from a lawsuit involving construction defects in the Spinnaker building.[2]Â  
The Regime moved for summary judgment, attaching a memorandum and several exhibits.Â  The Regime explained it initiated two lawsuits from 1994 to 1997.Â  The first suit involved construction-related defects in the Spinnaker building.Â  This lawsuit settled for $300,000.Â  The second lawsuit involved construction-related defects in the other four buildings within the Regime.Â  The second lawsuit settled for $7 million.[3]Â  
According to the Regime, the total recovery from these suits did not cover the entire expense of repairing the buildings.Â  As a result, the Regimeâ€™s board assessed all of the unit owners according to their percentage of ownership in the Regime.Â  The Aratas refused to pay this assessment. Â After the Regime filed the present foreclosure action, the Aratas sought a temporary injunction to stop the Regimeâ€™s repair of the buildings. Â This request was denied.Â  
The Aratas filed a motion in opposition to summary judgment.Â  They argued the second lawsuit, relating to defects in all of the Regimeâ€™s buildings except the Spinnaker building, resulted in a deficiency.Â  Consequently, the Aratas contended, the Regime improperly levied the assessment to cover the deficiency as to those buildings only.Â  Furthermore, they reiterated their position that the Regimeâ€™s By-Laws prohibited such an assessment. 
After a hearing, the circuit court granted summary judgment to the Regime and ordered foreclosure of the lien.Â  The Aratas moved for reconsideration, which the circuit court denied.Â  This appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
When reviewing the grant of a summary judgment motion, the appellate court applies the same standard which governs the circuit court under Rule 56(c), SCRCP: summary judgment is proper when no genuine issue of material fact exists and the moving party is entitled to judgment as a matter of law.Â  David v. McLeod Regâ€™l Med. Ctr., 367 S.C. 242, 247, 626 S.E.2d 1, 3 (2006); Bennett v. Investors Title Ins. Co., 370 S.C. 578, ___, 635 S.E.2d 649, 654-55 (Ct. App. 2006).Â  In determining whether any triable issues of fact exist, the evidence and all reasonable inferences must be viewed in the light most favorable to the non-moving party. Law v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Corrs., 368 S.C. 424, 434, 629 S.E.2d 642, 648 (2006); Wells v. City of Lynchburg, 331 S.C. 296, 302, 501 S.E.2d 746, 749 (Ct. App. 1998).Â  If triable issues exist, those issues must go the jury. Mulherin-Howell v. Cobb, 362 S.C. 588, 595, 608 S.E.2d 587, 591 (Ct. App. 2005). Â 
Summary judgment is appropriate if the pleadings, depositions, answers to interrogatories, and admissions on file, together with the affidavits, if any, show there is no genuine issue as to any material fact and the moving party is entitled to judgment as a matter of law. Rule 56(c), SCRCP; Law, 368 S.C. at 434, 629 S.E.2d at 648; BPS, Inc. v. Worthy, 362 S.C. 319, 325, 608 S.E.2d 155, 159 (Ct. App. 2005). Â On appeal from an order granting summary judgment, the appellate court will review all ambiguities, conclusions, and inferences arising in and from the evidence in a light most favorable to the non-moving party below. Sloan v. Friends of Hunley, Inc., 369 S.C. 20, 25, 630 S.E.2d 474, 477 (2006); see also Schmidt v. Courtney, 357 S.C. 310, 317, 592 S.E.2d 326, 330 (Ct. App. 2003) (stating that all ambiguities, conclusions, and inferences arising from the evidence must be construed strongly against the moving party).
When further inquiry into the facts of the case is desirable to clarify application of the law, summary judgment is not appropriate.Â  Gadson v. Hembree, 364 S.C. 316, 320, 613 S.E.2d 533, 535 (2005); Miller v. Blumenthal Mills, Inc., 365 S.C. 204, 220, 616 S.E.2d 722, 729 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  Even when there is no dispute as to evidentiary facts, but only as to the conclusions or inferences to be drawn from them, summary judgment should be denied.Â  Nelson v. Charleston County Parks & Recreation Commâ€™n, 362 S.C. 1, 5, 605 S.E.2d 744, 746 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  However, when plain, palpable, and indisputable facts exist on which reasonable minds cannot differ, summary judgment should be granted. Â Rife v. Hitachi Constr. Mach. Co., Ltd., 363 S.C. 209, 214, 609 S.E.2d 565, 568 (Ct. App. 2005); Ellis v. Davidson, 358 S.C. 509, 518, 595 S.E.2d 817, 822 (Ct. App. 2004).
The party seeking summary judgment has the burden of clearly establishing the absence of a genuine issue of material fact. Â Jones v. State Farm Mut. Auto. Ins. Co., 364 S.C. 222, 228, 612 S.E.2d 719, 722 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  The moving party may discharge the burden of demonstrating the absence of a genuine issue of material fact by pointing out the absence of evidence to support the nonmoving partyâ€™s case. Â Lanham v. Blue Cross & Blue Shield of S.C., Inc., 349 S.C. 356, 361, 563 S.E.2d 331, 333 (2002).Â  Once the party moving for summary judgment meets the initial burden of showing an absence of evidentiary support for the opponentâ€™s case, the opponent cannot simply rest on mere allegations or denials contained in the pleadings.Â  Bennett v. Investors Title Ins. Co., 370 S.C. 561, ___, 635 S.E.2d 660, 665 (Ct. App. 2006).Â  Rather, the nonmoving party must come forward with specific facts showing there is a genuine issue for trial. Â Rife, 363 S.C. at 214, 609 S.E.2d at 568.
The purpose of summary judgment is to expedite the disposition of cases which do not require the services of a fact finder. Â Dawkins v. Fields, 354 S.C. 58, 69, 580 S.E.2d 433, 438 (2003); Rumpf v. Massachusetts Mut. Life Ins. Co., 357 S.C. 386, 393, 593 S.E.2d 183, 186 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  Because it is a drastic remedy, summary judgment should be cautiously invoked to ensure that a litigant is not improperly deprived of a trial on disputed factual issues. Â Helena Chem. Co. v. Allianz Underwriters Ins. Co., 357 S.C. 631, 644, 594 S.E.2d 455, 462 (2004); B & B Liquors, Inc. v. Oâ€™Neil, 361 S.C. 267, 270, 603 S.E.2d 629, 631 (Ct. App. 2004).
DISCUSSION
I. The By-Laws
The Aratas contend the circuit court erred in holding that the Regimeâ€™s By-Laws did not prohibit the assessment.Â  Alternatively, they maintain the By-Laws are ambiguous.Â  In response, the Regime argues both the By-Laws and statutory authority compel the construction defects be repaired through a pro rata assessment.Â  We agree with the Regime.
The operative documents that govern a horizontal property regime constitute a contract between the association and its individual members.Â  Swanson v. Parkway Estates Townhouse Assâ€™n, 567 N.W.2d 767, 768 (Minn. App. 1997); see also Reyhani v. Stone Creek Cove Condo. II Horizâ€™l Prop. Regime, 329 S.C. 206, 211-13, 494 S.E.2d 465, 468-69 (Ct. App. 1997) (applying principles of contract law to interpret the operative documents of a horizontal property regime); Houck v. Rivers, 316 S.C. 414, 416, 450 S.E.2d 106, 108 (Ct. App. 1994) (interpreting provisions of a master deed using contract law).Â  The interpretation of a clear and unambiguous agreement is a question of law for the court.Â  Pearson v. Church of God, 325 S.C. 45, 54, 478 S.E.2d 849, 853 (1996); Stribling v. Stribling, 369 S.C. 400, ___, 632 S.E.2d 291, 293 (Ct. App. 2006).
In construing a contract, the primary objective is to ascertain and give effect to the intention of the parties.Â  D.A. Davis Constr. Co., Inc. v. Palmetto Props., Inc., 281 S.C. 415, 418, 315 S.E.2d 370, 372 (1984); Ellie, Inc. v. Miccichi, 358 S.C. 78, 93, 594 S.E.2d 485, 493 (Ct. App. 2004); see also Brady v. Brady, 222 S.C. 242, 246, 72 S.E.2d 193, 195 (1952) (â€œAgreements should be liberally construed so as to give them effect and carry out the intention of the parties.â€).Â  The partiesâ€™ intention should first be determined from the language of the contract.Â  Schulmeyer v. State Farm Fire & Cas. Co., 353 S.C. 491, 495, 579 S.E.2d 132, 134 (2003); Gilbert v. Miller, 356 S.C. 25, 30, 586 S.E.2d 861, 864 (Ct. App. 2003); Goode v. St. Stephens United Methodist Church, 329 S.C. 433, 445, 494 S.E.2d 827, 833 (Ct. App. 1997); see also Bruce v. Blalock, 241 S.C. 155, 161, 127 S.E.2d 439, 442 (1962) (â€œIt is axiomatic that the intent and purport of a written contract or agreement has to be gathered from the contents of the entire agreement and not from any particular clause or provision thereof.â€).
In general, if the contract is unambiguous, clear, and explicit, it must be construed according to the terms the parties have used, and the terms are to be taken and understood in their plain, ordinary, and popular sense.Â  Ingram v. Kaseyâ€™s Assocs., 340 S.C. 98, 110, 531 S.E.2d 287, 293 (2000); Jordan v. Sec. Group, Inc., 311 S.C. 227, 230, 428 S.E.2d 705, 707 (1993); see also Superior Auto. Ins. Co. v. Maners, 261 S.C. 257, 263, 199 S.E.2d 719, 722 (1973) (â€œ[T]o ascertain the intention of an instrument resort is first to be had to its language, and if such is perfectly plain and capable of legal construction, such language determines the force and effect of the instrument.â€).Â  When an agreement is clear and capable of legal interpretation, the courtâ€™s only function is to interpret its lawful meaning, discover the intention of the parties as found within the agreement, and give effect to it.Â  Heins v. Heins, 344 S.C. 146, 158, 543 S.E.2d 224, 230 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  The court must enforce an unambiguous contract according to its terms, regardless of the contractâ€™s wisdom or folly, or the partiesâ€™ failure to guard their rights carefully.Â  McPherson v. J. E. Sirrine & Co., 206 S.C. 183, 206, 33 S.E.2d 501, 510 (1945); Ellie, 358 S.C. at 93-94, 594 S.E.2d at 493.
Article IX of the Regimeâ€™s By-Laws provides, in pertinent part:
ARTICLE IX
RECONSTRUCTION AND REPAIR

  
    In the event of casualty loss or damage to the Property, the [Regimeâ€™s] Board of Directors shall be responsible for applying the proceeds of all casualty insurance to the repair or reconstruction of the Property in accordance with the provisions of this ARTICLE IX.Â  Reconstruction or repair shall be mandatory unless two-thirds or more of the Property is destroyed or substantially damaged.Â  If two-thirds or more of the Property is destroyed or substantially damaged, reconstruction shall not be mandatory . . . . If less than two-thirds of the Property is destroyed or substantially damaged, then such Property shall be repaired in the following manner:
    . . . 
    (3) If the insurance proceeds paid to the Board are insufficient to cover the cost of reconstruction, the deficiency shall be paid as a special assessment by the Unit Owners whose units are being reconstructed or repaired in proportion to the damage done to their respective Units.
    (4) The insurance proceeds received by the Board . . . and any special assessments collected to cover a deficiency in insurance shall constitute a construction fund from which the Board . . . shall disburse payment of the costs of reconstruction and repair.Â  The first disbursements from the construction fund shall be insurance proceeds; and if there is a balance in the fund after payment of all costs of reconstruction and repair, it shall be distributed to the Unit Owners who paid special assessments in proportion to their payments.Â  Any balance remaining after such distribution shall be retained by the Association.
  

Moreover, Article X of the Regimeâ€™s By-Laws reads, in relevant part:
ARTICLE X
INSURANCE TRUST

  
    In the event of casualty loss to the Property, all insurance proceeds indemnifying the loss or damage shall be paid jointly to the Board of Directors as Insurance Trustee . . . . The Board of Directors, acting as Insurance Trustee, shall receive and hold all insurance proceeds in trust for the purposes stated in this ARTICLE X, and for the benefit of the Association, the Unit Owners, and their respective mortgagees in the following share:
    . . . 
    (2) Insurance proceeds paid on account of loss or damage to less than all of the Units, when the damage is restored, shall be held for the benefit of Unit Owners of the damaged Units . . . in proportion to the costs of repairing each damaged unit.
  

The Aratas argue these provisions provide the proper procedures to collect and use funds obtained from the above-referenced lawsuits.Â  Moreover, they assert the Regime could not assess unit owners in the Spinnaker building to pay for reconstruction and repair costs with respect to the other buildings in the Regime.Â  To support their argument, they specifically reference Article IXâ€™s language referring to â€œcasualty loss or damage to the Propertyâ€ and the fact that the adjective â€œcasualtyâ€ is omitted from later references to loss and insurance within Article IX.
Initially, we hold Articles IX and X of the Regimeâ€™s By-Laws have no application to the present case. Â A contract is read as a whole document so that one may not, by pointing out a single sentence or clause, create an ambiguity.Â  S. Atl. Fin. Servs., Inc. v. Middleton, 356 S.C. 444, 447, 590 S.E.2d 27, 29 (2003); see also Yarborough v. Phoenix Mut. Life Ins. Co., 266 S.C. 584, 592, 225 S.E.2d 344, 349 (1976) (â€œThat construction will be adopted which will give effect to the whole instrument and to each of its various parts and provisions, if it is reasonable to do so.â€); J.T.M. Co., Inc. v. Vane, 283 S.C. 512, 516, 323 S.E.2d 794, 796 (Ct. App. 1984) (â€œIn determining the intent and purport of a contract, a court should not look solely to one clause read in isolation from the rest of the document; rather, it should consider the contents of the whole instrument.â€).
In this case, the opening paragraph of Article IX refers to â€œcasualty loss or damage to the Property . . .â€ and â€œthe proceeds of all casualty insurance.â€Â  The remainder of Article IX guides the board in how to apply these insurance proceeds and what procedure to follow if the proceeds are deficient.Â  The clear, unambiguous intent of this provision is to provide the board guidance in the event of a casualty loss or damage caused by a casualty.
Moreover, we agree with the Regime that other provisions within the Regimeâ€™s Master Deed and By-Laws specifically allow the assessment.Â  Article V, Section (e) of the Master Deed reads, in relevant part:

  The obligations of all Unit owners with regard to assessments for common expenses and the maintenance and repair of the individual Units shall be as provided in the By-Laws of the [Regime] . . . .

Article VII, Section 6(c) of the Regimeâ€™s By-Laws provides, in pertinent part:

  All maintenance, repair and replacement to the common elements as defined in the Master Deed, the painting and decorating of the exterior doors and exterior window sash and the washing of exterior glass shall be made by the [Regimeâ€™s] Board [of Directors] . . . and shall be charged to the Unit Owners as a common expense . . . .

Article VIII, Section (a) of the Master Deed defines the Regimeâ€™s common elements, which include â€œthe foundations, roofs, perimeter walls, walls and partitions separating units, [and] load-bearing floors . . . .â€Â  
The Regimeâ€™s Master Deed and By-Laws clearly provide for the assessment of all unit owners for construction defects with respect to any of the buildings within the Regime.Â  Additionally, this language complies with statutory law and the general purpose behind horizontal property regimes.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 27-31-240 (Supp. 2005) (â€œThe co-owners of the apartments are bound to contribute pro rata . . . toward the expenses of administration and of maintenance and repair of the general common elements.â€); Sterling Village Condo., Inc. v. Breitenbach, 251 So.2d 685, 688 (Fla. App. 1971) (â€œEvery man may justly consider his home his castle and himself as the king thereof; nonetheless his sovereign fiat to use his property as he pleases must yield, at least in degree, where ownership is in common or cooperation with others.â€).
II. Other Issues
The Aratas contend several material issues of fact exist about the proceeds from settlement of the above-referenced lawsuits.Â  Furthermore, they maintain the issue of whether the assessment would be used to pay for repair to buildings other than the Spinnaker buildings is a genuine issue of material fact for a jury.Â  Additionally, they assert the circuit court prematurely granted summary judgment because little discovery had taken place and their motion to amend was still pending.Â  Based on our conclusion that the Regimeâ€™s Master Deed and By-Laws unambiguously allow such an assessment, we need not address these issues.
CONCLUSION
We hold the Regimeâ€™s assessment complied with its operative documents.Â  Moreover, we find the Regime followed the procedure required by statute and the general considerations behind horizontal property regimes with respect to the assessment in this case.Â  Further, these conclusions render it unnecessary for this court to address the Aratasâ€™ remaining contentions.Â  Accordingly, the circuit courtâ€™s order is
AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON, HUFF, and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2] The record does not reveal whether the circuit court heard or ruled upon this motion.
[3] Although the facts alleged in the Regimeâ€™s memorandum are not supported by admissible evidence, the Aratas alleged the same scenario in their appellate brief.Â  Moreover, as will be shown, these facts are immaterial to the circuit courtâ€™s decision.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        The State Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Anthony L. Mann Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
Daniel F. Pieper, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-016
Submitted January 1, 2007 â€“ Filed January 11, 2007

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Joseph L. Savitz, III, Â of Columbia, for Appellant.
        Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Donald J. Zelenka, Assistant Attorney General Derrick K. McFarland, all of Columbia; and Solicitor Ralph Hoisington, of Charleston, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Â Â Anthony L. Mann appeals his convictions for murder and armed robbery.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
On January 7th, 2002, Mann was riding in an automobile with Michael Crumb and Eric Zack, when he was paged by Beverly Blake. Â Over a cellular phone, Blake explained to Mann that her roommate, Dante Tobias, was trying to â€œpimp her outâ€ against her will.Â  She wanted to pack her belongings and leave Tobias and requested the men pick her up in their vehicle.Â  Additionally, Blake informed Mann that Tobias kept money and drugs inside a safe in his house, and the two made plans to steal those items from Tobias.Â  Mann, Crumb, and Zack first visited the residence of Peter Davies, where Mann obtained a gun.Â  Before proceeding to Tobiasâ€™ home, the three men stopped to allow Mann to test-fire the newly acquired weapon.Â  Â Â 
Mann entered Tobiasâ€™ house first, followed shortly thereafter by Crumb, with Zack remaining in the car.Â  Upon entering the living room, Crumb saw Mann had the gun pointed to Tobiasâ€™ head and was arguing with him as to whether or not he was trying to prostitute Blake.Â  Following Mannâ€™s demand, Tobias provided the combination to the safe; however, neither Blake nor Crumb was successful in their attempts to open it.Â  Eventually, Blake and Crumb filled trash bags with items from around the house and left.Â  As Crumb and Blake sat in the car, they heard a gunshot and a scream from Tobias.Â  Mann emerged from the home and informed the others he had shot Tobias in the leg.Â  However, contrary to what Mann told his comrades, Tobias lay dead.Â  He had not been hit in the leg but was struck by a bullet in his back that exited through his chest.Â  
The group then returned to Daviesâ€™ house, where they divided the loot.Â  Mann warned Zack and Crumb not to tell anyone about the dayâ€™s events.Â  At Daviesâ€™ request, Terrance Hudson appeared at the home and provided a ride to Davies, Blake, and Mann.Â  Although Hudson dropped all three of his passengers off at another vehicle in a parking lot some distance away, eventually all four of them ended up at the residence of Nicole Oâ€™Connell.Â  Before leaving Oâ€™Connellâ€™s with Mann and Davies, Blake told her friend, Tiffany Mercado, that Mann would be giving her a ride to Mercadoâ€™s house.Â  Blake was never heard from or seen alive again.
On January 13th, 2002 the body of Beverly Blake was discovered in a secluded, wooded area.Â  She had been shot three times in the head, once in the back, and once in the chest.Â  Based on the condition of her body, the temperature, and other elements, her death was estimated as having occurred on or around January 7th.Â  She appeared to be wearing the same clothes she was wearing when last seen. 
Mann was later arrested and indicted for the armed robbery and murder of Tobias, as well as the murder of Blake.Â  The circuit court judge allowed the two murders to be joined in a single trial because, â€œthe evidence for the murder of victim number one, Dante Tobias, [was] necessary for a full presentation of the case charging the defendant of murder of victim number two, Beverly Blake.â€Â  The judge later stated, â€œBecause of the first, he had to do the second.â€Â  
The trial court held two hearings concerning the prosecutionâ€™s request that it be allowed to consolidate Mannâ€™s indictments.Â  The State argued the evidence of crimes was intertwined and that evidence of either murder was necessary to prove the other.Â  Conversely, Mann argued the two murders did not arise out of the same chain of circumstances and that South Carolina does not allow the joinder of two murder cases.
The trial judge ultimately found:

  The allegations are victim number one lived with victim number two.Â  Victim number two and the defendant conspired to rob victim number one.Â  Victim number two heard a shot while the defendant was the only person with victim number two and the defendant shot victim number two . . . . 
  The evidence that the State uses to prove the murder of victim number one, Dante Tobias, will most likely be admissible to show that the defendantâ€™s alleged motive for murdering victim number two, Beverly Blake, thatâ€™s under the theory the State advances.Â  Of course, in a preliminary determination pretrial if that turns out to not to be the case, I will have to take up any appropriate remedies at that time. 

In addition to testimony establishing the facts as described above, a number of witnesses testified as to Mannâ€™s behavior and particular statements made after the death of Tobias.Â  Zack testified Mann told him that he planned to â€œget rid ofâ€ Blake.Â  Shannon Keyes, a friend of Mannâ€™s, received a call from Mann following the murders.Â  According to Keyes, Mann indicated, â€œ[he and Blake] went go do something and it didnâ€™t turn out the way it was supposed to, and he had to do what he had to and he had to lay low for awhile.â€Â  
Dustin James testified Mann indicated to him that he killed Blake because she knew Mann killed Tobias.Â  Mann also stated that Blake was â€œin the woods.â€Â  Similarly, Krystal Lackey testified Mann said he â€œfound out that [Blake] had given some information and supposedly had told the police, and his words were that he had to kill that n-gg-r bitch.â€Â Â  
For a time, Mervin Menier shared a jail cell with Mann.Â  Consistent with the testimony from other witnesses, Menier testified Mann told him that he shot Tobias.Â  He also told Menier he shot and killed Blake in a secluded area that same night because she was getting nervous.Â  
At the conclusion of the Stateâ€™s case, Mann moved for a mistrial on the basis the indictments were improperly joined.Â  After extensive discussions on the issue, the trial judge denied this motion.Â  
DISCUSSION
Mann avers the trial judge erred by allowing the State to consolidate the two murder charges into a single trial and claims the prosecution established no logical connection between the two homicides.Â  He contends joinder was prejudicial because it is likely the jury inferred a criminal disposition based on evidence he may have been involved in the murder of Blake, and, on that basis alone, found Mann guilty of Tobiasâ€™ murder. Â We disagree.
When offenses charged in separate indictments are of the same general nature involving connected transactions closely related in kind, place, and character, the trial court has the discretion to order the indictments tried together, but only so long as the defendantâ€™s substantive rights are not prejudiced.Â  State v. Cutro, 365 S.C. 366, 374, 618 S.E.2d 890, 894 (2005); State v. Sullivan, 277 S.C. 35, 282 S.E.2d 838 (1981).Â  â€œ[J]oinder of offenses in one trial is â€˜proper if the offenses (1) are of the same general nature or character and spring from the same series of transactions, (2) are committed by the same offender, and (3) require the same or similar proof.â€™ â€Â  State v. Simmons, 352 S.C. 342, 351, 573 S.E.2d 856, 861 (Ct. App. 2002) (citations omitted).Â  Offenses are considered to be of the same general nature where they are inter-connected.Â  State v. Harry, 321 S.C. 273, 468 S.E.2d 76 (Ct. App. 1996).Â  In determining joinder, the trial judge need not find clear and convincing evidence of the charges.Â  Cutro, 365 S.C. at 374, 618 S.E.2d at 894. Â If the trial judge finds there is no substantial evidence to submit any one the joined charges to the jury, the defendant may move for a mistrial on the basis of unfair prejudice resulting from joinder.Â  Cutro, 365 S.C. at 375, 618 S.E.2d at 894; see also State v. Tate, 286 S.C. 462, 334 S.E.2d 289 (1985) (finding prejudice when two forgery charges, not provable by the same evidence, were improperly consolidated). Â Â Â Â Â 
Applying this criterion to the case at bar, there was no error.Â  Simply having two murders occur sequentially within a short span of time and within a small geographic boundary does not in itself determine that the crimes can be prosecuted in a single trial.Â  See State v. Middleton, 288, S.C. 21, 23-24, 339 S.E.2d 692, 693 (1986).Â  However, in this case the State demonstrated much more than a close proximity in time and place. Â These offenses were of the same general nature and character and sprung from the same series of transactions.Â  Overwhelming evidence was presented that Mann committed the two murders.Â  See Simmons, 352 S.C. 342, 573 S.E.2d 856; State v. Carter, 324 S.C. 383, 386, 478 S.E.2d 86, 88 (Ct. App. 1996). Â Evidence of the killing of Tobias was highly relevant in a review of Blakeâ€™s murder.Â  In a Lyle context, evidence of one murder has a relevance to the other and is indicative of motive and intent. Â See State v. Lyle, 125 S.C. 406, 118 S.E. 803 (1923).Â  Thus, similar proof was necessary to find that Mann committed both crimes.Â  
Mann cannot show any prejudice resulting from the trial judgeâ€™s decision to allow the State to consolidate the charges against him.Â  The trial court charged the jury that â€œeach indictment charges a separate and distinct offense.Â  You must decide each indictment on the law and evidence applicable to it.Â  A defendant may be acquitted or convicted on any or all of the offenses charged.Â  You will be asked to write a separate verdict as to each indictment.â€Â  Accordingly, there was no prejudice.
When placed in context of the Stateâ€™s evidence, Blakeâ€™s knowledge of Tobiasâ€™ shooting provided a motive for her murder.Â  At most, the events formed a seamless chain of actions played out over the span of a few hours, and at the least, the murders are intimately connected as the fallout from the first provided the very necessity for the second.Â  On the basis of the substantial evidence presented in this case, the trial judge properly allowed the charges to be consolidated and correctly denied Mannâ€™s motion for a mistrial on the basis of improper joinder.
CONCLUSION 
Accordingly, the trial judge did not abuse his discretion by allowing the State to consolidate all the offenses in a single trial, and Mannâ€™s convictions are
AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON, HUFF, and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        St. Luke Methodist Church Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Lynn Coker Browder, Mark B. Browder, Robert R. McGee and Patricia Coker Respondents,
      
    
  


Appeal from Florence County 
Â James E. Brogdon, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-018
Heard December 8, 2006 â€“ Filed January 11, 2007

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        D. Malloy McEachin, Jr., of Florence, for Appellant.
        C. Craig Young, of Florence, for Respondents.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Following a non-jury trial, St. Luke Methodist Church appeals the trial judgeâ€™s granting of a prescriptive easement over its cemetery, arguing that Respondentsâ€™ use has not been continuous over twenty years and that the sanctity of the cemetery should trump any prescriptive easement Respondents may have.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
St. Luke cemetery in Florence County has been in existence for over a hundred years.Â  The one-acre cemetery is surrounded on all sides by property belonging to others.Â  Blue Stone Drive is the right-of-way the church has always used to get from Sardis Highway to its property. Respondents, the owners and residents of the properties surrounding the cemetery, as well as their predecessors in title, have always used Blue Stone Drive as the exclusive means to access their properties.Â  In fact, because Blue Stone Drive is the only street that leads to the property behind the cemetery, it is also traversed by mail carriers and emergency personnel.Â  Florence County has regularly maintained Blue Stone Drive since at least 1973.Â  Â Â 
When Lynn Browder, one of the respondents, registered her plat in 1994 in order to build her house, she listed a fifty-foot right-of-way from her land to Sardis Highway, wholly outside of St. Lukeâ€™s cemetery property.Â  This right-of-way is impassible, however, due to a fish pond, a canal ditch, and the wetland quality of the land.Â  All of the materials used to build Lynn Browderâ€™s house were brought in on Blue Stone Drive.Â  Also, Browderâ€™s motherâ€™s mobile home and the two mobile homes on Respondent Robert McGeeâ€™s property were brought in on Blue Stone Drive.Â  
Until the commencement of this action, St. Luke never made any attempt to restrict neighboring residentsâ€™ use of Blue Stone Drive. Â Neither Respondents nor their predecessors in title ever sought permission to use Blue Stone Drive.Â  
For over thirty-five years, there has been a fence around three sides of the cemetery, including the side along the back edge.Â  St. Luke does not claim to have erected the fence.Â  More recently, a portion of the fence at the back corner of the property has been rolled up, allowing traffic on Blue Stone Drive to cross the back of the cemetery property.Â  By 1995, traffic on Blue Stone Drive had begun crossing the back of the cemetery property, and the roadway has migrated close to several gravesites near the rear boundary of the cemetery.Â  The potential desecration of the gravesites is St. Lukeâ€™s primary concern in bringing this lawsuit.Â  
In his order, the trial judge noted that Respondents could reach their property without following the present path of Blue Stone Drive through the back of the cemetery.Â  He reasoned that redirecting traffic would eliminate any desecration of gravesites, while keeping Blue Stone Drive open for county maintenance and available for continued access to Respondentsâ€™ properties.Â  The trial judge found that Respondents have obtained a prescriptive easement to access their properties by way of Blue Stone Drive.Â  Pursuant to the courtâ€™s equitable powers, the trial judge relocated the road so as to provide access in the manner least burdensome to the church.Â  Thus, he ordered that traffic on Blue Stone Drive be redirected such that it veers off the cemetery property sixty-two feet before the back edge.Â  St. Luke appeals this ruling.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
The determination of the existence of an easement is a question of fact in a law action and subject to an â€œany evidenceâ€ standard of review when tried by a judge without a jury.Â  Slear v. Hanna, 329 S.C. 407, 410, 496 S.E.2d 633, 635 (1998).Â  The question of the extent of the easement is equitable.Â  Tupper v. Dorchester County, 326 S.C. 318, 323, 487 S.E.2d 187, 190 (1997).Â  On appeal from an action in equity, tried by the judge alone, without a reference, the appellate court has jurisdiction to find facts in accordance with its views of the preponderance of the evidence.Â  Doe v. Clark, 318 S.C. 274, 276, 457 S.E.2d 336, 337 (1995); Thames v. Daniels, 344 S.C. 564, 571, 544 S.E.2d 854, 857 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  This broad scope of review does not require the appellate court to disregard the findings below.Â  Stevenson v. Stevenson, 276 S.C. 475, 477, 279 S.E.2d 616, 617 (1981); Satcher v. Satcher, 351 S.C 477, 482, 570 S.E.2d 535, 538 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  Nor is the appellant relieved of its burden of convincing the court that the trial judge committed error in his findings.Â  Pinckney v. Warren, 344 S.C. 382, 387, 544 S.E.2d 620, 623 (2001); Stevenson v. Stevenson, 276 S.C. 475, 477, 279 S.E.2d 616, 617 (1981).
LAW / ANALYSIS
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  St. Luke argues the trial judge erred in concluding that the Respondents have a prescriptive easement over the cemetery.Â  We disagree.Â  
To establish an easement by prescription, there must be continued and uninterrupted use or enjoyment of the right for the full period of twenty years, identity of the thing enjoyed must be proven, and use must be adverse or under claim of right.Â  Pittman v. Lowther, 363 S.C. 47, 50, 610 S.E.2d 479, 480 (2005).Â  St. Luke argues that the twenty-year time period element was not established because evidence was presented which indicated that prior to 1994, Blue Stone Drive was used exclusively as an access to the cemetery.Â  In support of this contention, St. Luke points to the testimony of the church members and to photographs taken in 1970 showing a fence along the propertyâ€™s southwest corner. Â Â However, the church members did not testify that Blue Stone Drive was never used to access residences before 1994.Â  They testified that traffic from the road had not threatened the gravesites until then.Â  Further, there were numerous witnesses who testified to continuous and exclusive use of Blue Stone Drive by the Respondents and their predecessors to access their properties from Sardis Highway since before 1973.Â  The existence of the fence along the back of the property in 1970 does not refute this testimony; rather it indicates that traffic along Blue Stone Drive changed course over the years such that it later began to cross the back of the property where the fence once stood.Â  The trial judgeâ€™s order does not provide for a prescriptive easement across the area where that fence stood; instead it provides that the easement ends sixty-two feet in front of that area.Â  
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  St. Luke also argues equity favors preserving the sanctity of the cemetery, relying on testimony that the traveled portion of Blue Stone Drive is seven feet from one headstone.Â  However, these arguments ignore the actual nature of the trial judgeâ€™s order.Â  His order in effect steers the traffic on Blue Stone Drive clear of the threatened gravesites.Â  
St. Luke argues that plats registered by Respondents Lynn Browder and Robert McGee imply that Respondents had other access to their properties and were not using Blue Stone Drive for ingress and egress as a matter of right.Â  However, the testimony of Respondents is that Blue Stone Drive has always been the only way they have accessed their properties, and the only way they can access their properties.Â  Furthermore, Florence County has maintained the road for public access since at least 1973, and there exist several residences with addresses on Blue Stone Drive.Â  The existence of plats describing other accesses to Respondentsâ€™ properties does not obviate the evidence supporting Respondentsâ€™ claim.Â  
In addition, the testimony at trial supports a finding that Respondents have used Blue Stone Drive for a continuous and uninterrupted period in excess of twenty years.Â  
CONCLUSION
Because we find there is ample evidence to support the trial judgeâ€™s finding of a prescriptive easement over St. Lukeâ€™s cemetery in favor of Respondents, and because his modification steers traffic away from the gravesites, we hold the circuit court order should be
AFFIRMED.[1]
HEARN, C. J., and BEATTY and SHORT, J. J., concur.

[1] St. Luke also argued that the trial judge erred in finding that Blue Stone Road has been a public road since 1973.Â  However, in light of our disposition of this case, we need not address this argument.Â  See Whiteside v. Cherokee County Sch. Dist. No. One, 311 S.C. 335, 340, 428 S.E.2d 886, 889 (1993) (stating appellate court need not address remaining issues when resolution of prior issue is dispositive).Â
