THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        Stephen M. Whisonant, Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Protection Services, Inc., and Travelers Indemnity Company, Appellants.
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County
Â James W. Johnson, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-019
Submitted January 1, 2007 â€“ Filed January 11, 2007Â Â Â  

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Byron Putnam Roberts, of Columbia, for Appellants
        Stephen Benjamin Samuels, of Lexington, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: Â In this workersâ€™ compensation case, the circuit court affirmed the decision of the Appellate Panel of the Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission, in which the Appellate Panel held Stephen M. Whisonant had not reached maximum medical improvement and was entitled to temporary total disability compensation and additional medical treatment.Â  The employer, Protection Services, Inc., and carrier, Travelers Indemnity Company (collectively Protection Services) appeal.Â  We affirm.[1]Â  
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
Whisonant was involved in an admitted work-related accident in the early hours of January 11, 2001.Â  While he was returning from a job site, the truck he was driving was rear-ended by a tractor trailer on I-95.Â  Whisonantâ€™s truck flipped up in the air, rolled twice, and landed on its top.Â  Whisonant was knocked unconscious by the accident.Â  He was treated at the Colleton County Medical Center emergency room for a neck injury, a concussion, contusions on his chest, and abrasions on his left flank. Â He declined x-rays but had a ct scan on his head.Â  Later that day he was treated at Doctorâ€™s Care, the company health care facility. Â During a follow-up visit, he was diagnosed with cervical strain.Â  At Whisonantâ€™s February 17, 2001 visit, the doctor noted the cervical strain was resolved and released Whisonant with no restrictions.Â  Â Whisonant did not miss any work due to the accident.Â  He continued working for Protection Services until his employment was terminated for unrelated reasons in August of 2001.
Whisonant testified that when he was released by Doctorâ€™s Care, he had a stiff neck and had trouble turning his head when backing up trucks.Â  Around two weeks after being released, he started experiencing numbness in his right arm when driving or keeping his arm in the same position for extended periods of time. Â His symptoms continued to worsen over time. 
On January 25, 2002, Whisonant was treated at Richland Memorial Hospital, where he related that since his accident he had been bothered by neck pain and occasional numbness in his right arm.Â Â  He sought treatment at the emergency room on March 25, 2002 complaining of extreme pain in his right shoulder.Â  Whisonant explained this was the first time he experienced so much pain that he had to go to the emergency room.Â  He was diagnosed with Right C6 radiopathy and set up for an MRI.Â  The MRI report stated â€œImpression is of Multilevel degenerative disc, facet, and uncovertebral spondylosis.â€Â Â Â Â  
Whisonant was seen again at Doctorâ€™s Care on June 27, 2002.Â  The doctor noted Whisonant had palpable spasm and pain.Â  He placed the following restrictions on the return to work form:Â  â€œNo lifting more than 10 pounds.Â  No operation of hazardous or fast-moving machinery, no driving.Â  Ground level work only, no ladder or heights.Â  No repeated bending, stooping, squatting, pushing, jerking, twisting or bouncing.Â  No continuous standing.Â  Minimum [walking], climbing (includes stairs).Â  No overhead lifting.â€Â  In addition, the doctor referred Whisonant to a neurosurgeon.Â  However, Protection Services refused to pay for Whisonant to see the neurosurgeon.Â  
At his attorneyâ€™s suggestion, Whisonant saw an orthopedist, Dr. Donald R. Johnson, II, on September 22, 2002.Â  Dr. Johnson recommended an injection and if that was not successful within three weeks or so then he have surgical decompression.Â  He opined Whisonant had not reached maximum medical improvement (MMI).Â  Whisonant was prescribed Celebrex, Tylox, and Neurontin for the pain.Â  Â Â Â Â 
Whisonant filed a Form 50 seeking additional medical treatment for his neck and right arm plus temporary total disability from June 27, 2002 until he reaches maximum medical improvement.Â  The single commissioner held Whisonant had not reached maximum medical improvement.Â  He found Whisonant was entitled to additional medical treatment as directed by Dr. Johnson as the authorized treating physician and ordered Protection Services to reimburse Whisonant for the previous treatment by Dr. Johnson.Â  The commissioner ruled Whisonant was entitled to receive temporary total disability compensation from June 27, 2002, the date the authorized treating physician put him on light duty, and continuing on a running award of $421.78 until further order of the commission.Â  The Appellate Panel of the South Carolina Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission affirmed the single commissionerâ€™s decision and incorporated by reference the single commissionerâ€™s findings of fact and conclusions of law.Â  The circuit court affirmed the Appellate Panelâ€™s order.Â  This appeal followed. Â Â 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
The Administrative Procedures Act establishes the standard of review for decisions by the South Carolina Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission.Â  Lark v. Bi-Lo, 276 S.C. 130, 135, 276 S.E.2d 304, 306 (1981).Â  This court can reverse or modify the Appellate Panelâ€™s decision only if the appellantâ€™s substantial rights have been prejudiced because the decision is affected by an error of law or is clearly erroneous in view of the reliable, probative, and substantial evidence on the whole record.Â  Shealy v. Aiken County, 341 S.C. 448, 454, 535 S.E.2d 438, 442 (2000); S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-380(A)(5) (Supp. 2006).Â  â€œSubstantial evidence is not a mere scintilla of evidence nor evidence viewed from one side, but such evidence, when the whole record is considered, as would allow reasonable minds to reach the conclusion the [Appellate Panel] reached.â€Â  Shealy, 341 S.C. at 455, 535 S.E.2d at 442.Â  The possibility of drawing two inconsistent conclusions does not prevent the Appellate Panelâ€™s conclusions from being supported by substantial evidence.Â  Tiller v. Natâ€™l Health Care Ctr., 334 S.C. 333, 338, 513 S.E.2d 843, 845 (1999).
DISCUSSION
Protection Services argues the circuit court erred in affirming the finding of the Appellate Panel that Whisonantâ€™s present complaints were causally related to his work-related accident.Â  We disagree.Â  
â€œIf a medical expert is unwilling to state with certainty a connection between an accident and an injury, â€˜the expression of a cautious opinionâ€™ may support an award if there are facts outside the medical testimony that also support an award.â€ Tiller v. Natl.Â  Health Care Ctr., 334 S.C. 333, 340, 513 S.E.2d 843, 846 (1999);Â  Muir v. C.R. Bard, Inc., 336 S.C. 266, 286, 519 S.E.2d 583, 593 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  â€œProof that a claimantÂ  sustained an injury may be established by circumstantial and direct evidence where circumstances lead an unprejudiced mind to reasonably infer the injury was caused by the accident.Â  However, such evidence need not reach such a degree of certainty as to exclude every reasonable or possible conclusion other than that reached by the Commission.â€Â Â  Tiller, 334 S.C. at 341, 513 S.E.2d at 846-47 (citations omitted).Â  Â Â Â Â 
Protection Services contends Whisonant failed to present evidence of even a cautious medical opinion to support the award.Â  We disagree with this interpretation of Whisonantâ€™s doctorâ€™s diagnosis.Â  Whisonantâ€™s orthopedist, Dr. Johnson, wrote in his evaluation of Whisonant:Â  â€œI cannot ascertain whether the accident is causally related to his current symptoms other than by the history given to me by the patient.â€Â  He related Whisonantâ€™s history and then stated, â€œI suspect that he had an aggravation of a pre-existing condition.â€Â  
We find Dr. Johnson did in fact render a cautious opinion that Whisonantâ€™s current symptoms were causally related to the accident.Â  The aggravation of a pre-existing condition is a compensable injury.Â  See Brown v. R.L. Jordan Oil Co., 291 S.C. 272, 275, 353 S.E.2d 280, 282 (1987) (stating when a pre-existing condition or disease is accelerated or aggravated by injury or accident arising out of and in the course of the employment, the resulting disability is a compensable injury).Â Â  Dr. Johnson merely qualified his opinion that his diagnosis was based on the history Whisonant provided him.Â  The Appellate Panel found Dr. Johnsonâ€™s report with Whisonantâ€™s history of no symptoms before the accident but symptoms afterwards was sufficient to prove a causal connection between the accident and the injury.Â  We find substantial evidence in the record to support this finding.Â  
Protection Services contends Whisonantâ€™s failure to report neck or arm problem to Doctorâ€™s Care during his visits immediately after the accident, to other doctorâ€™s during visits for other ailments, or to his supervisors evidences his claim for an accident-related injury lacks credibility.Â  Â Â 
In the order adopted in its entirety by the Appellate Panel, the single commissioner found:

  While I am concerned about the gap in treatment and the periods where Claimant saw doctors for unrelated reasons and did not complain of neck or arm problems, this can be attributed to the progressive nature of Claimantâ€™s problems and Claimantâ€™s quiet nature.Â  I find Claimant is not a person who complains about his problems.Â  This is based on the medical records, Claimantâ€™s testimony and the testimony of Venus Mace.Â  

Â â€œThe final determination of witness credibility and the weight to be accorded evidence is reserved to the [Appellate Panel].Â  It is not the task of this Court to weigh the evidence as found by the [Appellate Panel].â€Â  Shealy v. Aiken County, 341 S.C. 448, 455, 535 S.E.2d 438, 442 (2000) (citations omitted). 
As the Appellate Panel found Whisonant credible and there is substantial evidence in the record to support its finding that his injuries were causally connected to his work-related accident, we hold the circuit court did err in affirming the Appellate Panelâ€™s decision.Â  
Protection Services argues the circuit court erred in affirming the finding of the Appellate Panel that Whisonant is not at MMI and is entitled to temporary total disability benefits since June 27, 2002.Â  We disagree.Â  
Dr. Johnson stated in his report, â€œI certainly donâ€™t feel [Whisonant] has reached maximum medical improvement.â€Â  He recommended a cervical injection and if that was not successful in three weeks or so, surgical decompression and fusion at three levels.â€Â  The Appellate Panel considered this report, as well as his other doctorâ€™s records, in concluding Whisonant had not reached MMI.Â  We find this conclusion is clearly supported by substantial evidence.Â  
At the end of its brief, Protection Services argues against an award of benefits because â€œClaimant was terminated from his job with the employer for violation of company policy and he has since voluntarily removed himself from the labor market.â€[2] Â Protection Services failed to raise this argument in its request for commission review.Â  Therefore, the argument is not properly before this court. Rodney v. Michelin Tire Corp., 320 S.C. 515, 517, 466 S.E.2d 357, 358 (1996) (stating arguments not raised to the workersâ€™ compensation commission are not preserved for appeal);Â  Creech v. Ducane Co., 320 S.C. 559, 564, 467 S.E.2d 114, 117 (Ct. App. 1995) (stating only issues within the application for review are preserved for appeal to the commission).
CONCLUSION
For the above stated reason, the order of the circuit court is 
AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON, HUFF, and BEATTY, JJ. concur.Â  Â Â  Â 

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2] Whisonant testified that after his employment with Protection Services was terminated, he attempted to look for other employment until his unemployment benefits ended.Â  He then gave up trying to find another job as he could not find anything that that he could do considering his injuries.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        South Carolina Department of Social Services, Respondent,

        Mother, Father, and Child, Defendants,
        Of whom Father is Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From York County
Â Robert E. Guess, Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-020
Submitted January 1, 2007 â€“ Filed January 11, 2007Â Â Â  

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Christi P. Cox, of Rock Hill, for Appellant.
        Cherie Teat Barton, of York, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Father appeals the family courtâ€™s order terminating his parental rights.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
Father is Childâ€™s biological father. Â This appeal arises from the family courtâ€™s termination of Fatherâ€™s parental rights on January 31, 2006, for the following statutory grounds: (1) Child has been in foster care under the responsibility of the State for more than fifteen of the most recent twenty-two months; (2) Child has been out of the home for six months following the adoption of a placement plan and Father has not remedied the conditions that caused removal; and (3) Child has been out of the home and Father failed to support or visit Child for a period of six months prior to the commencement of the termination of parental rights proceedings. Â 
Child was born in 1992.Â  When Child was two, Father left the household[2] and Child continued to reside with Mother until August 29, 2002.Â  In August, when Child was almost ten years old, he was removed from Motherâ€™s custody due to allegations of physical neglect stemming from Motherâ€™s substance-abuse problems.Â  Despite his young age, Child was out late at night and Child had been charged with several incidents by law enforcement including cruelty to animals, larceny, simple assault, arson, theft from a motor vehicle, vandalism, aggravated assault, and burglary second-degree.Â  Child has been in foster care continuously since his removal.Â  At the time of Childâ€™s removal from Motherâ€™s custody, Father had violated probation by using drugs and was incarcerated at the Moss Justice Center.Â  Subsequently, he enrolled in a twenty-eight day in-patient substance abuse center.
After his release, the Department of Social Services (the Department) and Father entered into a treatment plan that required Father to (1) pay child support in the amount of $50 per month; (2) obtain suitable housing; (3) obtain employment; (4) contact Keystone to schedule an assessment for substance abuse; and (5) participate in family counseling until released by Childâ€™s therapist.
For a brief period from August 29, 2002 until March 31, 2003, Father was not incarcerated.Â  During that time, he had four visits with Child and two phone conversations.Â  After those visits, Childâ€™s behavior would regress.Â  Because of this, Childâ€™s guardian ad litem recommended that Child not visit with Father.Â  At that time the Department was not in agreement with the guardian ad litemâ€™s recommendation. Â The Department later ended Fatherâ€™s visitation privileges in March 2003 based on the recommendation of Childâ€™s therapist.
In June of 2005, the Department filed an action for termination of Fatherâ€™s parental rights.Â  During the hearing, Father testified that after he completed a substance abuse program, he again used drugs.Â  He testified he used drugs for â€œabout ten years, twenty years.â€Â  Further, Father testified that prior to Childâ€™s removal Mother had told him she wanted him to take custody of Child, and that he told Mother he first needed some time to get â€œstraight.â€Â  During this time, however, Father violated his parole by using drugs and was incarcerated.Â  He also testified that while he was not incarcerated, he was employed but did not pay child support.Â  The record shows Father made two child support payments during the entire time Child has been in the Departmentâ€™s custody.Â  Father testified that during his incarceration, after his parole was revoked for the second time, he did not seek any visitation with Child.Â  At the time of the termination hearing, Father was incarcerated and eligible for parole in November or December of 2006.
Following the hearing, the family court concluded, pursuant to section 20-7-1572 of the South Carolina Code, that termination of Fatherâ€™s parental rights was warranted under the circumstances and that such termination was in Childâ€™s best interest.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1572 (Supp. 2005).Â  Specifically, the family court found Child had been removed from Fatherâ€™s home for more than six months and Father failed to visit or support Child.Â  Additionally, the family court found Father failed to remedy the conditions that led to Childâ€™s removal; namely, he does not have a home in which to house Child and by Fatherâ€™s own admission it would take six to eight months after his release from prison before he would have a home for Child.Â  The family court noted Child had been in foster care for fifteen of the most recent twenty-two months and had been waiting three years for Father to provide a home for him, but Father has been unable to do so.Â  Moreover, the family court found that Father has not completed counseling.Â  Based on the foregoing, the family court ordered the termination of Fatherâ€™s parental rights.Â  This appeal followed.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In a termination of parental rights case, â€œthe appellate court has jurisdiction to examine the entire record to determine the facts according to its view of the evidence.â€ Â Doe v. Baby Boy Roe, 353 S.C. 576, 579, 578 S.E.2d 733, 735 (Ct. App. 2003) (citing Richland County Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Earles, 330 S.C. 24, 32, 496 S.E.2d 864, 866 (1998)).Â  In our examination, the best interest of the child is our paramount consideration.Â  Id. at 579, 578 S.E.2d at 735.Â  Additionally, the grounds for termination of parental rights must be proved by clear and convincing evidence.Â  South Carolina Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Parker, 336 S.C. 248, 254, 519 S.E.2d 351, 354 (Ct. App. 1999) (citing Greenville County Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Bowes, 313 S.C. 188, 194, 437 S.E.2d 107, 110 (1993)).Â  â€œOur broad scope of review does not require us to disregard the findings below or ignore the fact the trial judge was in a better position to assess the credibility of the witnesses.â€Â  South Carolina Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Cummings, 345 S.C. 288, 293, 547 S.E.2d 506, 509 (Ct. App. 2001) (citing Dorchester County Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Miller, 324 S.C. 445, 452, 477 S.E.2d 476, 480 (Ct. App. 1996)).
LAW/ANALYSIS
On appeal, Father argues the family court erred in terminating his parental rights.Â  He contends termination was not warranted based on the facts and circumstances of this case.Â  We disagree.
Section 20-7-1572 of the South Carolina Code governs actions for termination of parental rights in South Carolina and provides â€œ[t]he family court may order the termination of parental rights upon a finding of one or more of the [statutory] grounds and a finding that termination is in the best interest of the child . . . .â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1572 (Supp. 2005).
The family court found Child had been out of the home for six months following the adoption of a placement plan and Father had not remedied the conditions that caused the removal.Â  See id. Â§ 20-7-1572 (2) (â€œThe child has been removed from the parent . . . , has been out of the home for a period of six months following the adoption of a placement plan by court orderÂ  . . . , and the parent has not remedied the conditions which caused the removal.â€).Â  Father did not appeal this finding; therefore, it is the law of the case.Â  See South Carolina Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Seegars, 367 S.C. 623, 628 n.3, 627 S.E.2d 718, 721 n.3 (2006).Â  Therefore, as long as termination of Fatherâ€™s parental rights was also in the best interest of Child, we will uphold the family courtâ€™s order.Â  
The family court did, in fact, find terminating Fatherâ€™s parental rights was in the best interest of Child.Â  Darren Weldon, Childâ€™s caseworker at the Department, testified Child has bonded with his foster family and the family would like to adopt him.Â  Weldon testified that Child was belligerent and defiant when they first met.Â  Weldon testified Child constantly fought in school and he hung around with the wrong crowd.Â  Before the Departmentâ€™s intervention, Child developed a criminal record and had numerous incidents filed against him with the police, including a charge of cruelty to animals.Â  Weldon testified that, since Child has been in foster care, Child has stabilized, is very polite, goes to school, and shows he wants to be a productive part of society.Â  Weldon stated Child told him on numerous occasions that he does not want to be reunited with Father.Â  In addition, Childâ€™s guardian ad litem testified he believed terminating Fatherâ€™s parental rights was in Childâ€™s best interest.Â  The record fully supports the family courtâ€™s decision that the termination of Fatherâ€™s parental rights was in the best interest of Child.
The order of the family court is, therefore,
AFFIRMED.[3]
GOOLSBY, STILWELL, and SHORT, JJ., concur.

[1] Â We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2] Â Father has not lived with Child since that time.Â  Child is currently fourteen years old.
[3]Â  In light of our resolution of this case, we need not address Fatherâ€™s remaining issues.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        Jeannie Stuart, Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        William R. Stuart, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
Â R. Kinard Johnson, Jr., Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-021
Heard November 7, 2007 â€“ Filed January 12, 2007Â Â Â  

REVERSED IN PART AND AFFIRMED IN PART


  
    
      
        C. Rauch Wise and Ted Ben Wyndham, of Greenwood, for Appellant
        David Alan Wilson and T. Preston Reid, of Greenville, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  In this divorce action, William Stuart (Husband) appeals the family courtâ€™s order finding his dental practice was marital property,Â  failing to give Husband credit for payments he made on the principal of the lake house, and awarding Jeannie Stuart (Wife) attorneysâ€™ fees and $45,960 per year in alimony. Â We reverse in part and affirm in part. 
FACTS
Husband and Wife married on November 1, 1991.Â  During the marriage, the parties acquired their primary residence.Â  Husband contributed $21,000.00 of non-marital funds toward the down payment, and Wife contributed $201,000.00 of non-marital funds toward the down payment and $32,868.91 of non-marital funds toward improvements.Â  The parties also acquired a lake house during their marriage.Â  Wife paid $37,500.00 as a down payment for the lake house.Â  Husband made all the payments on both homes during the marriage.Â  These payments resulted in the principal owed on the primary residence being reduced by $50,000.00 and the principal owed on the lake house being reduced by $32,710.21.Â  Prior to the marriage, Husband established a dental practice in 1975 or 1976, and in 1988 he moved the practice to Greenville.
In June 2001, the parties separated.Â  On March 22, 2002, Wife filed a complaint seeking separate maintenance and support, equitable distribution of marital property and debts, alimony, and attorneysâ€™ fees and suit costs.Â  Later, Wife moved to amend her complaint to seek a divorce on the ground that the parties had lived separate and apart for one-year.Â  Husband consented to the amendment, and the family court granted the motion.Â  By order issued February 25, 2004, the family court granted Wife a divorce, ordered Husband to pay Wife permanent alimony in the amount of $3,830.00 per month and $7,000.00 toward Wifeâ€™s attorneysâ€™ fees, and divided the partiesâ€™ marital property and debts.Â  This appeal follows.Â Â  Â 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
On appeal from the family court, this court has the authority to find the facts in accordance with its own view of the preponderance of the evidence.Â  Rutherford v. Rutherford, 307 S.C. 199, 204, 414 S.E.2d 157, 160 (1992). We are not, however, required to disregard the findings of the family court, which saw and heard the witnesses and was in a better position to evaluate their credibility and assign comparative weight to their testimony.Â  Haselden v. Haselden, 347 S.C. 48, 58, 552 S.E.2d 329, 334 (Ct. App. 2001).
ANALYSIS
The Dental Practice
Husband claims the family court erred by declaring the dental practice to be marital property.Â  We agree.
Generally, property acquired by either party prior to the marriage is nonmarital property. Â Greene v. Greene, 351 S.C. 329, 338, 569 S.E.2d 393, 398 (Ct. App. 2002); S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-70473(2) (Supp. 2001).Â  Nonmarital property may be transmuted into marital property if: (1) it becomes so commingled with marital property as to be untraceable; (2) it is jointly titled; or (3) it is utilized by the parties in support of the marriage or in some other manner so as to evidence an intent by the parties to make it marital property. Â Pool v. Pool, 321 S.C. 84, 88, 467 S.E.2d 753, 756 (Ct. App. 1996), affâ€™d as modified, 329 S.C. 324, 494 S.E.2d 820 (1998).Â  The spouse claiming transmutation bears the burden of showing that, during the marriage, the parties themselves regarded the property as the common property of the marriage. Â Id. Â The mere use of separate property to support the marriage, without some additional evidence of intent to treat the property as marital, is not sufficient to establish transmutation. Â Id.
The evidence presented shows Husband owned the dental practice before the marriage, and the parties did not intend to treat the dental practice as marital property.Â  The family court held that Husband had started his dental practice three years before his marriage to Wife.Â  Our reading of the record reveals that Husband had been in practice for twelve to thirteen years prior to the time the family court set for the beginning of his practice.Â  We find that Husband moved his preexisting practice three years prior to his marriage to Wife.Â  Under either interpretation, it is clear that Husband owned the practice before he married Wife.Â  Husband testified that the couple never considered the dental practice to be marital property and kept their monies separate.Â  Wife presented no evidence to show there was an intent to treat the dental practice as marital property.Â  Therefore, she has failed to carry her burden and has not shown the dental practice was transmuted into marital property.Â  The dental practice should not have been considered as marital property for equitable distribution. Â Â Â Â Â 
Principal Payments for the Lake House
Husband claims the family court erred by failing to give him credit for payments made to the principal owed on the lake house when he was given credit for similar payments on the primary residence.Â  We disagree. 
The division of marital property is in the family courtâ€™s discretion and will not be disturbed absent an abuse of that discretion. Â Craig v. Craig, 365 S.C. 285, 290, 617 S.E.2d 359, 361 (2005). Â Section 20-7-472 of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2005) provides fifteen factors for the family court to consider in apportioning marital property and affords the family court with the discretion to give weight to each of these factors â€œas it finds appropriate.â€ On appeal, this court looks to the overall fairness of the apportionment, and it is irrelevant that this court might have weighed specific factors differently than the family court. Â Greene v. Greene, 351 S.C. 329, 340, 569 S.E.2d 393, 399 (Ct. App. 2002). Â Absent an abuse of discretion, the apportionment of marital property will not be disturbed on appeal. Â Deidun v. Deidun, 362 S.C. 47, 58, 606 S.E.2d 489, 495 (Ct. App. 2004).
The family court awarded Wife the primary home valued at $500,000.00 and mortgage debt of $50,000.00 for that home.Â  This resulted in a net equity of $450,000.00 to Wife.Â  The family court held that Husband should receive the $21,000.00 he put towards the down payment, the $50,000.00 by which he reduced the principal owed on the primary residence, and $72,500.00 as his share of the increase in equity exceeding his contributions.
The family court awarded Husband the partiesâ€™ interest in the lake house valued at $107,500.00 and the mortgage debt of $25,000.00 for that home.Â  This resulted in a net equity of $82,500.00 to Husband. Â The family court held that Wife should receive the $37,500.00 she contributed as the down payment and $22,500.00 as her share of the increase in equity exceeding her contributions.Â  The family court adjusted the distribution of the remaining assets to give Husband the remaining $83,500.00 ($143,500.00 Wife owed to Husband minus $60,000.00 he owed to her).Â  Next, the family court calculated the net total of the remaining assets and stated that each party should receive half of the value of the assets.Â  
Wife was awarded the primary home; therefore Husband was entitled to receive credit for the payments he had made towards the principal owed on the primary home.Â  Husband was awarded ownership of the coupleâ€™s interest in the lake house.Â  If husband was to receive an additional credit for the payments he made towards the principal owed on the lake house, he would basically be receiving a credit for a payment he made to himself.Â Â  After considering that Husband retained ownership of the coupleâ€™s interest in the lake house, it appears the family court gave each party credit for his or her contributions in a fair and equitable manner.Â  The family court did not abuse its discretion in refusing to grant Husband credit for payments he made towards the principal owed on the lake house.Â Â  Â Â Â 
Attorneysâ€™ Fees
Husband claims the family court erred by awarding Wife attorneysâ€™ fees.Â  We agree.
Attorneysâ€™ fees may be assessed against a party in an action brought in the family court. S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-420(A)(38) (Supp.2005); Patel v. Patel, 359 S.C. 515, 533, 599 S.E.2d 114, 123 (2004). The award of attorneysâ€™ fees is within the discretion of the court. Â Hailey v. Hailey, 357 S.C. 18, 31, 590 S.E.2d 495, 502 (Ct. App. 2003). The trial courtâ€™s decision regarding Â attorneysâ€™ fees will not be disturbed absent an abuse of discretion. Green v. Green, 320 S.C. 347, 353, 465 S.E.2d 130, 134 (Ct. App. 1995). 
    In deciding whether to award attorneysâ€™ fees, the family court should consider: (1) each partyâ€™s ability to pay his or her own fees; (2) the beneficial results obtained by counsel; (3) the respective financial condition of each party; and (4) the effect of the fee on each partyâ€™s standard of living. Upchurch v. Upchurch, 367 S.C. 16, 28, 624 S.E.2d 643, 648-49 (2006). 
The family court found that either party could pay his or her own attorneysâ€™ fees, and neither party would suffer a detriment to his or her standard of living if they had to pay the other partyâ€™s attorneysâ€™ fees.Â  The family court went on to award Wife attorneysâ€™ fees due to her success on the central contested issues of equitable apportionment and alimony.Â Â  Â 
Under these circumstances, we hold the family court erred in ordering Husband to pay Wifeâ€™s attorneysâ€™ fees. Â Considering the partiesâ€™ ability to pay their own fees, the partiesâ€™ respective financial conditions, and the effect of the fee on each partyâ€™s standard of living, we believe Husband and Wife should be responsible for their own attorneysâ€™ fees.Â  Furthermore, the beneficial results achieved at trial and relied on in awarding Wife attorneysâ€™ fees will be greatly reduced by the outcome of this appeal. See Doe v. Doe, 370 S.C. 206,Â Â  , 634 S.E.2d 51, 58 (Ct. App. 2006).Â  
Alimony
Husband claims the family court erred by awarding Wife $45,960.00 per year in alimony.Â  We disagree.
An award of alimony will not be disturbed absent an abuse of discretion. Â Dearybury v. Dearybury, 351 S.C. 278, 282, 569 S.E.2d 367, 369 (2002).Â  When awarding alimony, the family court considers the following thirteen factors set forth in section 20-3-130(C) (Supp.2005) of the South Carolina Code: (1) duration of the marriage; (2) physical and emotional health of the parties; (3) educational background of the parties; (4) employment history and earning potential of the parties; (5) standard of living established during the marriage; (6) current and reasonably anticipated earnings of the parties; (7) current and reasonably anticipated expenses of the parties; (8) marital and nonmarital properties of the parties; (9) custody of children; (10) marital misconduct or fault; (11) tax consequences; (12) prior support obligations; and (13) other factors the court considers relevant.
The family court stated it had weighed all of the required factors in determining the issue of alimony.Â  In making its decision, the trial court specifically mentioned Wifeâ€™s health, the tax consequences to both parties, the standard of living during marriage, Wifeâ€™s inability to obtain health insurance independently, the earnings and expenses of both parties. Â The family court considered all the applicable factors for determining the issue of alimony, and from our review of the record, we do not find the family court abused its discretion on this issue.Â  
CONCLUSION
For the reasons set forth above, we reverse the family courtâ€™s inclusion of Husbands dental practice as marital property and award of attorneysâ€™ fees to Wife, affirm the family courtâ€™s denial of credit to Husband for payments toward principal owed on the lake house, and affirm the family courtâ€™s award of alimony to Wife.Â  Accordingly, the order of the family court is Â 
REVERSED IN PART AND AFFIRMED IN PART. 
GOOLSBY, STILWELL, and SHORT, JJ., concur.

Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-022
Submitted January 1, 2007 â€“ Filed January 12, 2007Â Â Â  

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Appellate Defender Aileen P. Clare, of Columbia, for Appellant
        Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott,
        Senior Assistant Attorney General Norman Mark Rapoport, all of Columbia; and Solicitor Robert M. Ariail, of Greenville, for Respondent(s).
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: Anthony Smith appeals the trial courtâ€™s denial of his motion to dismiss the charges against him on the basis of a denial of his right to a speedy trial and the trial courtâ€™s denial of his motion to dismiss his 2005 indictments on the basis of excessive pre-indictment delay.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
Anthony Smith was arrested on September 17, 2003, for home invasion and robbery. Â On October 21, 2003, and November 18, 2003, Smith was indicted for armed robbery, first degree burglary, and possession of a weapon during the commission of a violent crime.Â  Smithâ€™s original attorney was relieved for health reasons in May 2004 and was replaced in June 2004.Â  Smith filed requests to have the charges against him dropped for failure to prosecute in April and July of 2004, and he attempted to contact the clerk of court, judge, and the solicitor about the delay in his trial.Â  On January 5, 2005, Smith was indicted for five counts of attempted armed robbery, two counts of assault and battery with intent to kill, and two counts of armed robbery.Â  Smithâ€™s original indictments and his subsequent nine indictments all arose from the same home invasion and robbery.Â  
In a pretrial hearing, Smithâ€™s attorney moved to have the charges against Smith dismissed. Â Smithâ€™s attorney argued the charges from the original indictments should be dismissed because Smith had been denied a speedy trial. Â Smithâ€™s attorney did not present any evidence of prejudice, and he simply stated it was not â€œright for someone to sit in jail 16 months for an uncomplicated case.â€ Â Smithâ€™s attorney also moved to dismiss the nine new indictments for excessive pre-indictment delay.Â  Smithâ€™s attorney argued that while â€œthe basic facts had not changedâ€ it was not right to wait â€œ16 months and then go to the grand jury for some more stuff in the same case.â€Â  The trial court denied both motions. Â This appeal followed.
LAW/ANALYSIS
Smithâ€™s did not present any evidence of prejudice, and his main complaint was the amount of time that had passed. Â Therefore, we affirm the trial courtâ€™s denial of Smithâ€™s motions.Â  See State v. Foster, 260 S.C. 511, 197 S.E.2d 280 (1973) (explaining that the length of delay is merely a triggering mechanism which brings additional factors into consideration); State v. Tyson, 283 S.C. 375, 323 S.E.2d 770 (1984) (affirming a trial judgeâ€™s denial of a speedy trial motion where there was no detriment other than the incarceration); State v. Brazell, 325 S.C. 65, 480 S.E.2d 64 (1997) (holding there was no violation of the right to a speedy trial where lack of prejudice negated the long delay and, in the context of pre-indictment delay, the defendant has the burden to show the delay caused substantial actual prejudice to his right to a fair trial). Â Therefore, the order of the trial court is 
AFFIRMED.
GOOLSBY, STILWELL, and SHORT, JJ., concur.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        Kenneth S. Pinckney, Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Robert J. Salamon, Lowcountry Chiropractic, Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
Mikell R. Scarborough, Master-In-Equity

Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-023
Submitted January 1, 2007 â€“ Filed January 12, 2007

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Kenneth S. Pinckney, of Cross, Pro Se Appellant.
        N. Keith Emge, Jr., of Charleston, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Kenneth S. Pinckney appeals the trial courtâ€™s award of summary judgment in favor of Dr. Robert J. Salamon.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
On March 11, 2003, Kenneth S. Pinckney received chiropractic treatment for lower back pain from Dr. Robert J. Salamon.Â  After leaving Dr. Salamonâ€™s office, Pinckney experienced great discomfort in his throat, wheezing, difficulty swallowing, and the loss of his voice. Â Pinckney associated the problems in his neck and throat with the care he received from Dr. Salamon, particularly a procedure that involved Pinckney turning his head from side to side while lying on an examination table.
As a result of his alleged injury, Pinckney filed a medical malpractice lawsuit against Dr. Salamon.Â  The complaint claimed Dr. Salamon was grossly negligent in the care he administered.Â  Additionally, Pinckney alleged Dr. Salamon failed to receive Pinckneyâ€™s informed consent in regard in any treatment that involved his neck and throat.
After his visit to Dr. Salamon, Pinckney saw Dr. Robert Marwick, an ear, nose and throat specialist. Â Dr. Marwick evaluated Pinckneyâ€™s condition and, although equivocal in his diagnosis, believed that Pinckney may have a fractured hyoid.Â  In his answer to interrogatories, Pinckney indicated that he intended to call Dr. Marwick as a witness. Â Shortly after the interrogatories were filed, Dr. Marwick stated in a letter to Pinckney: â€œI could not establish a causal connection between your medical condition and any treatment that you had received from a chiropractor.Â  Therefore, I will not be able to help you in your potential case as a witness.â€
Pinckney also proffered Dr. Jerald Yaden as an expert witness.Â  However, in his affidavit, Dr. Yaden stated he had no personal knowledge of the injury Pinckney allegedly sustained and that he could not testify to a reasonable degree of professional certainty that Dr. Salamonâ€™s treatment deviated from the standard of care in the field of chiropractics. Â Specifically, Dr. Yaden stated:

  I have not treated Kenneth S. Pinckney since April of 2001.
  I have no personal knowledge of the alleged injuries sustained by Mr. Pinckney in March of 2003.
  If called to testify in this matter, I could not testify to a reasonable degree of professional certainty that Dr. Salamonâ€™s treatment of Mr. Pinckney deviated from the standard of care in the chiropractic profession or that Dr. Salamonâ€™s treatment of Mr. Pinckney was most probably the cause of the injuries alleged by Mr. Pinckney.

Pinckney listed a number of other physicians who could serve as witnesses.Â  However, upon being subpoenaed, these doctors all indicated they had only treated Pinckney prior to his visit with Dr. Salamon and had no involvement with the injury at issue in this case.
Dr. Salamon moved for summary judgment, citing Pinckneyâ€™s failure to proffer expert testimony proving the standard of care had been breached and was the proximate cause of his injury.Â  The master-in-equity granted this motion, to which Pinckney now appeals.
DISCUSSION
When reviewing the grant of a summary judgment motion, this court applies the same standard which governs the trial court under Rule 56(c), SCRCP: summary judgment is proper when there is no genuine issue as to any material fact and the moving party is entitled to judgment as a matter of law.Â  Baughman v. Am. Tel & Tel. Co., 306 S.C. 101, 114-15, 410 S.E.2d 537, 545 (1991). Â The moving party may discharge the burden of demonstrating the absence of a genuine issue of material fact by pointing out the absence of evidence to support the nonmoving partyâ€™s case. Â Lanham v. Blue Cross and Blue Shield of S.C., Inc., 349 S.C. 356, 361, 563 S.E.2d 331, 333 (2002).
Although â€œthe court must view the facts and inferences therefrom in a light most favorable to the nonmoving party,â€ Bravis v. Dunbar, 316 S.C. 263, 265, 449 S.E.2d 495, 496 (Ct. App. 1994), in order to withstand a motion for summary judgment, the nonmoving party must establish specific facts showing that there is a genuine issue of material fact for trial.Â  Matsushita Elec. Indus. Co. v. Zenith Radio Corp., 475 U.S. 574, 106 S. Ct. 1348 (1986).Â  This court has previously held: 

  A party opposing a properly supported motion for summary judgment, however, may not rest on the mere allegations or denials of his pleading, but must set forth or point to specific facts showing that there is a genuine issue of material fact.Â  Thus, the existence of a mere scintilla of evidence in support of the nonmoving partyâ€™s position is not sufficient to overcome a motion for summary judgment. 

Dickert v. Metropolitan Life Ins. Co., 306 S.C. 311, 313, 411, S.E.2d 672, 673 (Ct. App. 1991) (internal citations omitted), revâ€™d in part on other grounds, 311 S.C. 218, 428 S.E.2d 700 (1993).Â  Thus, the nonmoving party cannot rest solely on its pleadings.
A physician commits malpractice by not exercising that degree of skill and learning that is ordinarily possessed and employed by members of the profession in good standing, acting in the same or similar circumstances. Durham v. Vinson, 360 S.C. 639, 650-51, 602 S.E.2d 760, 766 (2004).Â  In order to recover in a malpractice action, a plaintiff must prove: (1) a duty of care owed to the defendant by the plaintiff; (2) a breach of that duty by a negligent act or omission; and (3) damages proximately resulting from the defendantâ€™s breach. Â Â See Crolley v. Hutchins, 300 S.C. 355, 387 S.E.2d 716 (Ct. App. 1989).Â  Failure to conform to the standard of care must generally be shown by expert testimony, unless the subject matter is within common knowledge and experience.Â  Jernigan v. King, 312 S.C. 331, 440 S.E.2d 379 (Ct. App. 1993).Â  
As the standard of care owed by chiropractor for the treatment of lower back pain is not within the common knowledge, Pinckney must present expert testimony in order to establish his claim.Â  In regard to negligence, the expert must provide the duty of care owed in treating the condition and that through a negligent act or omission, Dr. Salamon breached this duty, proximately causing Pinckneyâ€™s injury.Â  Similarly, Pinckneyâ€™s claim for lack of informed consent must be proven by expert testimony establishing the professional standard for disclosure for Dr. Salamonâ€™s branch of medicine, the doctor breached that standard in regards to Pinckney, and Pinckney was harmed as a result. 
In the context of medical malpractice, South Carolina has the following burden for showing causation:

  [W]hen opinions of medical experts are relied upon to establish causal connection of negligence to injury, the proper test to be applied is that the expert must, with reasonable certainty, state that in his professional opinion the injuries complained of most probably resulted from the alleged negligence of the [defendant].

Billups v. Leliuga, 303 S.C. 36, 40, 398 S.E.2d 75, 77 (Ct. App. 1990).Â  Thus, the â€œtest for the admissibility of expert testimony on a causal connection requires the expert to state that the result most probably came from the cause alleged.â€Â  32 S.C. Juris Witness Â§ 79 (referencing Clark v. Greenville County, 313 S.C. 205, 437 S.E.2d 117 (1993)).Â  Medical expert testimony that the injury â€œpossibly,â€ â€œcould have,â€ or â€œmight haveâ€ resulted from the alleged negligence is insufficient to prove causation.Â  See Billups, 303 S.C. at 40, 398 S.E.2d at 77.
The uncontested statement of Dr. Marwick, the only physician known to have evaluated Pinckney after visiting Dr. Salamon, was that he cannot meet South Carolinaâ€™s standard for expert testimony pertaining to causation.Â  None of the other doctors Pinckney listed as experts examined him subsequent to the alleged injury.Â  Pinckney failed to proffer any expert testimony regarding a breach of the standard of care or that the breach was the proximate cause of the injury.Â  As a result, there are no genuine issues of material fact as to his causes of action.Â  Because the issue discussed is dispositive, we need not address any other issues.
CONCLUSION 
Accordingly, the grant of summary judgment is 
AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON, HUFF, and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        The State, Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Samuel Simmons, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Horry County
Â Steven H. John, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-024
Submitted January 1, 2007 â€“ Filed January 17, 2007

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Chief Attorney Joseph L. Savitz, III, of Columbia, for Appellant.
        Attorney General Henry D. McMaster; Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh; Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott; Assistant Attorney General Shawn L. Reeves, all of Columbia; and Solicitor J. Gregory Hembree, of Conway; for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Appellant, Samuel Simmons, was indicted for and convicted of armed robbery, assault and battery with intent to kill, grand larceny and criminal conspiracy.Â  Simmons appeals, asserting the trial court erred in overruling his Batson[1] motion.Â  We affirm.[2]
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
During jury selection, the State exercised five peremptory challenges.Â  Simmons made a Batson motion, challenging the striking of three of those jurors:Â  numbers 92, 36, and 55.Â  The trial court explained to defense counsel following his request for a hearing on the matter that the solicitor was required to present a race or gender neutral explanation for each strike and, if the court found the explanation to be race or gender neutral, it would then look to defense counsel for an explanation as to why it was a racially based strike that was mere pretense. Â 
The solicitor explained juror number 92 and juror number 36 both had criminal convictions.Â  As to number 55, he stated as follows:

  Juror number 55 was the one that stood up there for a good while I looked over at Ms. Canteen to try to get a signal which I apparently misinterpreted as a strike.Â  She tells me that she was giving me an okay which is not a thumbs up or an okay.Â  But a different signal I interpreted to be a strike.Â  So I struck him because I thought that Ms. Canteen in my office was saying that he would not make a good juror.
  I do not have any other reason because obviously she didnâ€™t have a reason.Â  I only have her as my reason.

In response, defense counsel stated he would like to put on the record that, in regard to those three jurors, the solicitor looked over at Ms. Canteen, a member of the solicitorâ€™s office, as well as at law enforcement officer Lieutenant Grayson.Â  He also requested, and was provided, corroboration of the convictions of jurors 92 and 36.Â  
The trial court found the criminal charges were race neutral explanations.Â  When the court asked counsel if he had any further argument, he replied, â€œNo, sir, Your Honor.Â  And to clarify number 55 is the one that the solicitor said that he took the wrong hand signal I believe.â€Â  The trial judge confirmed this statement, and counsel stated he had â€œno further objections to the jury.â€Â  The trial court then put the following on the record:

  Based upon that . . . I do not find that the explanation though there was a mistake or an error by the solicitorâ€™s office in number 55, that it is not an error that was grounded in the jurorâ€™s race.Â  I do find that it was merely a common error or mistake by the solicitorâ€™s office.Â  Itâ€™s certain[ly] not a mere [pretextual] argument or reason and certainly do not find that for the other two.Â  Therefore your Batson motion is denied.Â  You have any other arguments?

Counsel responded that he had no other argument on the matter, and the trial went forward.Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
On appeal, Simmons asserts the trial court erroneously denied his Batson motion as to the juror struck based on the misinterpreted hand signal.Â  He argues the State, as the proponent of the strike, was required to offer a facially race-neutral explanation for the strike and failed to do so in this instance because the State may not meet its burden by merely asserting a third person made the decision to strike and communicated this decision to the solicitor.
â€œThe Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution prohibits the striking of a venire person on the basis of race or gender.â€Â  State v. Shuler, 344 S.C. 604, 615, 545 S.E.2d 805, 810 (2001).Â  â€œâ€˜The purposes of Batson and its progeny are to protect the defendantâ€™s right to a fair trial by a jury of the defendantâ€™s peers, protect each venirepersonâ€™s right not to be excluded from jury service for discriminatory reasons, and preserve public confidence in the fairness of our system of justice by seeking to eradicate discrimination in the jury selection process.â€™â€Â Â Â  State v. Rayfield, 369 S.C. 106, ___, 631 S.E.2d 244, 247 (2006) (quoting State v. Haigler, 334 S.C. 623, 628-29, 515 S.E.2d 88, 90 (1999)).Â  â€œBoth the State and defendants are prohibited from discriminatorily exercising a peremptory challenge of a prospective juror.â€Â  Id.Â Â  When a party strikes a member of a cognizable racial group or gender and an opposing party requests a Batson hearing, the trial court must hold one.Â  Shuler, 344 S.C. at 615, 545 S.E.2d at 810.
In State v. Adams, 322 S.C. 114, 470 S.E.2d 366 (1996) (citing Purkett v. Elem, 514 U.S. 765 (1995)), our supreme court set forth the proper procedure for a Batson hearing.

  After a party objects to a jury strike, the proponent of the strike must offer a facially race-neutral explanation.Â  Â  This explanation is not required to be persuasive or even plausible.Â  Once the proponent states a reason that is race-neutral, the burden is on the party challenging the strike to show the explanation is mere pretext, either by showing similarly situated members of another race were seated on the jury or the reason given for the strike is so fundamentally implausible as to constitute mere pretext despite a lack of disparate treatment.

Rayfield, 369 S.C. at ___, 631 S.E.2d at 247 (citing Adams, 322 S.C. at 123-24, 470 S.E.2d at 371-72; State v. Haigler, 334 S.C. 623, 629-30, 515 S.E.2d 88, 90-91 (1999)).Â  â€œIt is important to note that the â€˜proponent of the peremptory challenges will not have any burden of presenting reasonably specific, legitimate explanations for the strikes.Â  Instead, [he or she] need only present racially neutral explanations.â€™â€Â  State v. Flynn, 368 S.C. 83, 86, 627 S.E.2d 763, 765 (Ct. App. 2006) (quoting Adams, 322 S.C. at 123-24, 470 S.E.2d at 371).Â  Additionally, the burden of persuading the trial court that a Batson violation has occurred remains at all times on the opponent of the strike.Â  State v. Haigler, 334 S.C. 623, 629, 515 S.E.2d 88, 91(1999).
 â€œIn deciding whether the opponent of a strike has carried the burden of persuasion, a court must undertake a sensitive inquiry into the circumstantial and direct evidence of intent.â€Â  Id. Â Â â€œThe trial judgeâ€™s findings of purposeful discrimination rest largely on his evaluation of demeanor and credibility.â€Â  Shuler, 344 S.C. at 615, 545 S.E.2d at 810.Â  â€œOften the demeanor of the challenged attorney will be the best and only evidence of discrimination, and â€˜evaluation of the prosecutorâ€™s mind lies peculiarly within a trial judgeâ€™s province.â€™â€ Â Id. at 615-16, 545 S.E.2d at 810 (citing Hernandez v. New York, 500 U.S. 352, 365, 111 S.Ct. 1859, 114 L.Ed.2d 395 (1991)).Â Â  The trial courtâ€™s findings in regard to whether there was purposeful discrimination are accorded great deference and such a determination will be set aside on appeal only if clearly erroneous. Haigler, 334 S.C. at 630, 515 S.E.2d at 91.
Simmons, relying on the case of State v. Marble, 311 S.C. 23, 426 S.E.2d 744 (1992), argues the State, as the proponent of the strike, failed to offer a facially race-neutral explanation for the strike, because the State may not meet such a burden by asserting a third party made the decision to strike and then communicated that decision to the solicitor.Â  In Marble, our supreme court, relying on its recent decision in State v. Adams, 307 S.C. 368, 415 S.E.2d 402 (1992), held the State may not meet its burden under Batson by merely asserting that a third person made the decision to strike and communicated this decision to the Solicitor.Â  Both Marble and Adams, however, were interpreted under the previous case law that required the State to give a clear and reasonably specific explanation for its strike in the second step of the Batson procedure.Â  Marble, 311 S.C. at 24, 426 S.E.2d at 745;Â  Adams, 307 S.C. at 370, 415 S.E.2d at 403.Â  As previously noted, our law now mandates that the proponent of the strike no longer has any burden of presenting reasonably specific, legitimate explanations for the strikes, but need only present racially neutral explanations.Â  State v. Flynn, 368 S.C. 83, 86, 627 S.E.2d 763, 765 (Ct. App. 2006).Â  Further, both Marble and Adams noted the â€œclear and reasonably specific explanationâ€ offered by the third person must be provided because, without this requirement, there would be no assurance that the third person did not make the decision based on the jurorâ€™s race.Â  Marble, 311 S.C. at 24, 426 S.E.2d at 745; Adams, 307 S.C. at 370, 415 S.E.2d at 403.Â  Here, the explanation offered was not that the solicitor relied on the unexplained and unchallengeable reason of a third party, but that he mistakenly interpreted the signal of an employee in his office who was assisting him in jury selection.Â  Because the third person in this case had, in fact, indicated that the solicitor should not strike the juror, there is assurance that the decision was not made by the third person based on the jurorâ€™s race.Â  In other words, there could be no purposeful discrimination based on the jurorâ€™s race by the third person, as she indicated that this juror should be selected by the solicitor, not struck.Â  Â Â Â Â Â 
In the case at hand, the solicitor offered as a race-neutral explanation for striking juror number 55 that he had misinterpreted a signal from an employee in his office, representing that the strike of this juror was an inadvertent mistake.Â  The trial court accepted the explanation that it was merely an error on the part of the solicitor.Â  Mindful that the demeanor of the challenged attorney is often the best and only evidence of discrimination,Â  that the evaluation of that attorneyâ€™s mind lies peculiarly within a trial judgeâ€™s province, and that the trial courtâ€™s findings in regard to whether there was purposeful discrimination are accorded such great deference, we hold the trial courtâ€™s determination that the strike was race-neutral was not clearly erroneous.Â  See State v. Casey, 325 S.C. 447, 481 S.E.2d 169 (Ct. App. 1997) (wherein this court held, although the solicitor did not challenge a female venire member with prior jury service yet struck the male juror with prior service, and thus the reason for striking the juror was applied inconsistently, the Stateâ€™s explanation that it was merely an omission and mistake on its part was gender-neutral).Â  Once the State provided a race-neutral reason, it was incumbent upon Simmons, as the opponent of the strike, to show the explanation was mere pretext. Simmons offered no evidence of pretext, and clearly failed to meet his burden.
For the foregoing reasons, Simmonsâ€™ convictions areÂ Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Â Â Â Â  
AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON, HUFF, and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

[1] Batson v. Kentucky, 476 U.S. 79 (1986). 
[2] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        The State, Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Corey Moss, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
Â C. Victor Pyle, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-025
Submitted January 1, 2007 â€“ Filed January 17, 2007

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Assistant Appellate Defender Aileen P. Clare, of Columbia, for Appellant.
        Attorney General Henry D. McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Assistant Attorney General Shawn L. Reeves, all of Columbia; and Solicitor Robert M. Ariail, of Greenville, for Respondent.
      
    
  


PER CURIAM:Â  Appellant, Corey Moss, was indicted for and convicted of distribution of crack cocaine and distribution of crack cocaine within close proximity of a school.Â  Moss appeals, asserting the trial court erred in ruling the photographic lineup used to identify him was not suggestive.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
On May 27, 2003, around 4:15 in the afternoon, Officer Patrick Brown posed as a construction worker while working an undercover operation in the Cotton Street area of the city of Greenville.Â  Officer Brown slowed his vehicle as he drove past three black males and heard someone yell for him to turn around and come back.Â  The man yelling was a black male, wearing a white t-shirt, baggy jeans and white shoes with red writing.Â  When Officer Brown drove back up, the man asked him what he wanted.Â  The officer told him he wanted â€œtwenty of that hard,â€ which is street slang for a single hit of crack cocaine.Â  The man gave Officer Brown a beige rocklike substance in exchange for $20.Â  Looking in his rear view mirror, he observed the man walk into a house at 5 Cotton Street.Â  As the officer drove away, he gave detectives Lawson and White a physical description of the suspect through some surveillance equipment.Â  He described the subject as a black male, about 5â€™6â€™â€™ or 5â€™7â€, around 150 pounds, wearing a white t-shirt, baggy denim jeans, and white tennis shoes with red writing.Â  
Detective Melissa Lawson testified she was in the area of the controlled buy and could hear the transaction take place over audio.Â  She corroborated the conversation between Officer Brown and the other party, as well as the description that was given by Officer Brown.Â  After having Officer Brown confirm the description of the suspect, Detective Lawson contacted Corporal Aiken, the community patrol officer for that area, and gave him the description and the location of the purchase.Â  Corporal Aiken testified, after receiving the description and the area of the transaction, along with the fact that the suspect went to 5 Cotton Street when he left, he immediately told Detective Lawson that Corey Moss fit the description.Â  He stated Moss was the only individual in that area that fit that description, Mossâ€™ aunt lived at 5 Cotton Street, and Moss did hang out there often.Â  After getting a clothing description, Corporal Aiken went to the area and observed Moss walking about fifty yards from where the transaction had occurred.Â  Moss was wearing a white t-shirt, baggy blue jeans, and white tennis shoes with red marking.Â  
After Corporal Aiken told her the description fit Corey Moss, Detective Lawson obtained a computer-generated photo array which included Mossâ€™ picture along with five other males with similar characteristics.Â  The pictures were randomly placed in one of six slots.Â  Approximately three to three and a half hours after the purchase, Detective Lawson showed Officer Brown the photo array, telling him the person who sold him crack cocaine may or may not be in the array.Â  She stated Officer Brown immediately picked out Moss.
Officer Brown testified the individuals in the array were all black males with the same complexion, with similar hair, and about the same age.Â  He stated he was face to face with the seller, they were close to one another, they were on eye level, he made conversation and eye contact with him, and he got a very good look at the personâ€™s face.Â  Further, Officer Brown indicated he was paying close attention to the individual as he was trained to do, so he could give a good description of him. Â Detective Lawson informed him it was a random photo array which may or may not include the subject.Â  Detective Lawson did not indicate or tell Officer Brown which picture he should select.Â  Officer Brown stated he did not have to study the array, and that he recognized Moss â€œright off the bat.â€Â  He testified he was â€œa hundred percent positive thatâ€™s the guy.â€Â  
Prior to trial Moss moved to â€œdismiss the warrant and quash the indictmentâ€ based on an alleged improper identification procedure.Â  The trial court then held a hearing concerning the lineup.Â  After hearing Officer Brownâ€™s testimony and reviewing the photo array, the trial court found â€œnothing at all suggestive in [the] lineupâ€ and denied Mossâ€™ motion to quash, noting because the lineup was not suggestive, it need not review the factors set forth in Neil v. Biggers, 409 U.S. 188 (1972). 
LAW/ANALYSIS
On appeal, appellant argues the trial court erred in finding the photographic lineup was not suggestive. Â He asserts the lineup was unduly suggestive as (1) his photograph was the first one in the six-picture array, (2) he was the only subject directly facing the camera as all the others were tilting their heads to the viewerâ€™s right, and (3) the other subjects were more brightly lit than he.Â  Moss thus contends the lineup and resulting identification should have been suppressed.Â  
â€œA criminal defendant may be deprived of due process of law by an identification procedure which is unnecessarily suggestive and conducive to irreparable mistaken identification.â€Â  State v. Traylor, 360 S.C. 74, 81, 600 S.E.2d 523, 526 (2004).Â  If a suggestive out-of-court identification procedure created a very substantial likelihood of irreparable misidentification, an in-court identification of the accused is inadmissible.Â  Id.Â  â€œThe United States Supreme Court has developed a two-prong inquiry to determine the admissibility of an out-of-court identification.â€Â  Id.Â  (citing Neil v. Biggers, 409 U.S. 188 (1972)).Â  First, the trial court must ascertain whether the identification process was unduly suggestive.Â  State v. Moore, 343 S.C. 282, 287, 540 S.E.2d 445, 447 (2000).Â  Next, the trial court must decide whether the out-of-court identification was nevertheless so reliable that no substantial likelihood of misidentification existed.Â  Id. 
Even if the identification procedure is unduly suggestive, it need not be excluded so long as, under all the circumstances, the identification was reliable notwithstanding the suggestiveness.Â  Traylor, 360 S.C. at 82, 600 S.E.2d at 527.Â  Rather, the inquiry then focuses on whether, under the totality of the circumstances, there was a substantial likelihood of irreparable misidentification.Â  Id.Â  In evaluating the totality of the circumstances to determine the likelihood of misidentification, the following factors should be considered:Â  (1) the witnessâ€™s opportunity to view the perpetrator at the time of the crime, (2) the witnessâ€™s degree of attention, (3) the accuracy of the witnessâ€™s prior description of the perpetrator, (4) the level of certainty demonstrated by the witness at the confrontation, and (5) the length of time between the crime and the confrontation. Â State v. Cheeseboro, 346 S.C. 526, 541, 552 S.E.2d 300, 308 (2001).Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 
We first note Moss never moved to suppress the identification evidence.Â  Rather, Moss moved to quash the indictment and dismiss the warrant based on the allegedly improper identification procedure. Â Undoubtedly, Moss is challenging on appeal the admissibility of evidence, not the sufficiency of the indictment or any constitutional basis for quashing the indictment.Â  Â Additionally, Moss failed to object to any of the testimony concerning Officer Brownâ€™s identification of him or the admission of the photo array into evidence.Â  It is thus questionable whether appellant has properly preserved this argument for our review. See State v. Nichols, 325 S.C. 111, 120-21, 481 S.E.2d 118, 123 (1997)Â  (â€œAn issue may not be raised for the first time on appeal, but must have been raised to the trial judge to be preserved for appellate review.â€);Â  State v. Simpson 325 S.C. 37, 42, 479 S.E.2d 57, 60 (1996) (holding, where appellantâ€™s counsel did not make any objections during the testimony, issue of admissibility of evidence was not preserved for appellate review as a ruling in limine is not a final ruling on the admissibility of evidence and unless an objection is made at the time the evidence is offered and a final ruling made, the issue is not preserved for review).Â Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 
In spite of trial counselâ€™s motion being one to quash the indictment rather than suppress the evidence, it is clear the trial court held a â€œhearing concerning the lineup,â€ and essentially ruled on the admissibility of the evidence, determining the lineup was not suggestive and the court therefore need not continue evaluation with the Neil v. Biggers factors.Â  Additionally, Officer Brown was the first witness to testify following the courtâ€™s ruling on the lineup.Â  State v. Bowman, 366 S.C. 485, 500-01, 623 S.E.2d 378, 386 (2005) (noting an exception to the rule requiring a contemporaneous objection when evidence is introduced exists where a judge makes an in limine ruling on the admission of evidence on the record immediately prior to the introduction of the evidence in question). 
However, turning to the merits, we find no error in the trial courtâ€™s determination that the photographic lineup was not suggestive.Â  First, the only argument Moss raised to the trial court in arguing the lineup was unduly suggestive was that his picture was the first picture in the photographic array.Â  He never argued to the trial court, as he does on appeal, that he was the only subject directly facing the camera and the other subjects were more brightly lit.Â  See State v. Shuler, 353 S.C. 176, 187, 577 S.E.2d 438, 443 (2003) ( a party cannot raise one basis in support of a motion at trial and another on appeal).Â  Further, the record shows that the photo array was computer generated, with the individual photographs randomly placed into one of six places.Â  We decline to find the mere fact that a defendantâ€™s photograph is the first one in a photo array renders such a lineup impermissibly suggestive, especially as here, where the order of the photos is randomly selected by computer.Â  See White v. State, 187 Ga. App. 301, 302, 370 S.E.2d 50, 51 (1988) (finding photographic lineup was not impermissibly suggestive where appellantâ€™s picture was â€œ in the front and center position in the photo arrayâ€).Â  Additionally, we have viewed the lineup in question and agree with the trial court that there is simply nothing suggestive about the lineup.Â  As in this courtâ€™s decision in State v. Patterson, 337 S.C. 215, 230, 522 S.E.2d 845, 852 (Ct. App. 1999), none of the six photographs in the lineup stand out from the others.Â  They are of comparable size and composition, with each subject being similar in appearance, age and physical characteristics.Â  As well, the record shows Detective Lawson did not suggest to Officer Brown which photograph was of the suspect. 
Finally, even if the lineup were unduly suggestive, Officer Brownâ€™s identification of Moss was clearly reliable in light of the totality of the circumstances. Â Â First, insofar as the witnessâ€™s opportunity to observe the individual at the time of the crime, Officer Brown testified he was on eye level and face to face with the seller, they were close to one another, he made conversation and eye contact with him, and he got a very good look at the personâ€™s face.Â  Further, Officer Brown stated he was paying close attention to the individual as he was trained to do, so he could give a good description of him. Â Based on Officer Brownâ€™s description, Corporal Aiken shortly thereafter traveled to the area and observed Moss walking about fifty yards from where the transaction had occurred wearing a white t-shirt, baggy blue jeans, and white tennis shoes with red marking, just as Officer Brown had described.Â  Officer Brown testified that he recognized Moss â€œright off the batâ€ and Detective Lawson corroborated Officer Brown immediately picked out Moss.Â  Â Officer Brown further indicated he was â€œa hundred percent positiveâ€ Moss was the individual who had sold him the crack cocaine.Â  Finally, Officer Brown made the identification of Moss only three to three and a half hours after the purchase.
CONCLUSION
We hold the identification procedure used in this case was not unduly suggestive.Â  We further hold, even if the lineup were suggestive, Officer Brownâ€™s pre-trial identification of Moss was reliable in light of the totality of the circumstances. Â For the foregoing reasons, appellantâ€™s convictions are
AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON, HUFF, and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
