THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        South Carolina Department of Social Services, Respondent,
        v.
        Georgia B., Willie R., Marcus B., and B. R., DOB: 03/09/02Â  D. B., DOB: 12/22/00, Defendants, of whom Willie R. is Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Aiken County
Â Dale Moore Gable, Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-044
Submitted December 1, 2006 â€“ Filed January 24, 2007

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Amy Patterson Shumpert and Clarke W. McCants, III, both of Aiken, for Appellant.
        Dennis M. Gmerek, of Aiken, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: Willie R. (Father) appeals the termination of his parental rights (TPR) to B.R. (Child).Â  Georgia B. (Mother) was also a defendant in the underlying TPR action but does not join in this appeal. Â Specifically, Father contends the family court erred in granting TPR because the South Carolina Department of Social Services (DSS) failed to prove by clear and convincing evidence that Father did not remedy the conditions which caused the removal of Child, and the court improperly allowed evidence regarding Motherâ€™s criminal history and prior involvement with DSS.[1]Â  We affirm.[2]
FACTS
In February 2003, DSS initiated an investigation surrounding the care of Child.Â  At the time of DSSâ€™s investigation, Father was in prison for driving under suspension and Mother was the sole caregiver for Child; Mother and Father (collectively, Parents) have never been married.Â  DSS determined Child had been abandoned and subjected to physical neglect.Â  DSS removed Child from Motherâ€™s care and placed Child in foster care.Â  Â Â 
In April 2003, DSS and Parents entered into a consent order for removal which placed custody of Child with DSS.Â  In addition, the order approved a treatment plan for Parents.Â  Father was ordered to: (1) successfully complete parenting classes; (2) successfully complete an alcohol/drug treatment program; (3) complete a psychological evaluation; (4) visit his daughter regularly; and (5) provide financial support for his daughter.Â  In addition, Father was instructed to â€œobtain and maintain safe housing and employment for at least six consecutive months.â€Â Â Â  
Initially, Father made steady progress under the treatment plan.Â Â  Specifically, Father completed parenting classes, completed a psychological evaluation, obtained housing, obtained employment, and enrolled in an alcohol/drug treatment program.Â  However, Father only submitted to fifteen out of twenty-seven requested drug screens and tested positive for alcohol on one test.Â Â Â  
In October 2003, prior to a Judicial Review hearing, DSS and Parents entered into another consent order.Â  The consent order amended Fatherâ€™s treatment plan to require Father to: (1) refrain from the use of alcohol; and (2) â€œdevelop a specific plan for transportation of [Child] to and from medical appointments and therapy sessions.â€Â  The order also provided that all adults living in Fatherâ€™s home must submit to drug screens and background checks.Â Â  
In February 2004, the family court issued an order granting a six month extension for reunification to allow Parents to work on their treatment plans. Â The order provides â€œ[i]t is clearly not in [Childâ€™s] best interests for SCDSS to initiate termination of parental rights at this time because [Parents] have made some progress towards removing risk of harm to [Child].â€ Â However, the order also notes Father has yet to provide a plan for transportation of Child to her medical appointments, to maintain a stable home, or to secure adequate housing for Child.Â  In addition, the order notes concerns about Fatherâ€™s â€œalcohol environment.â€Â  The order amends the treatment plan to require Father to submit to drug screens three times a week.Â Â Â  Â Â Â 
In June 2004, the family court held a permanency planning hearing.Â  The court found Father â€œhas not provided drug screens as requestedâ€ and â€œhas not been able to provide transportation for [Child] for her therapy appointments.â€Â  Therefore, the Court held Child should not be returned to Father â€œbecause it would cause an unreasonable risk of harm to childâ€™s life, physical health or safety, or mental well-being . . . .â€Â  The court authorized DSS to pursue TPR.Â Â Â  Â 
DSS initiated the present TPR action in August 2004, and a TPR hearing was held in September 2005.Â  At trial, DSS presented testimony Father did not appear for all of his drug screenings, Father only attended four of Childâ€™s weekly therapy sessions in over two years, and Child has been in Foster care for about thirty (30) months.Â  In addition, witnesses testified Child suffered from Fetal Alcohol Syndrome and was developmentally delayed but was making tremendous progress at her therapy sessions.Â  Also, over objection, DSS introduced testimony regarding the termination of Motherâ€™s parental rights as to three other children and Motherâ€™s criminal record.Â Â Â  
On September 23, 2005, the family court issued an order terminating Fatherâ€™s parental rights on the grounds that: (1) Child has lived outside of the home for a period of at least six (6) months; (2) Father failed to remedy the conditions which caused the removal of Child or to rehabilitate; (3) Child has been in foster care for fifteen of the last twenty-two months; and (4) Father failed to supply Child with the appropriate health care and it is unlikely that the home can be made safe within twelve months.Â  In addition, the court found TPR was in Childâ€™s best interest.Â  This appeal followed.Â Â Â Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In a TPR case, the best interest of the child is the paramount consideration.Â  Doe v. Baby Boy Roe, 353 S.C. 576, 579, 578 S.E.2d 733, 735 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  â€œThe interests of the child shall prevail if the childâ€™s interest and the parental rights conflict.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1578 (Supp. 2005).Â  Before parental rights can be forever terminated, the alleged grounds for the termination must be proven by clear and convincing evidence.Â  S.C. Dept. of Social Services v. Headden, 354 S.C. 602, 608-09, 582 S.E.2d 419, 423 (2003). Â 
On appeal, this court may review the record and make its own determination whether the grounds for termination are supported by clear and convincing evidence.Â  S.C. Dept. of Social Services v. Cummings, 345 S.C. 288, 293, 547 S.E.2d 506, 509 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  Despite this broad scope of review, however, we are not required to disregard the findings of the family court, and we note the family court is in a better position to evaluate the credibility of the witnesses and assign weight to their testimony.Â  Hooper v. Rockwell, 334 S.C. 281, 297, 513 S.E.2d 358, 367 (1999).
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.  Remedy Conditions Causing Removal
Father argues the family court erred in granting TPR because DSS failed to prove by clear and convincing evidence Father has not remedied the conditions which caused the removal of Child.Â  We affirm on other grounds.Â  
Pursuant to section 20-7-1572 of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2005), the family court may terminate parental rights upon finding at least one of eleven statutory grounds has been met and that termination is in the best interest of the child.Â  The paramount consideration in a TPR case is the best interests of the child or children.Â  S.C. Dept. of Social Services v. Richardson, 298 S.C. 130, 133, 378 S.E.2d 601, 603 (Ct. App. 1989). Â Â Â 
The record indicates statutory grounds for termination exist.Â  Section 20-7-1572(8) of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2005) allows for TPR when â€œthe child has been in foster care under the responsibility of the State for fifteen of the most recent twenty-two months.â€Â  On February 26, 2003, Child was taken into protective custody.Â  In April of 2003, Parents signed a consent order to place custody of Child with DSS, and the hearing to terminate Fatherâ€™s parental rights was held in September of 2005.Â  Child had been the responsibility of the state for the entire duration of this process.Â  The family court found that at the time of the termination hearing, Child had been in foster care for thirty-two consecutive months.
The evidence also demonstrates the termination of Fatherâ€™s parental rights is in the best interests of Child.Â  Childâ€™s foster mother intends to adopt Child and has demonstrated the ability to provide quality care for Child.Â  Moreover, paramount to Childâ€™s successful development is both the Childâ€™s and her parentâ€™s attendance at Childâ€™s weekly therapy sessions.Â  The foster mother has demonstrated a commitment and ability to attend Childâ€™s sessions, whereas Father has only attended four sessions in over two years.Â  Father even testified, â€œI wouldnâ€™t have a job if I visited [Child] every week.â€Â  Finally, the guardian ad litem, Childâ€™s therapist, and DSS case workers all opined the termination of Fatherâ€™s parental rights is in Childâ€™s best interest.Â Â Â  
Father does not appeal from the family courtâ€™s finding concerning the duration of foster care, and we find this to be an independent grounds upon which his parental rights may be terminated.Â  See Doe v. Baby Boy Roe, 353 S.C. 576, 581, 578 S.E.2d 733, 736 (Ct. App. 2003) (holding that parental rights can be terminated once a child has languished in foster care for fifteen out of the last twenty-two months and the family court finds termination is in the childâ€™s best interest).Â  We find the family courtâ€™s decision to terminate Fatherâ€™s parental rights on the grounds that Child was in foster care under the responsibility of the State for fifteen of the most recent twenty-two months was in the best interest of Child.Â  Therefore, we affirm the termination and need not address the merits of Fatherâ€™s remediation argument.Â  
II.  Admission of Evidence 
Father next contends the family court erred in allowing testimony regarding the termination of Motherâ€™s parental rights to three other children and Motherâ€™s prior convictions.Â  We disagree. 
Generally, all relevant evidence is admissible.Â  Rule 402, SCRE; Moore v. Moore, 360 S.C. 241, 258, 599 S.E.2d 467, 476 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  However, relevant evidence may be excluded when its probative value is substantially outweighed by the danger of unfair prejudice.Â  Rule 403, SCRE; Moore, 360 S.C. at 258, 599 S.E.2d at 476.Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â 
The admission of evidence is within the trial courtâ€™s discretion.Â  Gamble v. Intâ€™l Paper Realty Corp. of S.C., 323 S.C. 367, 373, 474 S.E.2d 438, 441 (1996).Â  The courtâ€™s ruling to admit or exclude evidence will only be reversed if it constitutes a clear abuse of discretion.Â  Id.Â  â€œAn abuse of discretion occurs when the ruling is based on an error of law or a factual conclusion without evidentiary support.â€ Vaught v. A.O. Hardee & Sons, Inc.,Â  366 S.C. 475, 480, 623 S.E.2d 373, 375 (2005). 
The family court did not commit an abuse of discretion in allowing testimony about either the termination of Motherâ€™s parental rights to three other children or Motherâ€™s past convictions.Â  Father and Mother were living together at the time of the TPR hearing.Â  Therefore, Motherâ€™s recurring problems with the law and her recurring problems with childcare are certainly relevant in determining whether Childâ€™s best interests are served by remaining with her foster mother or moving in with Father.Â  In addition, Father is not unfairly prejudiced by the introduction of this evidence because the evidence is highly relevant.Â  Therefore, the family court did not err in allowing testimony regarding either Motherâ€™s prior involvement with DSS or Motherâ€™s prior convictions.Â  
CONCLUSION
Based on the foregoing, the family court did not err in terminating Fatherâ€™s parental rights to Child.Â  The decision of the family court is accordingly 
AFFIRMED. 
HEARN, C.J., BEATTY, and SHORT, JJ., concur.

[1] The underlying action involved the termination of Motherâ€™s parental rights to another of her minor children unrelated to Father.Â  The orders throughout this action involve both minor children.Â  However, because the present appeal only involves Fatherâ€™s rights to Child, any reference to Motherâ€™s other child is omitted. 
[2] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

v.
Charleston County School District, Respondent.

R. Markley Dennis, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2007-UP-046
Submitted January 1, 2007 â€“ Filed January 26, 2007

Deena Smith McRackan, of Charleston, for Appellant. 
Alice F. Paylor and Andrew D. Gowdown, both of Charleston, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  George Mack appeals his dismissal from his position as a social studies teacher at Brentwood Middle School in the Charleston County School District.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
In 2004, as a result of unsatisfactory evaluations,[2] the Associate Superintendent for Constituent District No. 4 recommended Mackâ€™s continuing contract not be renewed for the 2004-2005 school year.Â  Mack appealed the recommendation to the District 4 Board of Trustees.Â  The board issued an order on June 4 directing that Mack be offered a contract, but was to demonstrate, â€œduring the first ninety days of the school year, proficiency in the areas required by the Districtâ€™s formal evaluation process.â€Â  The order further stated that â€œduring the first ninety (90) days, the administration at Brentwood Middle School shall make certain that no less than four (4) period long evaluations are conducted of Mr. Mack and shall assess that he is proficient in all areas required by the formal evaluation process.â€Â  
The 2004-2005 school year began on August 9.Â  Edwin Jones, principal of Brentwood Middle School at the time, observed a portion of one of Mackâ€™s social studies classes on September 30 and October 5.Â  He observed entire class periods on October 20 and December 8.Â  Jean Siewicki, a long-time educator in the District, also observed Mack for two class periods on November 9 and December 14.Â  According to both Jones and Siewicki, Mackâ€™s performance was unsatisfactory.Â  In their opinions Mack failed to communicate high expectations for his students, did not engage students in critical thinking, did not sequence the content of his material in a logical fashion, lacked long and short-term planning skills, and exhibited poor classroom management, particularly in the area of student discipline.Â  Based upon these unsatisfactory evaluations, Mack was terminated.Â  He appealed his termination to members of the District 4 Board who concluded â€œthe administration ha[d] presented substantial evidence that Mr. Mack has failed to satisfactorily perform his duties and responsibilities as a teacher.â€Â  The Charleston County School District Board and the circuit court agreed and upheld the decision to terminate Mack.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
 The standard applicable to judicial review of a school board decision is limited to a determination of whether the decision is supported by substantial evidence.Â  Laws v. Richland County Sch. Dist. No. 1, 270 S.C. 492, 495, 243 S.E.2d 192, 193 (1978).Â  Substantial evidence is evidence which, considering the record as a whole, would allow reasonable minds to reach the conclusion the board reached or must have reached in order to justify its action.Â  Id. at 495-96, 243 S.E.2d at 193.
LAW/ANALYSIS
Mack raises two issues on appeal.Â  First, he argues that the evaluation requirements in the June 4 order did not comply with state laws and regulations or with school district policy so that the termination of his employment based on the resulting assessments constitutes an error of law.Â  The circuit courtâ€™s order does not address any procedural violations, and there is no Rule 59(e) motion in the record seeking a ruling on that issue.Â  It appears this precise issue is raised for the first time on appeal to this court.Â  Consequently, it is not preserved for our review.Â  See Wilder Corp. v. Wilke, 330 S.C. 71, 76, 497 S.E.2d 731, 733 (1998) (â€œIt is axiomatic that an issue cannot be raised for the first time on appeal, but must have been raised to and ruled upon by the trial judge to be preserved for appellate review.â€).

 Secondly, assuming the evaluation process outlined in the June 4 order was valid, Mack contends that process was not followed, and the resulting assessments therefore cannot serve as the basis for his termination.Â  The preservation of this argument is somewhat suspect as well.Â  Nevertheless even on the merits, Mackâ€™s argument is unpersuasive.Â  Mack argues that the evaluations were not performed within the proscribed ninety-day period and did not include four period-long evaluations.Â  According to the record before us, it appears that November 7 marked the end of the ninety-day period in which Mack was to be evaluated.Â  If so, three of the observations fell within the ninety-day period, and three of the observations, November 9, December 8, and December 14, were conducted beyond this period.Â  The evaluators testified that four of the six observations were for a full class period.Â  There is some evidence that Ms. Siewickiâ€™s observations were not for a full ninety-minute class period.Â  However, Ms. Siewicki explained she observed the entire social studies portion of one class until Mack began discussing a different subject, nutrition.Â  She also testified that she conducted her other evaluation from the beginning of class until the bell rang, which she assumed signaled the end of the period. Â Based on the testimony, we conclude that District 4 substantially complied with the mandates of the June 4 order.Â  Furthermore, there is no evidence that Mack was denied due process by the lack of strict adherence to the order.Â  In fact, Mack concedes that even if the June 4 order had been followed with absolute precision there may well have been substantial evidence to support the decision to terminate his employment.Â  The evaluations and testimony of Jones and Siewicki provide substantial evidence to support Mackâ€™s termination.Â 
For all of the foregoing reasons, the decision of the circuit court is 
 AFFIRMED.
GOOLSBY, STILWELL, and SHORT, JJ., concur.
